questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following contains both DNA and RNA?
questions.solution:
• Bacteria are prokaryotic organisms that reproduce asexually and contain both DNA and RNA; which are essential for replication, translation, and transduction.
  • In contrast, viruses can contain either DNA or RNA. Plasmids are made up of only circular DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following attributes makes CLED medium better than MacConkey agar?
questions.solution:
• CLED medium differentiates lactose fermenters from non-fer­menters and inhibits the growth of other commensals just like MacConkey medium. It allows urinary bacteria to grow and supports the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except hemolytic Streptococcus)and Candida. (Which McConkey does not) This attribute makes CLED medium better than MacConkey agar.
 
  • CLED agar (cystine lactose electrolyte deficient medium) is electrolyte deficient, hence, it also helps in preventing proteus swarming, this is the most important use of CLED agar. But proteus swarming can be prevented in MacConkey agar as well by reducing the concentration of sodium chloride. Therefore, it's not the reason for the superiority of CLED over MacConkey. 
 
  • MacConkey agar is a differential medium in which lactose fermenting( Eg E.coli) which stains pink color and Non lactose fermenting( Eg Shigella species, Salmonella) which do not change the color.
  • Contents of MacConkey agar - Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Neutral red, Sodium taurocholate.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 42.

questions.text: Which test requires a sample of whole blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: IGRA IGRA requires whole blood as the sample. Widal requires only serum, COVID-19 RT PCR requires a Nasopharyngeal/oropharyngeal swab while GeneXpert can be performed on sputum/pleural fluid/BAL, etc. IGRAs is an in-vitro blood test of cell-mediated immune response; it measures T-cell release of IFN-γ following stimulation by antigens specific to the M. tuberculosis complex (with the exception of BCG substrains), i.e. early secreted antigenic target 6 (ESAT-6) and culture filtrate protein 10 (CFP-10).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: Who is considered the father of microbiology?
questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur is often referred to as the "Father of Microbiology" due to his groundbreaking contributions to the field. Here are some key points about his work:

Contributions to Microbiology:

  1. Germ Theory of Disease: Pasteur was instrumental in developing the germ theory, which posits that many diseases are caused by microorganisms. This was a revolutionary idea at the time and laid the groundwork for modern medicine.

  2. Pasteurization: He developed the process of pasteurization, which involves heating liquids to kill harmful bacteria. This method is widely used to preserve food and beverages, particularly milk and wine.

  3. Vaccines: Pasteur created vaccines for several diseases, including rabies and anthrax. His work in immunology demonstrated that weakened forms of pathogens could be used to confer immunity.

  4. Fermentation Studies: He conducted extensive research on fermentation, demonstrating that microorganisms were responsible for the process. This work had significant implications for food production and preservation.

  5. Spontaneous Generation: Pasteur's experiments debunked the theory of spontaneous generation, showing that microorganisms came from other microorganisms, not from non-living matter.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 3.

questions.text: Mention the fundamentals of the given test for HBV
questions.solution:
The immunochromatographic test for Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) is a diagnostic technique that utilizes a specialized cassette strip to detect the presence of three major antigens (HBsAg, HBAg and HBeAg) associated with HBV. The cassette contains a sample application pad, a conjugate pad, a nitrocellulose membrane, and a visible readout. The sample is first applied to the application pad and then transferred to the conjugate pad, which contains colored particles such as blue latex beads that are specifically bound to antibodies against the HBV antigens. When the sample is added to the conjugate pad, any HBV antigens present in the sample will bind to the antibodies in the conjugate pad, forming a visible cluster of colored particles. The sample is then transferred to the nitrocellulose membrane where the binded antigen-antibody complexes are able to migrate along the membrane. The membrane is then read visually. If a visible readout of the colored clusters appears then the test is considered positive and the patient is diagnosed as HBV positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 547.

questions.text: What is the cause for the Antiseptic property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
• Bleaching powder, also known as calcium hypochlorite (CaOCi2) is produced when chlorine is passed through calcium chloride. Upon dissolving in water, it reacts with the water to form hypochlorous acid (HOCI) and hypochlorite ions (OCI-).
  • Both are potent oxidizing agents and act as disinfectants - However, it is the hypochlorous acid(HOCl) that is the most potent form of disinfectant(70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ion) because the neutral hypochlorous acid can better penetrate cell walls of pathogenic microorganisms than the negatively charged hypochlorite ion. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 577.

questions.text: Name the category A bioterrorism agent amongst the following.
questions.solution:
Category A bioterrorism agents are biological agents that have the potential to cause mass casualties and panic.
Category A bioterrorism agents include

  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis)
  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (variola major)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (filoviruses [e.g., Ebola, Marburg] and arenaviruses [e.g., Lassa, Machupo])
Category B- Minority priority agents, Moderately well disseminated, Moderate morbidity and low mortality. Eg- Coxiella burnetti, Burkholderia mallei, Burkholderia psedomallei, Ricin toxin, Cryptosporidum parvum, Salmonella typhi, Chlamydia psittaci. Category C- Low priority agents, could be engineered for mass dissemination, Readily available, Easy to produce, Potentially high morbidity and mortality. Eg- Emergent viruses: Nipah and Hantavirus, corona, H1N1, Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 662.

choices.text: Routine microscopy with a negatively stained background

questions.text: A patient is suffering from Hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's urine was collected, and a sample of it was analyzed under a microscope. What approach is being utilized to make the organism visible, out of the following list?
questions.solution:
• The given image is of a Leptospira visualized using Dark Field Microscopy. 
  • Dark field microscopy is a microscopy technique that involves illuminating a specimen with oblique or off-axis light, resulting in a dark background surrounding the specimen. This technique allows for the observation of the motility of the thin, tightly-coiled, and flexible Leptospirae as they have a thin axial filament and delicate membrane which can appear only as a chain of minute cocci. It is the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize the organism when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.
  • The Leptospira infection is suggested from the hook-like appearance of the spirochetes seen in the dark field microscopy image along with the clinical history with the patient having Hepatorenal syndrome.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: After how many hours does a nosocomial infection occur?
questions.solution:
• Hospital-acquired infections (HAI) or nosocomial are infections that are not present or are incubating at the time of a patient's admission to a healthcare setting but become clinically evident 48 hours or more after admission.
  • These infections are caused by viral, bacterial, and fungal pathogens and can lead to bloodstream infection (BSI), pneumonia (e.g., ventilator-associated pneumonia [VAP]), urinary tract infection (UTI), and surgical site infection (SSI).
  • The term 'healthcare-associated infections' is the preferred term to replace older ones like 'nosocomial', 'hospital-acquired', or 'hospital-onset' infections.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 648.

questions.text: Which specimen is stained with oil-red O
questions.solution:
Oil red O stain is used in the staining of fats (triglycerides & lipids). Among all the options given only the frozen section preserves the fat content. Alcohol and aldehyde fixatives dissolve the fat present in the specimen and hence can’t be stained by Oil red O stain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a milk pasteurization test
questions.solution:
Pasteurization is a technique used for the disinfection of milk. The efficacy of Pasteurisation can be checked by : 1. Phosphatase test: Enzyme destroyed by heat, so it is absent in pasteurized milk. 2. Standard plate/Colony count: It will be <30000 colonies/ml in pasteurized milk. 3. Coliform Test: E.coli in milk indicates fecal contamination, it is zero in pasteurized milk
Pasteurization is the process of applying heat, to milk for a specific period (71 degree Celsius for 15 seconds) followed by rapid cooling to 10 degree Celsius or less, for the purpose of killing pathogenic. There are two methods, Holder method and Flash method.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: Which of the following is an obligate anaerobic organism?
questions.solution:
• Prevotella is an obligate anaerobe.
  • Aerobic and anaerobic bacteria can be identified by growing them in test tubes of thioglycollate broth.
  • Obligate anaerobes are poisoned by oxygen and gather at the bottom of the tube where O2 is lowest while obligate aerobes gather at the top of the tube where O2 concentration is highest.
  • Prevotella resides in the oral and respiratory tract. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old non-immunized child reported to the OPD with pseudomembrane over the tonsils. A sample of the throat was collected, stained, and inspected under a microscope. Choose the correct stains from the options provided.
(i) Albert stain 1
(ii) Albert stain 2
(iii) Iodine
(iv) Acetone
(v) Methylene blue
(vi) Safranin
(vii) Water
questions.solution:
The given image shows a microscopic image of a Coryenebacterium diptheriae (History of pseudomembrane/unvaccinated child points towards diphtheria) stained with Albert’s stain.

Albert’s Staining is a type of differential stain that stains metachromatic granules/volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Albert stain is composed of two reagents— Albert stain 1 and 2 which are applied to slide respectively.

Albert Solution 1:

  • toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid, and alcohol

Albert solution 2:

  • Iodine and Potassium iodide in water


Albert's, Neisser's and ponder's stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin/Babes Ernst granules) of corynebacterium diphtheria.

Among the given options, best answer is option (1).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 673.

questions.solution:

  • Specifically, hydrogen peroxide is the active agent used in this device to eliminate hazardous microbes and pathogens that may be present. This technology can provide further safety and prevent any contamination while operating in the theater, enabling a safe and clean environment for all patients.
other commonly used methods of sterilisation are:-

questions.text: Which of the following is utilized for blood spill management?
questions.solution:
• Chlorine-based compounds  - in particular - Sodium hypochlorite are used in blood spill management.
  • It is usually diluted in water depending on its intended use.
  • "Strong chlorine solution" - 0.5% solution of hypochlorite (~ 5000 ppm free chlorine) is used for large blood spills. Such solutions have been demonstrated to inactivate both Clostridium difficile and HPV,
Option a) Chlorhexidine (hibitane) : This is one of the most useful skin antiseptics. Highly active against vegetative gram-positive organisms, and moderately active against gram-positive microbes.
Option b) Formaldehyde: it is a highly toxic gas effective against vegetative bacteria,fungi and many viruses but only slowly effective against bacterial spores. It is most commonly used for disinfection of rooms, may also be used for disinfection of blankets, beds, books and other articles which cannot be boiled.
Option c) Ethyl alcohol: Is most commonly used for skin disinfection and hand washing. It is potent bactericides, fungicidal, virucidal and tuberculocidal but does not destroy bacterial spores.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which of the following species' spores are used in an autoclave as a control?
questions.solution:
• Spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as a control in the autoclave.
  • Sterilization control of autoclave: For determining the efficacy of moist heat sterilization, spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as test organism. This is a thermophilic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 55-60 degrees and its spores require an exposure of 12 minutes at 121 degrees to be killed.
  • The effectiveness of sterilisation by hot air oven can be monitored by using biological indicators like spores of nontoxigenic strains of Clostridium tetani or Bacillus subtilis subspecies niger.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 32.

questions.text: Aerosol spread leading to epidemics is seen in infection with:
questions.solution:
• Aerosol spread leading to epidemics is seen in infection with Legionella.
  • Human infection due to Legionella is caused by inhalation of aerosols produced by air conditioners and cooling towers which act as disseminators.
  • Aerosolized legionellae can survive for very long and can be carried over for long distances.
  • No animal reservoirs exist. No evidence of human - to - transmission and no carrier state is established.

questions.text: In relation to prions, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Correct statement about prions is (1) Long incubation period. Clinical illness in the case of prions infection is preceded by a long incubation period (months to decades ).
  • Prions do not contain any nucleic acid(only protien) and cannot be detroyed by autoclaving. 
  • They are also not immunogenic. 
  • Prions cause diseases such as CJD( Creutzfeldt- Jakob disease), Kuru, Alzheimer's and Parkinsons. It has two isoforms PrpSC which causes the disease. PrpC is the normal prion found in human cells.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 448.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest antiseptic resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Prion

Prion is known to have the highest antiseptic resistance as they do not contain nucleic acid, unlike bacteria, fungi, viruses, and other pathogens. They are therefore resistant to procedures that destroy pathogens by breaking down nucleic acid. Furthermore, because these particles are an abnormal version of a normal protein that is already coded for in the body, they do not trigger a host immune response, as other pathogens do.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 560.

questions.text: All of the following statements about antibiotic resistance are true, with the exception of:

Plasmid-mediated resistance is transferred by two means - vertical transmission through cell division and horizontal transmission through conjugation. Horizontal transmission is more common than vertical.

questions.text: Match the following stains with their respective uses.
questions.solution:
(a) ZN stain is used to detect the presence of acid-fast bacteria such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which causes tuberculosis.
(b) Gram stain is used to differentiate bacterial species into two groups based on the differences in the cell wall structure. Gram-positive bacteria turn purple or blue, while Gram-negative bacteria turn red or pink. Therefore, option (ii) is correct.
(c) Albert stain is used to detect Corynebacterium diphtheriae
(d) Fite-Faraco stain is used to detect the presence of lipid-containing organisms such as Mycobacterium leprae.




Reference:  Chen, Ping et al. “A highly efficient Ziehl-Neelsen stain: identifying de novo intracellular Mycobacterium tuberculosis and improving detection of extracellular M. tuberculosis in cerebrospinal fluid.” Journal of clinical microbiology vol. 50,4 (2012): 1166-70. doi:10.1128/JCM.05756-11. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3318527/

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to?
questions.solution:
Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation.
Somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin (Ig) genes plays a key role in antibody mediated immunity
 
  • Affinity maturation is the process by which B cells produce antibodies with increasing affinity for their specific antigen during an immune response.
  • This occurs due to somatic hypermutation, a process where point mutations are introduced into the variable (V) regions of immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells within the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues.
  • B cells with higher-affinity receptors are selected for survival and proliferation through interaction with antigen-presenting cells and follicular helper T cells.


Other options: 
 

  1. Isotype Switching:

    • Also called class switch recombination (CSR), it involves changing the antibody's constant region (e.g., IgM to IgG) but does not directly improve antigen-binding affinity.

  2. mRNA Splicing:

    • This is a post-transcriptional process involved in the generation of mature mRNA and is unrelated to affinity maturation.

  3. VDJ Rearrangement:

    • This occurs during B cell development in the bone marrow and generates the initial antigen-binding diversity, but it is not responsible for the improved affinity seen during the immune response.



Reference: Lange Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, 13th edition, Page no 433.

questions.text: A transparent organism can be studied by adjusting the contrast and its living characteristics can also be noticed by?
questions.solution:
In a phase contrast microscope phase shifts are created as light travels through interior structures with various refractive indices, and phase plates then translate these phase shifts into changes in the amplitude of the light.
 
  • Phase-contrast microscopy is specifically designed to enhance the contrast of transparent and colorless specimens, such as living cells and microorganisms.
  • It works by exploiting differences in the refractive index of the specimen and the surrounding medium to produce high-contrast images without the need for staining, which is particularly useful for observing living organisms.

Other options:
 
  1. Dark field microscopy: Enhances contrast by illuminating the specimen with oblique light, making it appear bright against a dark background, but it is less effective for detailed internal structures.
  2. Electron Microscopy: Provides very high resolution for studying ultrastructures but requires fixed, non-living samples.
  3. Compound Microscope: A standard light microscope that typically requires staining to observe transparent specimens, making it less suitable for live studies.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10-12.

questions.text: Identify the test given in the image.
questions.solution:

  • Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) enables the localization of a particular DNA sequence or an entire chromosome in a cell. In order to target particular chromosomal sites in the nucleus, fluorescent DNA probes are used. Under a fluorescent microscope, the colored signals generated are observed.

questions.text: Which of the following should be done in case of a mercury spill from a sphygmomanometer?
questions.solution:
In case of a mercury spill, the following steps as given in CPCB guidelines on “Environmentally Sound Techniques for Mercury Waste Generated from Healthcare Facilities” shall be followed:
  1.  A syringe (without a needle) shall be used to suck the beads of mercury.
  2. Collected mercury should be placed slowly and carefully into an unbreakable plastic container/glass bottle with an airtight lid half filled with water.
  3. After removing larger beads, use sticky tape to collect smaller hard-to-see beads. Place the sticky tape in a punctured-proof yellow bag and secure it properly.



DO NOT's while handling a Mercury spill






Reference: CPCB guidelines on “Environmentally Sound Techniques for Mercury Waste Generated from Healthcare Facilities" (2012). URL:  https://cpcb.nic.in/openpdffile.php?id=TGF0ZXN0RmlsZS9MYXRlc3RfNThfR3VpZGVsaW5lc19Gb3JfTWVyY3VyeS5wZGY=

questions.text: Which of the following is a disinfectant but not a sanitizer?
questions.solution:

  • However, it is primarily used for disinfection rather than as a sanitizer.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a super antigen?
questions.solution:
Super antigens are class of antigens that activate T cell directly without being processed by Antigen Presenting cells.
They cause over production of cytokines leading to symptoms of shock and Multi organ failure.
Bacterial - Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome-1, Streptococcal toxin, Mycoplasma mitogen 1,Yersina Enterocolitica, ETEC Viral- EBV, CMV, Rabies nucleocapsid, HIV encoded negative regulatory factor
Fungi - Malassezia furfur.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 1326.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to detect Auto Antibodies?
questions.solution:
Indirect Immunofluoresence is used to detect antibodies against particular organisms.
This assay is used in detection of Auto antibodies in Auto immune disorders for eg. Anti nuclear Antibody {ANA} and in cases like syphlis for detection of micro-organisms like Trepenoma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 182.

questions.text: In which of the following organisms given below the genetic material Adenine is not equal to thymine?
questions.solution:
HIV consists of Single stranded RNA virus, hence Adenine will not be equal to thymine.
As per Chargaff rules -  Adenine =Thymine       Guanine= Cytosine

Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32th Edition, Page. No- 349, 352.

questions.text: Which of the following features is incorrectly matched with the disease?
questions.solution:
• Immunodeficient individuals lack the normal response to antigens. Hence no reaction seen on contact with antigen. Example - False negative Mantoux test.
  • Chickenpox infection on microscopy shows cytopathic effect of formation of multinucleated giant cells, with rounding and ballooning of infected cells.
  • Berylliosis causes chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease similar to sarcoidosis and Biopsy reveals non-caseating granulomas with monocytic infiltration.

Syphillis presents with the following lesions :

Primary syphilis - Hard chance, which is painless papule that becomes eroded and indurated.
Secondary Syphilis - Skin rashes on palms and soles which may be macular, papular, papulosquamous and nodular, but never vesicular or bullous.
Condylomata lata- mucocutaneous papules that coalesce to form large pink to grey lesions in warm moist intertriginous areas
Generalized lymphadenopathy is seen
Tertiary Syphilis - Gummas, which are locally destructive granulomatous lesions.

Reference: Essentials of Microbiology, 3rd edition, Page No 757 ,758.

questions.text: Which of the following lab sterilising techniques is used to sterilise a disposable pipette?
questions.solution:
Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Beta propiolactone/ formaldehyde Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
lonising radiation Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters,grafts

Autoclave is the most effective method to sterilise disposable pipette tips. Autoclaving involves subjecting the pipette tips to high-pressure steam at temperatures above 121°C (250°F) for around 20 minutes.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker textbook of Microbiology, 8th edition, Page No 30-38.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency diseases predisposes to infection by catalase-positive organisms?
questions.solution:
• Chronic granulomatous disease is an X linked recessive disease where Phagocytes cannot efficiently produce reactive oxygen species(ROS), which are crucial for destroying pathogens engulfed by these cells.
  • Reduced hydrogen peroxide (H202) production is the primary cause of the impaired bactericidal function.
  • Other mechanisms contributing to the disease process include Failure of leucocyte degranulation after phagocytosis, leading to delayed granule rupture and faulty release of myeloperoxidase further contributes to ineffective bactericidal activity.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease predisposes individuals to infection by catalase-positive organisms most commonly S. aureus.
  • This disease manifests itself as chronic suppurative granulomatous lesions of the skin and lymph nodes, along with hepatosplenomegaly, progressive lung infilterates and granulomatous septic osteomyelitis.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 117-118.

choices.text: Category C – Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category A – Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B – Moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates
Category D – Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement according to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents?
questions.solution:
Bioterrorism refers to the deliberate release or threat of release of biological agents, including viruses, bacteria, fungi, or their toxins, with the aim of causing disease or death among humans, livestock, or food crops. The goal is often to incite fear among the population or exert pressure on governments.

The CDC classifies bioterrorism agents into three categories:
 
  • Category A: These agents are highly transmissible from person to person and are associated with high mortality rates. They have the potential to cause significant public health emergencies.
 
  • Category B: Agents in this category are moderately easy to disseminate. They tend to cause moderate levels of illness (morbidity) and low mortality rates.
 
  • Category C: These are emerging pathogens, such as Nipah virus and Hantavirus, that could potentially be engineered for large-scale dissemination in the future. They are concerning due to their availability, high morbidity and mortality rates, and ease of production and dissemination.

There is no Category D in the CDC‘s classification system for bioterrorism agents.




Reference: Das, S, and V K Kataria. “Bioterrorism : A Public Health Perspective.” Medical journal, Armed Forces India vol. 66,3 (2010): 255-60. doi:10.1016/S0377-1237(10)80051-6. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4921253/

questions.text: The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is
questions.solution:
The India ink stain is commonly used to identify Cryptococcus species.

This method involves negative staining, which creates a dark background, allowing the unstained, encapsulated organisms to stand out. It is particularly useful for detecting organisms with capsules that do not retain simple stains, such as Cryptococcus neoformans.

In the India ink preparation, Cryptococcus neoformans appears as a globular, encapsulated yeast, with or without budding, and ranges from 5 to 20 μm in diameter. The capsule is visible against the dark background created by the stain.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biological samples such as CSF, sputum, and skin biopsies using routine fungal or bacterial culture media. Colonies typically appear white-to-cream coloured and may turn orange-tan or brown after extended incubation. They also exhibit a mucoid appearance due to their polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is done by
questions.solution:
• Plasma sterilization (also called hydrogen peroxide gas plasma sterilization) is a low-temperature sterilization method.

  • It uses hydrogen peroxide vapor which is energized into plasma (ionized state) by radiofrequency or microwave energy.

  • The plasma produces free radicals that destroy microorganisms (bacteria, spores, viruses, fungi).

  • Advantages: Fast cycle time, safe, no toxic residues.

  • Other options:

    • UV rays: Used for surface disinfection, not sterilization.

    • Gamma rays: Used for industrial sterilization (e.g., disposable syringes, catheters).

    • Ethylene oxide (ETO): Gas sterilization for heat/moisture-sensitive materials, but not plasma.



Instruments such as arthroscopes and ureteroscopes are commonly sterilized using plasma sterilization. The effectiveness of this sterilization method is monitored using Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus as control organisms.

questions.text: The culture media that is used to differentiate lactose fermenters and non-lactose fermenters is
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to differentiate lactose fermenters, which appear pink, from non-lactose fermenters, which remain colorless or pale.



Selectivity and Differential Nature:
Selective: The medium contains bile salts and dyes that inhibit the growth of gram-positive organisms and gram-negative cocci.
Differential: The presence of a pH indicator allows for the identification of lactose fermentation; when lactose is fermented, the pH indicator turns pink-red.
Contents of MacConkey Agar:
Mnemonic: PLANT

Peptone
Lactose
Agar
Neutral red
Taurocholate sodium
Color Reactions:
Lactose-fermenting organisms (e.g., E. coli): Produce a pink color due to acid production from lactose fermentation.
Non-lactose fermenting organisms (e.g., Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.): Do not change the color of the medium, remaining colorless or pale.

questions.text: Which of the following is a category B bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Category B bioterrorism agents are moderately easy to disseminate, result in moderate morbidity and low mortality rates
Example Brucella. Ref-Essentials of Microbiology • Page no: 821

questions.text: A patient was infected by Bacillus anthracis. Under which of the following bioterrorism categories does this organism fall into:
questions.solution:
The anthrax-causing bacteria, Bacillus anthracis, is categorized as a Category A bioterrorism agent.

The deliberate release of dangerous biological agents by attackers in order to spread illness is known as bioterrorism. Three categories are used to group these agents:

Category A agents can have a major impact on public health, have high mortality rates, and are highly transmissible between persons. Yersinia pestis, Clostridium botulinum, and Bacillus anthracis are a few examples.

Agents in category B cause moderate disease and have lower death rates since they are relatively easy to distribute. Brucella and Coxiella burnetii are two examples.

Because of their accessibility, high rates of illness and mortality, ease of manufacture and distribution, and potential for widespread release in the future, emerging pathogens are classified as Category C agents. Hantavirus and Nipah virus are two examples.



Reference
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology - 9th Edition - page 325-330, 420, 240-242

questions.text: E.coli can be grown best in which of the following media?
questions.solution:
The best media to grow E. Coli is MacConkey agar.

Lactose fermentators (seen as pink colonies) and nonlactose fermentators (shown as colorless or pale) can be distinguished using MacConkey agar. It is a differential and selective medium. Because bile salts and dyes inhibit both Gram-positive and Gram-negative cocci, MacConkey agar is selective. Because the pH indicator becomes pink-red as lactose ferments, it is differential.

MacConkey agar contents: Mnemonic: PLANT
  • Peptide
  • L-lactose
  • Agar
  • N-Red, neutral
  • Taurocholate 

Alternatives

The treatment for Hemophillus influenza is chocolate agar.

For Nesseria, Thyer-Martin agar is utilized.

Fungal culture is carried out on SDA agar.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no 42

questions.text: Where is the IgE receptor found?
questions.solution:
The IgE receptor (FcεRI) is primarily found on: Mast cells/Basophils and Eosinophils (to a lesser extent)

This receptor binds IgE antibodies, playing a crucial role in allergic reactions and parasite defense. When an allergen cross-links IgE bound to mast cells, it triggers degranulation, releasing histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

Other options

  • Promonocyte (2): These are precursors to monocytes/macrophages and do not express FcεRI.

  • T lymphocyte (3): T cells do not have FcεRI; they interact with antigens via T-cell receptors (TCR).

  • NK cell (4): Natural Killer (NK) cells express Fcγ receptors (for IgG) but not FcεRI.


  

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: Which of the following fragments is formed when IgG is hydrolyzed with papain?
questions.solution:
Memorizing Trick: -
PApaine- cleaves Above


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 96.

questions.text: Which disease's immunopathogenesis is associated with antibody-dependent enhancement?
questions.solution:
• Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) also known as the Halsted phenomenon happens when non-neutralizing antiviral antibodies make it easier for viruses to enter host cells, increasing the cells' capacity to spread infection.
  • Some cells lack the typical receptors that viruses employ to attach to their surfaces. The antiviral proteins, or antibodies, attach to antibody Fe receptors found on the plasma membrane of certain of these cells. The antigen-binding site on the antibody's opposite end is where the viruses attach.
  • The scenario of dengue virus infection is the most well-known instance of ADE (DENV). This virus can infect human macrophages through this route, turning a typically moderate viral infection into a potentially fatal condition.
  • The phenomenon of ADE may be observed when a person who has previously been infected with one serotype of DENV becomes infected many months or years later with a different serotype.
  • This explains the finding that while primary infections (initial infections) primarily result in moderate disease (DF) in children, secondary infections (re-infections at a later time) are more frequently linked to severe disease (DHF and/or DSS) in both children and adults.
Audio explanation for the above.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: What causes naive T-cell activation?
questions.solution:
While Dendritic cells, Macrophages, and B-lymphocytes - all three are APC(Antigen-presenting cells) - The Naive T-cells get activated predominantly by dendritic cells. They are the most crucial antigen-presenting cells for triggering T-cell responses against protein antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure whereby macrophages engulf various cells as seen in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Emperipolesis is the active engulfment of one cell by another, which remains intact. Seen in Rosai Dorfman disease.
  • In contrast to phagocytosis, where the engulfing cell is killed by the protective action of lysosomal enzymes, it exists momentarily within another cell and with an entire normal structure.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 840.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to killing caused by antibodies?
questions.solution:
Effector cells that mediate Antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity include NK Cells, monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils,   eosinophils and dendritic cells.
 
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity is a different process that can result in antibody-mediated cell death (ADCC).
A number of effector cells, primarily NK cells and macrophages, destroy cells that are coated with IgG antibodies by binding to the largest amount of the Fc fragment of IgG, which results in cell destruction without phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune privilege site?
questions.solution:
Seminiferous tubule of testis is an immune-privileged site.

Immune-privileged sites
  • Due to the tissues' inability to communicate with the blood and lymph, some antigens are hidden (sequestered) from the immune system.
  • Self-antigens in these tissues consequently do not trigger immunological responses and are generally disregarded by the immune system.
  • Such sites are referred to as immune-privileged sites because it is challenging to elicit immune responses in response to antigens injected into them.
  • Eye lens, CNS, and testis are examples of Immune Privileged sites. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 188.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions exhibit anti-centromere antibodies?
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies are seen in scleroderma.

The CREST (calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia) variety of the restricted type of systemic sclerosis is frequently characterized by a chronic course and anticentromere antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th edition, Page no 2089.

questions.text: What purpose does the technique shown in the image serve?
questions.solution:
The given diagram is known as the hybridoma technique for the development of monoclonal antibodies.

A mouse is given an antigen to which B cells in the spleen make antibodies.
These lymphocyte cells (seen as spleen cells in the diagram) are gathered and combined with myeloma cells to form hybridomas.
These hybridomas then divide and produce monoclonal antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 150.

questions.text: What stimulates IFN-beta?
questions.solution:
IFN-beta is stimulated by viral infection.

After being stimulated by viruses or polynucleotides, fibroblast and epithelial cells synthesize beta interferon (IFN-B), formerly known as fibroblast interferon. It is glycoprotein in nature. 
Types of Interferons: •IFN alpha - Leukocyte Interferon, has antiviral activity. •IFN beta - Produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells, has antiviral activity. •IFN gamma - Produced by T- lymphocytes, has immunomodulatory and anti- proliferative functions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 352.

questions.text: Which of the following determines whether an immunoglobin will get secreted or remain membrane bound?
questions.solution:
Alternative splicing—can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) sequence (eg, transmembrane vs secreted Ig, tropomyosin variants in muscle, dopamine receptors in the brain, host defense evasion by tumor cells).

 

  • Alternate splicing of the immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy chain gene determines whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or remain membrane-bound. During B cell development, the splicing mechanism can generate two different forms of the immunoglobulin: a membrane-bound form that is part of the B cell receptor (BCR) and a secreted form that is released into the bloodstream as an antibody.

    The other options are not directly involved in determining whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or membrane-bound:

    2. Class switching refers to the change in the constant region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (e.g., switching from IgM to IgG), not whether it is secreted or membrane-bound.

    • 3. Differential RNA Processing is a broader term that could refer to various modifications in RNA, but in this context, alternate splicing specifically controls the secretion or membrane binding.

    • 4. Allelic Exclusion ensures that each B cell produces antibodies from only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene, but it does not affect the secretion vs. membrane-bound decision.

Reference: Harpers Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Page no 371.

choices.text: It mediates  the release of histamine and other chemical mediators
It is the primary antibody involved in allergic reactions
It is involved in anti-parasitic immune responses
May cross the placenta and fix complement

questions.text: Which of the following statements about IgE antibodies is incorrect?
questions.solution:
People who have been exposed to certain antigens in the past and have developed antibodies to it (IgE) may experience an immediate allergic response if re-exposed, known as Immediate or Type I Hypersensitivity. This is a fast-acting immunologic reaction which can happen within minutes following the combination of the antigen and the antibodies to it, bound to mast cells. IgE antibodies do NOT cross the placenta. IgG is the only class of immunoglobulins which can cross the placenta
Ig E has the following features:
•Half-life 1 to 5 days.
•Causes type 1 hypertensivity reaction.
•It is the only heat liable antibody.
•Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 101.

questions.text: Which is the complement complex that attacks cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Membrane attack complex(MAC) formed as the end result of Complement pathways is made up of C5-C9 complement proteins.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 126.

questions.text: Select the complement factor that is a marker of humoral rejection.
questions.solution:
• Deposition of Complement breakdown product "C4d" in allo­grafts is a strong indicator of humoral rejection because C4d is pro­duced during activation of the complement system by the Antibody­ Dependent classical pathway.
  • It also provides the rationale for treating affected patients with B-cell-depleting agents(eg. Rituximab)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 237.

questions.text: Which of these is not a antigen-presenting cell?
questions.solution:
Antigen-presenting cells (APC)

  • These cells process and present antigens via MHC II to Th-cells. The immune system contains three types of antigen-presenting cells, i.e., macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells.
  • Langerhans cells are developmentally similar to dendritic cells. M cells express the protease cathepsin E, similar to other antigen-presenting cells.
  • Thymocytes are not antigen-presenting cells.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: What is Serum sickness?
questions.solution:
• Serum Sickness is an example of a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.
  • The most common diseases involving a type III hypersensitivity reaction include serum sickness, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, farmers' lungs (hypersensitivity pneumonitis), and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Eg of Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: Post streptococcus glomerulonephritis, SLE, Polyarteritis nodosa, Reactive arthritis, Serum sickness, Arthur reaction, Farmer's lung, Hypersensitivity pneumonia, Type 2 lepra reaction, Henoch schonlein purpura.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 164.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T-cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What role does Major Histocompatibility complex-1 and complex-2 play?
questions.solution:
MHC proteins - Their role is in the recognition and presentation of antigens to the immune system. MHC class I (MHC1) - Present on all nucleated cells and platelets - They are responsible for presenting HIV, EBV, and CMV viruses, among others, to our immune system. MHC class II (MHC2) - Present on Antigen-presenting cells - are responsible for presenting pollen, foods, and other foreign proteins to the immune system.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 141.

questions.text: What is opsonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  C3b

Opsonin is an antibody or other substance which binds to foreign microorganisms or cells making them more susceptible to phagocytosis.
C3b is known to be the best opsonizer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 124.

questions.text: Xenograft resistance in naked mice is not present due to the lack of
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell. A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant form a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T-lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T-cells and cytotoxic T-cells. The absence of functioning T-cells also prevents the rejection of allografts and xenografts.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 217.

choices.text: Proximal domains of alpha and beta subunit
Distal domains of alpha and beta subunit

questions.text: For the purpose of delivering processed antigen to CD8 T lymphocytes, the peptide binding site on class I MHC molecules is produced by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Distal domain of alpha subunit MHC 1 molecule is made of Alpha1,2,3 and Beta 2 microglobulin. Alpha 1 and 2 form peptide binding groove in which peptides of endogenous antigens connect with CD8 cytotoxic T Lymphocytes. MHC is found in all nucleated cells, APCs and Platelets (except RBCs).


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 141.

questions.text: Mention the class of antibody shown in the immunoglobulin structure.
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is a type of antibody found in the secretions of the body such as saliva, tears, respiratory and intestinal mucosal secretions. IgA is a dimer, consisting of two monomers joined together by a J-chain. There are two subclasses of IgA, IgA1, found predominately in serum, and IgA2, found predominantly in the body secretions. Due to its secretory component, IgA is effective at mediating local or mucosal immunity, meaning it can protect against infection on the mucosal surface like in the digestive or respiratory system. IgA is the most abundant antibody found in the human body and is therefore important in protecting against infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 99.

choices.text: resides in the epithelial layer of mucosa.

questions.text: Identify the function/correct option about gamma-delta T-cells from the following options-
questions.solution:
5–10% of the T cells in circulation are gamma-delta T cells, located in epithelial surfaces. They have gamma-delta heterodimer receptors, which have limited diversity and can identify phospholipid antigens, as opposed to helper and cytotoxic T cells, which have alpha-beta heterodimer receptors.
  • They differ from the conventional alpha-beta T cells by the fact that they do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides
  • They are part of innate immunity as the gamma-delta receptors exhibit limited diversity for the antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Mast cells are activated by?
questions.solution:
Mast cells are activated by the cross-linking of high-affinity IgE receptors, as are their circulating counterparts, basophils.
Mast cells can also be activated by a variety of different factors, such as complements C5a and C3a, which work by binding to receptors on the mast cell membrane and are known as anaphylatoxins because they generate reactions that resemble anaphylaxis.

Some chemokines, such as IL-8, as well as medications like codeine and morphine, adenosine, and melittin (found in bee venom), are additional mast cell secretagogues.

Molecules/Cytokines functioning as Mast cell secretagogues
  • C3a
  • C5a
  • IL- 8
  • Codeine
  • Morphine
  • Adenosine
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: The delayed hypersensitive reaction is caused by what type of cell or mediator
questions.solution:
In type IV Hypersensitivity reactions, Antigen-presenting cells activate Th1/cytotoxic T cells. T-cells then recruit macrophages and release inflammatory cytokines.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 169.

questions.text:
What cell mediators are involved in the Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
i. Mast cell
ii. Histamine
iii. Prostaglandins
iv. Neutrophils
questions.solution:
Mast Cells, histamine, and Prostaglandins are involved in Type I hypersensitivity reaction.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Which of the following is the basis for the Paul-Bunnel test?
questions.solution:
Heterophile antibodies are antibodies directed against external antigens which cross react with self antigens.

In Paul - Bunnell test, heterophile antibodies in the patient’s blood sample is made to react with sheep, horse or cow red blood cell antigens. This works on the principle of latex agglutination reaction.

Paul - Bunnell test was used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis by Ebstein - Barr Virus (EBV).

In patients with IMN, there is production of heterophile antibodies.

Other examples of Heterophile antibodies: -

  • Weil-Felix test
  • Monospot test
  • Cold Agglutination test 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: \(\gamma\delta\)-T cell is associated with:
questions.solution:
T cells that are mature and have a population that is small have a TCR that is of a different kind and consists of gamma and delta polypeptide chains. This gamma delta TCR is able to identify peptides, lipids and small molecules, not needing any assistance of MHC's proteins.

This type of T cell has a tendency to group together on epithelial surfaces, like skin, gastrointestinal and urinary mucosa, suggesting they serve as guard against organisms that try to enter by means of epithelial membranes. Nonetheless, the specificities of gamma delta T cells are yet to be figured out.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text:
There was a brucellosis suspicion regarding a patient. A sample of serum was sent for a routine agglutination test. When the sample was diluted, the test result changed from negative to positive.
What might have caused the original negative test results?
questions.solution:
Antibody overproduction occurs in the prozone. Due to their modest size, the immunological complexes generated in this zone are challenging to find. IgG, IgA, and IgM antibodies are discovered using the Standard Agglutination Test. 48 hours are spent incubating the sample at 37 degrees Celsius.
A titre of 1:160 or higher is regarded as important. Prozone phenomenon and the presence of insufficient or blocking antibodies are both associated with false negative SAT.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: Identify the conjugated antibody in the following figure:
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the antibody numbered 1 is the conjugate antibody.
 
The figure shows a molecular investigation technique which is used for the detection of the antibody marked 2. Since the antibody 1, is attached to the primary antibody (marked 2), it is known as the secondary or conjugated antibody with which a conjugated enzyme is attached. This conjugated enzyme is used to form an end product which can be easily detected. In this manner, the levels of Antibody 2 are measured indirectly.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: What does the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involve after the binding of complement and antibodies to the surface of encapsulated bacteria?
questions.solution:
After binding of complement and antibody on the surface of encapsulated bacteria, the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involves C3b and Fc. One of the most efficient ways of enhancing the phagocytosis of particles is coating the particles with IgG antibodies specific for the particles, which are then recognized by the high-affinity Fc receptor of phagocytes.
Components of the complement system, like fragments of the complement protein C3, are also potent opsonins.(C3b)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 177.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not apply to both "T cells" and "B cells"?
questions.solution:
Positive selection during development is a feature not shared between T-cells and B-cells.

During the course of development B-cells undergo negative selection while T-cells undergo both positive and negative selection.

Class I MHC is present in both T cells and B cells have additionally Class II MHC. Both have antigen specific receptors. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 131.

questions.text:
Which is the most common complement component deficiency?
1. C1
2. C2
3. C3
4. C4
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: C2

The most common complement deficiency is c2. It is seen in 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 20,000 patients. It is often associated with IgG deficiency.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 128.

questions.text: Identify the example of Type-II hypersensitivity.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Myasthenia gravis

Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction refers to an antibody-mediated immune reaction in which antibodies (IgG or IgM) are directed against cellular or extracellular matrix antigens, resulting in cellular destruction, functional loss, or tissue damage. In myasthenia gravis, antibodies are produced against the neuromuscular junction.
Atopic asthma- Type 1
Contact dermatitis- Type 4
Arthus reaction- Type 3

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: What do we call the sort of immunity to a specific infectious agent that comes after recovery from that infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Active adaptive immunity
Adaptive immunity is a type of immune response that is specific to a particular pathogen.
  • Active adaptive immunity refers to the immune response that develops after an individual is exposed to a pathogen and recovers from the resulting infection. During this process, the immune system produces memory cells that "remember" the pathogen and can mount a rapid and effective response if the individual is exposed to the same pathogen again in the future.
  • It involves the activation of lymphocytes, such as B cells and T cells, which recognize and respond to specific antigens on the surface of the pathogen.
  • This type of immunity is acquired over time, either through natural exposure to a pathogen or through vaccination.
  • This is why individuals who have had certain infections, such as chickenpox or measles, are typically immune to those diseases for the rest of their lives.
  • Passive adaptive immunity, on the other hand, refers to the transfer of pre-formed antibodies or immune cells from one individual to another. This type of immunity is typically short-lived and does not involve the activation of the recipient's own immune system. An example of passive adaptive immunity is the transfer of maternal antibodies to a developing fetus during pregnancy.
  • Innate immunity, both active and passive, is the first line of defense against pathogens and is not specific to a particular pathogen. It includes physical barriers, such as the skin and mucous membranes, as well as cellular and molecular components of the immune system that recognize and respond to common features of pathogens.
    Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 83.

questions.text: Which of the following does not use labelled antibody?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Haemagglutination

Except for haemagglutination, all other tests use labelled antibodies. Hemagglutination is a reaction that causes clumping of red blood cells in the presence of some enveloped viruses, such as the influenza virus. A glycoprotein on the viral surface, namely hemagglutinin, interacts with red blood cells, leading to the clumping of red blood cells and the formation of a lattice.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 112.

questions.text: Vaccines are not prepared using:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Antiserum

Antiserum is a blood serum that contains antibodies against an antigen. This is not used in the preparation of vaccines.
Example is Anti Snake Venom(ASV).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does T cells and B cells not share?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Positive Selection During Development

In positive selection, T cells in the thymus that binds moderately to MHC complexes receive survival signals. However, T cells whose TCRs bind too strongly to MHC complexes, and will likely be self-reactive, are killed in the process of negative selection. This property is not shown by B cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 131.

questions.text: A child who has bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysacchride rich capsules Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies is most likely to result in these infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: IgA + IgG2
  • Low levels of IgA can be seen with deficiencies of one or more IgG subclasses mostly IgG2. Infections by encapsulated bacteria (Hemophilus influenza and Streptococcus pneumoniae) are seen here which present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgA + IgG2 deficiency is the most likely immunoglobulin subclass deficiency to result in bacterial sinopulmonary infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules.
  • IgA is the primary immunoglobulin found in mucosal secretions and is important in preventing infections at mucosal surfaces.
  • IgG1 and IgG3 are important in opsonization and complement activation, which are important mechanisms for clearing bacterial infections. IgG2 is important for opsonization and complement activation against encapsulated bacteria.
  • Polysaccharide capsules are a virulence factor used by bacteria to evade the immune system.
  • The antibodies against these capsules are primarily IgA and IgG2.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in both IgA and IgG2 would make a person more susceptible to bacterial infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In summary, a child with bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysaccharide-rich capsules is most likely to have an IgA + IgG2 deficiency.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: A child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions. Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies has to be specifically looked into?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: IgG2
  • IgG2 infections are most commonly associated with capsulated organisms such as H. influenza. These present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgG2 deficiency needs to be specifically looked into in a child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions.
  • IgG2 is an important immunoglobulin subclass that plays a crucial role in the defense against bacterial infections, particularly those caused by encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • These bacteria have polysaccharide capsules that protect them from phagocytosis by macrophages and neutrophils.
  • However, IgG2 can recognize and bind to these capsules, facilitating opsonization and phagocytosis by immune cells.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in IgG2 can lead to recurrent infections with these bacteria.
  • On the other hand, deficiencies in IgA and IgG1 are associated with recurrent respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, but not specifically with polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgD deficiency is very rare and is not known to cause recurrent infections.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A foundational idea behind vaccination is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Immunologic Memory 

Vaccinations take advantage of memory lymphocyte development by artificially generating active immunity, a process called immunization. During a vaccination, the antigen of a pathogen is introduced into the body and stimulates the immune system to develop specific immunity against that pathogen. It doesn’t cause the disease that the pathogen brings because the vaccine uses an attenuated form of the pathogen that contains the same antigen but doesn’t have the capacity for replication.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: Except for_______, all of the following tests include Heterophile agglutination.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Rose-Waaler test

The Waaler Rose test is a slide hemagglutination method for the qualitative and semi-quantitative detection of RF in human serum. Stabilized sheep erythrocytes sensitized with rabbit IgG anti-sheep erythrocytes are agglutinated when mixed with samples containing RF.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins is a pentamer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Ig M 

IgM is a pentamer. It forms groups of five in solution.
Other options- IgA - Dimer
IgD - Monomer
IgG - Monomer

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 106.

questions.text: Antigen bound MHC class I binds and activates which of the following?
questions.solution:
• MHC I is found on all nucleated cells while MHCII is Found only on APC(Antigen-presenting cells).
  • Antigen-bound MHC class I binds and activates CD8+ cells which are cytotoxic T cells.




 Reference : Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 140 .

questions.text: Identify the cells stained by Toluidine blue?
questions.solution:
• Toluidine blue is a basic metachromatic dye commonly used in histology to stain mast cells.
  • Mast cells contain abundant granules that have an affinity for basic dyes, including toluidine blue. When stained with toluidine blue, mast cells appear purple or blue-purple due to the metachromatic staining property.


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 85,100,191,206,207,685,760,932,956,1152,1237 .

questions.text: Which among the following is a marker of NK cells?
questions.solution:
• The marker of NK cells among the options provided is CD 94 (option 4)
  • It forms a heterodimer with NKG2 proteins on the surface of NK cells.
  • The CD94-NKG2 complex acts as a receptor for certain MHC class I molecules and is involved in NK cell recognition and elimination of target cells, particularly those infected with viruses. 



 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 191,192,195 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
The component that is not a part of innate immunity among the given options is B lymphocytes. 

B-lymphocytes
B-lymphocytes are primarily associated with adaptive immunity rather than innate immunity. B-lymphocytes play a crucial role in adaptive immunity by producing antibodies, which are specific proteins that recognize and bind to specific antigens.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 190, 191, 193, 824 .

questions.text:
Which among the following is wrongly matched about the primary and secondary immune response? 

Primary Immune Response (PIR)           Secondary Immune Response (SIR)
questions.solution:
Option (3) is incorrect. High-affinity antibodies are seen in secondary immune response and Low-affinity antibodies are seen in primary. 
 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 147,148 .

questions.text: A 50-year old woman develops features as shown below after application of hair dye. Which component of the hair dye is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The female after application of hair dye develops intense acute edema over the entire face, prominent in the periorbital region, likely, representing a hypersensitivity reaction to a component of the hair dye (contact dermatitis) 
A substance called p-phenylenediamine which is an azo dye intermediate, most commonly used in permanent hair dyes as a black dye is the likely agent responsible for the patient’s dermatitis.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 128.15, 89.73, 128.60.

questions.text: IgM and IgD antibodies are expressed at the same time by B cells due to ?
questions.solution:
RNA splicing is the process by which different proteins are produced from the RNA transcript by splicing it in different ways.
B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to to alternative RNA splicing.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 203, 591.

questions.text: A boy, upon disturbing a bee hive, received several stings. After a few minutes, he developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. This is an example of
questions.solution:
The child developed anaphylactic shock following multiple bee stings. This is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction, which is IgE-mediated.

Here’s what happens:

  • On first exposure, the allergen (bee venom) stimulates IgE antibody production.

  • These IgE antibodies attach to mast cells and basophils.

  • On subsequent exposure, the allergen cross-links the surface-bound IgE, causing massive degranulation and release of histamine, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins.

  • This leads to bronchospasm, hypotension, urticaria, and vascular collapse — the hallmarks of anaphylaxis.

Hence, this is a Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE.

questions.text: A patient presents with PUO. He is suspected to be suffering from brucellosis. Multiple dilutions of his serum sample are put up for a standard agglutination test. The results came as follows: Negative agglutination for the serum dilutions 1:20 and 1:40; But 1:80 and 1:160 were positive for agglutination. Which of the following is responsible for the negative test in the first 2 dilutions?
questions.solution:
The negative test results observed in the first two tubes are due to the prozone phenomenon, where an excess of antibodies compared to antigens leads to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains how precipitation and agglutination reactions occur. The amount of precipitate formed depends significantly on the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation happens when a lattice of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

Key points related to this phenomenon:

- The prozone phenomenon occurs when there are excessive antibodies in the test system. This results in weak or absent precipitation, leading to a false-negative test result.

- In the zone of equivalence, the antigen and antibody are present in optimal proportions, leading to maximum precipitation and enhanced lattice formation.


- The post-zone phenomenon arises when there are excessive antigens in the test system, also resulting in weak or absent precipitation.

Both the prozone and post-zone phenomena can cause false-negative results in precipitation reactions. These false negatives can be corrected by making serial dilutions of the serum, which optimizes the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 107 .

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin G (IgG) is the most abundant immunoglobulin in serum, making up about 80% of total serum immunoglobulins. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response and is equally distributed between the intravascular and extravascular compartments.

Key Features of IgG:
Highest concentration of all immunoglobulins in serum.
Crosses the placenta, making it the only immunoglobulin to do so, providing natural passive immunity to newborns, protecting them from infections during early life.
It is involved in neutralizing toxins, opsonization (tagging pathogens for destruction), and activating the complement system, thus enhancing immune responses.
This makes IgG a vital component in both maternal and infant immunity.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is caused by
questions.solution:
• Type 2 lepra reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum, ENL) occurs in lepromatous leprosy.

  • It is mediated by immune complex deposition in tissues, leading to:

    • Fever, painful nodules, arthralgia, and systemic symptoms

  • This mechanism is characteristic of Type III (immune complex–mediated) hypersensitivity.

Other options:

  • Type II hypersensitivity: Antibody-mediated cytotoxic reaction; seen in Goodpasture’s, hemolytic anemia, not ENL.

  • Type IV hypersensitivity: T-cell–mediated delayed hypersensitivity; seen in tuberculin reaction, type 1 lepra reaction.

  • Type I hypersensitivity: IgE-mediated; seen in allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis.


Reference
Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 12 Edition - Page 343

questions.text: Two days after the administration of penicillin, a patient developed hemolysis due to antibodies produced against the drug. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
• Drug-induced hemolytic anemia occurs when penicillin binds to red blood cells, forming a hapten-RBC complex.

  • The immune system produces IgG or IgM antibodies against this complex.

  • Mechanism: Antibody-mediated cytotoxicity, leading to RBC destruction → hemolysis.

  • This reaction typically occurs within 1–2 days in sensitized individuals.

Other options:

  • Type I: IgE-mediated immediate hypersensitivity (anaphylaxis, urticaria).

  • Type III: Immune complex-mediated (serum sickness, Arthus reaction).

  • Type IV: T-cell–mediated delayed hypersensitivity (contact dermatitis, tuberculin test).



Reference
Kuby Immunology - 6th Edition - Page 504-505

questions.text: One of the effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity involves identifying and lysing target cells whose membrane surface antigens are bound by specific antibodies.NK cells are one of the effector cells capable of this process. What other cells are capable of this process?
questions.solution:
The question describes Antibody-Dependent Cell-Mediated Cytotoxicity (ADCC) — an important effector mechanism of the immune system where cells kill targets that are coated with antibodies.

What is ADCC?

  • ADCC occurs when immune cells bind to the Fc portion of antibodies (usually IgG or IgE) that are attached to target cells (e.g., virus-infected cells, tumor cells, or parasites).

  • This leads to lysis or apoptosis of the target cell.

  • Neutrophils: Use Fcγ receptors to recognize IgG-coated cells and kill them using reactive oxygen species and enzymes.

  • Eosinophils: Play a major role in ADCC against parasites by binding to IgE-coated helminths and releasing major basic protein and other cytotoxic granules.

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • 1. Macrophages only: While macrophages can phagocytose antibody-coated particles, they are not the only cells capable of ADCC.

  • 3. NK cells only: NK cells are major ADCC players, but not the only ones.

  • 4. Neutrophils only: Neutrophils are involved, but excluding eosinophils makes this option incorrect.



Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 192

questions.text: Enterohemorrhagic, enterotoxigenic, enteropathogenic and enteroinvasive are classifications of which of the following:
questions.solution:
Types of E. Coli causing diarrhoea are- 
 
  • Entero Pathogenic
  • Entero Invasive
  • Entero Toxic
  • Entero Hemorrhagic
  • Entero Aggregative
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

choices.text: It formed a biofilm on bronchial walls
It is resistant to most of antibiotics
There is a mistake with the culture technique

questions.text: A patient with cystic fibrosis is experiencing a case of pneumonia. Pseudomonas mucoid colonies were observed on sputum culture. What does this imply?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: It formed a biofilm on bronchial walls

Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Pseudomonas cepacia are the most common cause of opportunistic respiratory tract infections like pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients. It promotes infection by various factors, one of the most important factors being biofilm formation.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 322.

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae disrupts which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Cholera toxin produces Camp which in turn lead to increase chloride ion secretion in to cell lead to loss of tight junction/ zonula occludens in the cells. This leads to the watery diarrhea in Cholera. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: A young lady presents with signs of uncontrollable movements. Acute rheumatic fever and Sydenham's chorea are suspected. Other key Rheumatic fever criteria (arthritis, skin rashes, subcutaneous nodules, and carditis) were not present. There was no sign of a sore throat. What is the best inquiry to prove rheumatic aetiology?
questions.solution:
In the scenario described, where a young lady presents with signs of uncontrollable movements suggestive of Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever, but without other common criteria (like arthritis, skin rashes, subcutaneous nodules, or carditis), and no signs of a sore throat, the best inquiry to prove a rheumatic etiology would be:

2. Antistreptolysin O (ASO)

The ASO titer measures antibodies against streptolysin O, a substance produced by group A Streptococcus. An elevated ASO titer can indicate a recent streptococcal infection, which is relevant for diagnosing rheumatic fever.

While throat culture (option 3) could help identify an active infection, it may not be applicable in the absence of a sore throat.
PCR for M protein (option 4) could detect the bacteria but is less commonly used for diagnosing rheumatic fever compared to ASO.

Therefore, Antistreptolysin O (ASO) is the best choice for proving the rheumatic etiology in this case.

 
World Health Criteria for the diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever and Rheumatic Heart Disease
Major Criteria Minor Criteria Supporting evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection within the last 45 days
  1. Carditis
  2. Migratory polyarthritis
  3. Syndenham's chorea
  4. Subcutaneousnodules0
  5. Erythema marginatum
  • Clinical: Fever, polyarthralgia
  • Laboratory: Elevated ESR or leukocyte count
  • ECG: Prolonged P-R interval
 Revised Jones criteria do
not include elevated leucocyte count as a  laboratory minor mani- festation (but do include elevated C-reactive protein)
  • Elevated or rising anti-streptolysin O or other streptococcal antibody, or
  • A positive throat culture, or
  • Rapid antigen test for group A streptococcus0, or
  • Recent scarlet fever @1992 Revised Jones
criteria do not include recent scarlet fever as
supporting evidence of a recent streptococcal infection



 
Diagnostic categories Criteria
Primary episode of rheumatic fever Two major or one major two minor manifestations plus evidence of preceding group A streptococcal infection
Recurrent attack of rheumatic fever in a patient without established rheumatic heart disease Two major or one minor manifestations plus evidence of
preceding group A streptococcal infection
Recurrent attack of rheumatic fever in a patient with established rheumatic heart disease Two minor manifestations plus evidence of preceding group A streptococcal infection


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 218.

questions.text: Which bacteria are seen in the next stained slide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Nocardia asteroides
