The image shows acid-fast bacteriae with fine, right-angled, branching filaments which is characteristic of Nocardia asteroides. They are seen as pink rods against a blue background.
Other options – Actinomyces israelii is not acid-fast. 
M. tuberculous and M. leprae are straight rods with the absence of branching.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a Staphylococcus aureus disease that is not mediated by a toxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Septicemic shock

The septic shock caused by staphylococcus aureus is mediated by the dissemination of the bacteria itself and not by the production of toxins. This leads to widespread sepsis and hypotension which can be fatal if untreated.
Other options- Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin whereas TSS is caused by TSS toxin-1.
SSSS is caused by epidermolytic toxin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 205.

questions.text: Conjunctivitis in a two-week-old baby subsequently progressed to respiratory distress and pneumonia. X-ray of the chest revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. 14,300 WBCs were found in 1 microL. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of inclusion conjunctivitis in neonates that are under two weeks old. If not treated promptly, it progresses to pnuemonia. S.agalactiae causes meiningitis in neonates but is very rare to cause conjunctivitis

•As Chlamydia is a bacteria, it possess both DNA and RNA. •Chlamydia are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. They are filterable like viruses. They are called energy parasites as they lack enzymes for ATP synthesis. They cannot grow on artificial media but can grow on cell lines like Mccoy, Hela, or the yolk sac of the chicken embryo. •It occur in two forms Elementary body and Reticulate body.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 426.

questions.text: The image below shows a wet mount of a scraping taken from a young, sexually active female with a genital ulcer. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright / Giemsa - stained impression. Smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononucleosis cells (called pund cells).
Klebseilla granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a Safety pin appearance.
 
other options:-
(2) Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonococcal urethritis with purulent discharge
(3) Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid - having painful soft ulcer which bleeds on touch and painful bubos.
(4) Gardnerella vaginalis causes vaginitis - no itching with white discharge of fishy smell. They show characteristic vaginal epithelial cells containing intracellular organisms called Clue cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 681.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient arrived complaining of respiratory problems and fever peaks. Transesophageal ECHO identified the cardiac vegetations. Burkholderia cepacia was discovered in the culture. Which medication is recommended for Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins
B.Cepacia is resistant to most antibiotics which include:
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymyxin
  • Carboxypenicillins
  • First and second Gen cephalosporins
However, still sensitive to a handful of antibiotics among which the drug of choice is cotrimoxazole and third-generation cephalosporins.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 322.

questions.text: A young girl who complained of spontaneous movements was identified as having Sydenham chorea, which is symptomatic of acute rheumatic fever. Carditis or arthritic complaints are not present. A bad throat culture exists. Which of the following is the strongest indication of a recent streptococcal infection
questions.solution:
Antistreptolysin O (ASLO) titre is a blood test to measure antibodies against streptolysin O, a substance produced by group A streptococcus bacteria. The sensitivity of this test is around 95% which indicates that a negative result means no streptococcal infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 213.

questions.text: The nasal biopsy from a patient with a brain abscess revealed the following image. Name the organism observed and the stain applied.
questions.solution:
The image shows filamentous Gram-stained Nocardia.
They are also acid-fast and can be stained by the Modified Ziehl­ Neelsen technique. Nocardia asteroides is the most frequently found species infecting humans, and most cases occur as an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients.
Because it is acid-fast to some degree, it stains only weakly Gram-positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: An ulcer in the vaginal area was seen in a 24-year-old female patient. The following image was obtained from a cervical smear that had been Giemsa stained. Determine the responsible agent
questions.solution:
Coccobacilli seen in the above giemsa-stained specimen suggest a diagnosis of Granuloma Inguinale. Donovan bodies are seen intracellularly in mononuclear cells.
Granuloma lnguinale:
Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a long-lasting inflammatory condition brought on by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, a tiny, encapsulated coccobacillus closely linked to the Klebsiella genus. The organism is sexually transmitted. Presents with the painless genital ulcer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 404.

questions.text: Which of the following causes a phage-mediated change in C. diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Phage-mediated change in C. diphtheria is due to Transduction. 
In transduction, donor DNA is carried by a phage coat and is transferred into the recipient by the mechanism used for phage infection. 

Conjugation: Transfer of genetic material between bacterial cells by direct cell-to-cell contact or by a
the bridge-like connection between two cells.

Transformation: Genetic alteration of a cell resulting from the direct uptake and incorporation of exogenous genetic material from its surroundings and taken up through the cell membrane.

Transduction: DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another by a virus or the process whereby foreign DNA is introduced into another cell via a viral vector.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text:
A post-renal transplant patient complains of diarrhea, after three months. Stool microscopy showed organisms that were Kinyoun stain positive and measuring 2 to 6 microns.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
During the first three to six months following transplantation, opportunistic infections are particularly prevalent in post-transplant patients.
 
Due to extensive antibiotic use, Clostridium difficile is typically discovered within one month following transplantation.
 
A positive Kinyon stain (Modified acid fast) rule eliminates Balantidium. Size between 2 and 6 micrometers is indicative of Cryptosporidium hominis (previously parvum). Cystoisospora size 23-36 micrometers. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.text:
A patient develops a thick, gray coating on their tonsils and throat, which is followed by fever, chills, and swollen glands the next week.
Microscopic examination of a nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab revealed gram-positive organisms with a special stain. What are the constituents of the stain?
questions.solution:
It is Albert stain and its constituents are Toluidine blue, malachite green, Glacial acetic acid
 
  • The clinical characteristics indicated are suggestive of diphtheria.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria e's metachromatic granules are stained with Albert Stain.
  • Malachite green and toluidine blue O are the two stains that make up the Albert stain.
  • Volutin granules, the acidic portion of the cell, are stained by toluidine blue O, and the cytoplasm is stained by malachite green.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: Which is the cause of bacterial meningitis in a one-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The causative agent of bacterial meningitis in a 1-year child is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus)

In Neonates, acute bacterial meningitis is caused by :-
  • Group B Streptococcus (most common)
  • E. Coli
  • Listeria
In childhood, adults and elderly,the organisms causing acute bacterial meningitis are:- 
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides (meningococcus)
  • H. Influenza B
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 335.

questions.text: At a party, 200 people showed up, and some of them had diarrhea the next day. They consumed potato salad, hamburgers, oysters, and ice cream. 40 ill from 50 who consumed oyster 50 ill from 135 who consumed hamburger 60 ill from 140 who consumed salad 49 ill from 115 who consumed ice cream What is the most likely cause of this?What is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the most likely causative agent.
 
  • It is typically detected in late summer in raw oyster from polluted oyster beds. It has a minor gastroenteritis connection. Sushi and raw seafood also contain it.
  • Infected eggs are the main method of transmission for Salmonella enteritidis. Undercooked egg consumption is a significant risk factor. Between 12 to 72 hours of eating contaminated food, it might induce diarrhea.
  • Acute diarrhea, terminal ileitis, mesenteric lymphadenitis, and pseudo-appendicitis are all symptoms of Yersinia enterocolitica. Pork, milk, water, and tofu contamination are all linked to human yersiniosis.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to diagnose a Clostridium difficile infection?
questions.solution:
PCR for toxin gene detection in stool is very sensitive and specific for diagnosis of clostridium difficile diarrhea. 

Methods of diagnosis of C. difficile include:
Diagnosis is made after detection of one or both toxins by:
Stool cytotoxin assay
  • PCR 
  • ELISA: ELISA that detects toxin A or B in stool
  •  Colonoscopy: Characteristic ulcers, plaques, and pseudomembranes
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 272.

questions.text: Which organism can you identify from the image?
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows endoflagellum which is seen in Leptospira among the given options. 

Treponema, borrelia and leptospira are all spirochetes and they contain the typical endoflagellum (axial filament).

The flagella-like organelles in the periplasmic region enclosed by the outer membrane are known as endoflagella (axial filaments). At each end of the creature, the endoflagella start and wind around it, expanding to and overlapping at the middle.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: A biofilm-forming bacteria show antibiotic resistance by all of the following mechanisms except?
questions.solution:
Biofilm does not lead to the property of adherence.

Biochemically and visually, biofilm masses are significantly different from the free-living individual cells known as planktonic cells. Affected microbial metabolism, extracellular virulence factors produced, and decreased susceptibility to biocides, antimicrobial agents, and host defence molecules and cells are all effects of biofilm growth.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The picture displays colonies of pink bacilli against a blue background with acid-fast staining indicating that the organisms are acid fast.

Corynebacterium and Actinomyces are excluded because they are not acid fast.

Even though nocardia is acid fast, it appears as long, slender thread with branches.
Therefore, based on the aforementioned scenario, the culture is of mycobacterium and shows a large number of bacilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 13.

questions.text: What conditions are diagnosed with urine LAM?
questions.solution:
Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

LAM is a 17.5 kD glycolipid found in the outer cell wall of mycobacteria.  LAM  shows renal clearance, is heat stable and can be easily detected in urine.

As a bacterial product, it theoretically has the ability to distinguish between latent infection and active TB due to the former's larger bacterial content.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th edition, Page no 1008.

questions.text:
The patient exhibits pneumonia-related symptoms. On sheep agar, the gram positive cocci bacteria isolated from the sputum displayed alpha hemolysis.
Which of the following examinations will support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This statement refers to the ability of two types of Gram-positive cocci bacteria to form colonies on sheep agar that give off an alpha hemolysis. The two types of bacteria in this instance are Streptococcus viridians and Streptococcus pneumonia. To distinguish between the two bacteria, a test called optochin sensitivity can be used.

The Streptococcus viridians bacteria are optochin resistant, meaning that they are unaffected by the optochin test, while the Streptococcus pneumonia bacteria will be optochin sensitive, meaning that they react to the optochin test.

By testing the optochin sensitivity of the bacteria, it is possible to differentiate between the two types of Gram-positive alpha hemolytic cocci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 225.

choices.text: Most common mechanism is production of neutralizing substances
Plasmid mediated antibiotic resistance is always transmitted vertically
Complete elimination of the target is the mechanism of resistance to Vancomycin in some the strains of enterococcus
Alteration of target is the mechanism of resistance in some of the Pneumococcal strains

questions.text: With reference to antibiotic resistance, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Plasmid mediated resistance is exclusively transmitted horizontally because the plasmid is not incorporated into the chromosome. This means that the plasmid must be shared between individuals through methods such as conjugation, transformation, or transduction in order to be transmitted from one individual to another.

Since all these are horizontal transmission mechanisms, it is implied that plasmid mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively by horizontal transfer. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: A young male patient with urethral discharge showed up. Pus cells were discovered after a urine analysis, but no organisms. Which approach is ideal for  cultures?
questions.solution:
In this case, if the urine examination of a patient with urethral discharge only shows pus cells but no gram-negative diplococci, then it suggests that the patient may have non-gonococcal urethritis. Non-gonococcal urethritis is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, which is a bacterium that needs to be cultured on McCoy cells, HeLa cells, or Hep-2 cells. Therefore, this lab test can help confirm if a patient has non-gonoccocal urethritis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 683.

questions.text: A person working in a butcher shop had hand pustules that developed into ulcers. Which one of the following would aid in diagnosis the most?
questions.solution:
A visible pustule on the hand of an abattoir worker that has progressed to form an ulcer is a presumptive indication of cutaneous anthrax.

Mac-Fadyean's reaction, a test done by staining the lesion with polychrome methylene blue stain, can confirm the diagnosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria seen in the following gram stained specimen.
questions.solution:
In the given image, Cocci are depicted in pink colour, suggesting they are gram -ve.

Only gram -ve cocci in the options : N. Gonorrhoeae

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae are lanceolate gram positive cocci in pairs.
  • Staphylococcus aureus are gram positive cocci found in grape-like clusters..
  • Haemophilus influenzae are gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.
The given slide shows gram negative diplococci within the polymorphs, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. It is non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is aerobic but may grow anaerobically also. It is oxidase and catalase positive. It shows twitching motility. It is flagella independent form of bacteria translocation over moist surfaces that occurs by the extension and retraction of polar type 4 pili. These pili act as virulence factors by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 230.

questions.text: A patient with benign prostate enlargement was hospitalised for three weeks. He soon suffered what was likely a urinary tract infection related to his catheter. For culture, the catheter tip was submitted, and it was grown on blood agar. The blood agar has the following appearance after 24 hours. What is the UTI's most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The given image of blood culture finding shows Bull's eye swarming pattern exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in swarming on solid media. It can be suppressed by the addition of
•Phenylethyl alcohol
•Chloral hydrate
• Sulfonamides
•Sodium azide
•Boric acid
Increasing concentration of agar to 6%
Proteus species can cause urinary tract infection, and nosocomial infections such as hospital acquired pneumonia, surgical site infections, etc.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 288.

questions.text: Identify the organism seen in the silver impregnation micrograph below.
questions.solution:
The given image is a dark field microscopy image showing a spirochete with Hook-like appearance, suggesting Leptospira
  • Borrelia: Slender spirals measuring 0.2 µm in width and 5-15 µm in length
  • Treponema: Loose/Irregular Spirals
  • Ehrlichia:Tightly coiled, thin flexible spirochetes 5-15 µm long with very fine spirals 0.1-0.2 µm wide.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 378.

questions.text: Identify the obligate intracellular pathogen from the following.
questions.solution:
The answer is Coxiella burnetti

Coxiella Burnetti
1. Coxiella burnetii - obligately intracellular. 
2. Gram-negative coccobacillus
3. Extremely resilient to environmental stresses
4. Causes Q fever
5. DOC - Doxyxyline

Other examples include Chlamydia spp., Anaplasma spp., Ehrlichia spp., Rickettsia spp., Orientia spp.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 418.

questions.text: Pick the infection that causes a noncentrally distributed rash.
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

Initial Secondary Syphilis lesions are discrete light red or pink, nonpruritic macules that are spread throughout the trunk and proximal extremities; these macules develop into papular lesions that are widely dispersed and commonly affect the palms and soles.

Non-centrally distributed rash AKA centrifugal rash (Rashes of the Palms and Soles)


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 380.

choices.text: A catalase-positive gram positive coccus that grows in clusters

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy who had a very bad sore throat and a greyish pseudomembrane covering his tonsils and pharynx presented. What is most likely the organism causing this infection?
questions.solution:
Pseudomembrane over tonsil and pharynx is caused by Gram +ve bacilli out of the following, as the two main infectious causes of pseudomembrane over tonsil are membranous tonsillitis, caused by Gram positive catalase negative cocci, and diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria, which are Gram+ bacilli. The membrane of diphtheria may spread beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 240.

questions.text: The following is an image of a 23 year old female. Her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and she also has stiff neck. A lumbar puncture showed 4200 cells per microlitre, a protein level of 198, and a glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about the organism responsible for this ailment is true?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram negative diplococci.
Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse - Friderichsen syndrome.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: A 26 years old male presented with fever and headache for 3 days. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg and examination revealed the following rash on the legs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The case provided is of pyogenic meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis (Meningococcus). Petechial or purpuric non-blanching rashes are commonly seen in patients with meningitis by this organism. It is a capsulated Gram negative diplococci and ferments glucose and maltose.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: Gram-stain most likely reveals the following organism:
questions.solution:
Purple paired cocci can be seen in this figure, which are apparantly Lanceolate. Hence, this is a Gram-positive cocci, likely to be Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 224.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intracellular parasite that is obligate?
questions.solution:
Ehrlichia is a genus of rickettsiales. Ehrlichia chaffeensis are small, obligately intracellular, endosomal bacteria. Persistent infection in reservoir white-tailed deer is transmitted by lone star ticks. Flu-like illness can progress to severe multisystem disease with toxic shock-like syndrome, meningitis, or ARDS.

other options:-

(1) Tropheryma whippelii - This bacterium causes Whipple’s disease and is an intracellular pathogen, but it’s not strictly obligate like Ehrlichia chaffeensis.

(2) Bartonella henselae - This is an intracellular bacterium that causes cat scratch disease but can also exist in the extracellular environment.

(4) Mycobacteria - While Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an intracellular pathogen, it is facultative, meaning it can survive both inside and outside of host cells under certain conditions.

So, Ehrlichia chaffeensis is the most appropriate choice as an obligate intracellular parasite.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 416.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of acute bacterial meningitis?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone- a third generation cephalosporin is the empirical drug of choice for treatment of acute bacterial meningitis before culture reports are awaited. 

Once culture reports are available, organism sensitive antibiotic will be used in the treatment. For eg- In case of listeria meningitis, the drug of choice becomes ampicillin. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 233.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shows a "bull-neck" in extreme cases?
questions.solution:
Bull neck is seen in diphtheria which is a Cornybacterium diphtheriae infection. Incubation of the disease is typically 2-6 days and mostly affects children. Symptoms include a greyish-white membrane that forms over the tonsils, which can spread to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. This membrane is tenacious and can cause bleeding when removed. Cervical lymph nodes, especially jugulodigastric, can become enlarged and tender, giving the affected person a "Bulldog appearance". In addition, the patient will be ill and experience a low grade fever.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 241.

questions.text: Which one of the following does not cause lung infections?
questions.solution:
Rapidly growing atypical Mycobacteria causing lung infections are M. chelonie, M. fortuitum and M. abscessus. Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma seen in fish tank handlers. It involves skin in a sporotrichoid pattern. Tap water is believed to be its reservoir.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 367.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman admits to having a sore throat for three days as well as a fever and headache. She was discovered to be highly dehydrated, had a blood pressure reading of 90/50 mm Hg, and had little red spots on the distal part of the cuff. What is the most likely etiological factor that is generating these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Neisseria meningitidis.

It is characterized by fever, nausea, nuchal rigidity with signs of endotoxemia such as petechiae, purpura, ecchymosis.

Neisseria meningitis is a gram negative cocci which is a normal flora of nasopharynx. However, the most common route of spread to CNS is via hematogenous route. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: A boy came in with a three- day history of vomiting, headaches, and fever as well as one day of dizziness. Exam results for neck stiffness were positive. Additionally, he experienced one episode of generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTC), after which he passed out. CECT was discovered to be typical. Upon investigation of the CSF, it is found to include 300 cells/mm3 of cells (polymorphs: 50–70%), 70 mg/dL of protein, and 50 mg/dL of sugar (blood: 95 mg/dL). Which of the below- listed diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
The classic CSF Abnormalities in bacterial meningitis are: Elevated Opening pressure (>180 m H,0 in 90%) Polymorphonuclear leukocytosis (> 100 cells/mL in 90%) Decreased Glucose concentration (<2.2 mmol/L or <40 mg/dL and or CSF/serum glucose ratio <0.4in 60%) Elevated protein concentration (>45 mg/dL)



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 231.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Cefotetan

B. Cepacia are intrinsically resistant to:
Aminoglycosides
Polymyxin
Carboxypenicillins
First and second Gen cephalosporins
Cefotetan being a second-gen cephalosporin is not effective against B. cepacia.
Burkholderia cepacia complex is an opportunistic environmental pathogen. It causes fatal respiratory distress and septicemia in CF patients. This is termed as 'Cepacia syndrome'.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 322.

questions.text: What is diagnosed using a urea breath test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: H.pylori

The urea breath test is a non-invasive test used for the detection of H.pylori. Here, the patient drinks a carbon-labelled urea solution which can be detected in the breath as the CO2 expired. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 408.

questions.text: What is the name of the anaerobe that produces many abscesses, discharges sinuses, and shows sulphur granules in pus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Actinomycetes

Actinomyces is a gram-positive bacteria that causes actinomycosis which is characterised by multiple discharging sinuses and production of the characteristic sulphur granules.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 398.

questions.text: What organism is responsible for acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: E.coli

E.coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis. The second most common cause is Pseudomonas aeruginosa followed by Klebsiella.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 283.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning by releasing histamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: P. aeruginosa Scombroid fish poisoning, or histamine fish poisoning, is a syndrome resembling an allergic reaction that occurs after eating fish contaminated with high levels of histamine. It is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria among which the most common is P. Aeruginosa.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 321.

choices.text: Most common source of infection is cross-infection from infected people
About 30% of general population is healthy nasal carries

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding staphylococcus aureus is:
questions.solution:
The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps and diarrhea. It is caused by enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus aureus. It is preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the exotoxins are heat liable.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: A young toddler is experiencing sepsis. Bacteria that were identified demonstrated beta hemolysis on blood agar, bacitracin resistance, and a positive CAMP test. The most likely agent generating an infection is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: S. agalactia

S. agalacticus causes beta hemolysis on blood agar, has bacitracin resistance and produces a positive camp test.
Other options – S. pyogenes shows bacitracin sensitivity.
Enterococcus shows gamma hemolysis and S. Pneumonia shows alpha hemolysis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 219.

choices.text: Can survive in ice cold water for 2-4 weeks
Enterotoxin can have direct effects on other tissues besides intestinal epithelial cells

questions.text: The incorrect statement about EI-Tor Vibrio is:
questions.solution:
El tor vibrio’s enterotoxin has direct effects on intestinal epithelial cells only. They do not act on other epithelial cells.All other statements are correct.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 313.

questions.text: Chlamydia can be isolated from tissue samples using
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Yolk sac inoculation

Chlamydia can grow in the yolk sac of 6-8 day old chick embryos. The group-specific antigen and inclusion bodies can be well demonstrated in the yolk sac.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 426.

choices.text: PBP's are localized on the outer face of cell wall
PBP's are essential for cell wall synthesis
Alteration in PBP's is the primary bases of resistance in MRSA

questions.text: The following descriptions of Penicillin-binding proteins (PBP) are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: PBP's are localized on the outer face of cell wall .
Penicillin-binding Proteins (PBP) are located in the cell membrane. They confer resistance to the organism and are regulated by the mec A gene.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 767.

choices.text: Transmitted when adult mites feed on hosts

questions.text: The following facts about scrub typhus are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Transmitted when adult mites feed on hosts. Humans are infected when they are bitten by mite larvae which are also known as chiggers. For this reason, it is also known as chigger-borne typhus. All other statements are true and Doxycycline is the DOC. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text: Which disease is characterized by the presence of positive acid Schiff macrophages?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:Whipples disease
Whipple disease is characterized by the accumulation of myriad macrophages parasitized by Tropheryma whipplei (TW) bacilli denoted by periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positivity. These PAS+ macrophages are typically found in the duodenum associated with lymphangiectasia.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles Of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 1223.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is frequently linked to recurrent meningitis brought on by CSF leaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Pneumococci

Pneumococci is the most common cause of recurrent meningitis due to CSF leaks. It is usually secondary to pneumonia, conjunctivitis and otitis media.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 227.

choices.text: Ability to transfer resistance genes from adjacent commensal flora
Frequent and injudicious use of topical antibiotics

questions.text: A person who has worn contact lenses for a long time says that his left eye is irritated. After investigations, keratitis was determined to be the cause, and samples of the corneal tissue showed the proliferation of pseudomonas aeruginosa. The bacteria is found to be multi-drug resistant. Which of the following best describes how these isolated pseudomonas aeruginosa stains developed antibiotic resistance
questions.solution:
The most important mechanism by which pseudomonas causes infection and develops resistance is by its ability to produce a biofilm. It also has other virulence factors such as slime layer, presence of pili and production of exotoxin A.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 321.

questions.text: The organism that causes ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is usually:
questions.solution:
Acinetobacter baumannii is a common cause of nosocomial pneumonia, especially in people who require extended periods of mechanical ventilation.

Symptoms of hospital-acquired or ventilator-associated pneumonia caused by this bacteria are consistent with other nosocomial pathogens, characterized by fever and increased production of mucus. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: Pick the causative organism where a 12 years old boy gets vomiting within 3 hours of food consumption at a party.
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal food poisoning is a type of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcal enterotoxin, which is a heat and acid stable superantigen. It is a preformed toxin, meaning that its effects are felt within a short period of time (1-6 hours). Toxin is vagomimetic hence causes vomiting. There are 12 known serotypes of Staphylococcal enterotoxin, which are A-E, G-I, R-T and V, with serotype A being the most common cause of food poisoning. Contaminated food items such as dairy, bakery items, custards, salads, and processed meats are at high risk for contamination. Food handlers are the most common source of this contamination.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: Pick the suggestive method to use on a brother of a 5 years old boy who had a sore throat for the last two days. He has a greyish-white pseudomembrane around his tonsils and diphtheria is suspected. The brother got the last booster 22 months back.
questions.solution:
All contacts of a diphtheria patient irrespective of whether they received their primary immunization or booster dose, Prophylaxis with oral erythromycin is required. Those whose primary course or booster dose was received more than two years ago should only receive a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid. Non-immunized close contacts should receive prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin and also receive 1000-2000 units of diphtheria antitoxin as well as active immunization against diphtheria. All contacts should be placed under medical surveillance and should be examined daily for at least a week after being exposed, and the bacteriological surveillance of those close contacts should be continued for several weeks doing weekly swabbing.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: Pick the reason for donovanosis.
questions.solution:
Donovanosis (also known as Granuloma Inguinale) is a genital ulcer disease, caused by the bacteria known as Klebsiella (Calymmatobacterium) granulomatis. It is a rare but serious infection that is mainly spread through sexual contact. It is believed to be more common in tropical and subtropical regions. Those infected may present with painless, hypertrophic ulcers which have raised margins. A definitive diagnosis of donovanosis can be made of the presence of a “Donovan Body” in a Giemsa stain. This is a rounded coccobacilli, resembling a “safety-pin” appearance within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells. The infection is treated with antibiotics, such as tetracycline or doxycycline. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent further spread of the infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 404.

questions.text: Select the one which doesn't cause Urethritis in males.
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi is a gram-negative bacterium that causes a sexually transmitted infection known as soft chancre or chancroid. The infection is characterized by multiple, painful, non-indurated (not hard) irregular ulcers on the genital area. It is usually accompanied with painful regional lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes, usually on one side). The ulcers can be quite painful and can lead to secondary infections if left untreated.
Treatment involves antibiotics, and those individuals who have been infected with this bacteria should be tested for other STIs. It is a common cause of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in females and has been associated with post-surgical infections in the urethra. However, it does not cause urethritis in males. This is because the male urethra is much longer than the female, making it difficult for Haemophilus ducreyi to traverse and cause infections. In addition, the acidic environment of the male urethra helps to inhibit bacterial growth. Therefore, Haemophilus ducreyi does not typically cause urethritis in males

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 337.

choices.text: No vaccine needed as exposure has already occurred

questions.text: Select the suggestive measure to be given to a 12 years old close friend who is in fear of contracting d/s from her friend who has been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis.
questions.solution:
Meningococcal vaccine protects against four antigens related to four specific serotypes, A, C, Y, and W135. While vaccines for serotype B are still being evaluated, two types of vaccines are in use: capsular polysaccaride vaccines and conjugate vaccines. Only polysaccaride vaccines are licensed for use in our country, which come in bivalent (A+C) and tetravalent (A+C+Y+W135) forms. Each dose of the vaccine contains 50 Mg of the antigen and is given as a 0.5 ml injection subcutaneously in the deltoid region to those over two years old. The duration of immunity following the vaccine is 1-3 years. Singled dose of polysaccharide meningococcal vaccine would be prescribed in this case.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 233.

questions.text: Pick the one which helps in bacterial adhesion.
questions.solution:
Fimbriae are thin projections on the surface of bacterial cells that are involved in bacterial adhesion. They are important in the infectious process, allowing bacteria to attach to surfaces and spread to new locations. Fimbriae are made of proteins and act like short, thin, flexible fingers that extend outward from the cell membrane. These fingers are coated in carbohydrates, lipids, and other molecules that recognize and bind to a specific receptor on the surface of the target cell, allowing the bacteria to attach. Once attached, the bacteria will grow and reproduce.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 20.

questions.text: Pick the one which produces superantigens.
questions.solution:
Superantigens are antigens that can directly activate T cells without being processed by APCs, unlike other antigens which require processing. Superantigens bind to the variable region of the T-cell receptor and activate many T cells at once, causing a massive release of cytokines. This polyclonal B cell activation can lead to increased secretion of non-specific antibodies (hypergammaglobulinemia). Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE) is a superantigen responsible for streptococcal infections like scarlet fever, necrotising fascitis and toxic shock syndrome. It is classified into three antigenic types: SPE A, B, and C, where SPE A and C are superantigens. The Dick test is used to detect exposure to SPE and determine susceptibility to scarlet fever.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 93.

questions.text: A child develops septic shock following meningitis. On examination the child has a petechiae rash as shown in the figure. Which of the following is a gram negative diplococcus that can be the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Neisseria meningitidis is a type of bacteria that is responsible for many cases of meningitis and other serious infections. The bacteria is a capsulated, intracellular gram-negative diplococci, meaning that under a microscope it appears as two lenses in a half-moon shape and it is classified into thirteen different serogroups based on the capsular polysaccharide that coats the organism.
Humans are the only natural host for infection by this bacteria. Transmission is through inhalation of droplets.
Disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be diagnosed through Gram staining, culturing on selective media, serological testing, and molecular testing such as multiplex PCR.
Treatment of disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be done with antibiotics such as ceftriaxone and cefotaxime or penicillin, chemoprophylaxis with rifampicin and ciprotioxacin, and vaccine prophylaxis such as a polysaccharide vaccines. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli are both gram-negative bacilli and Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram-positive diplococci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: Select the medium for E.Coli 0157:H7.
questions.solution:
Sorbitol MacConkey agar is a selective and differential agar used to identify bacteria that can ferment the sugar sorbitol. It is used specifically to identify and differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli strains. It is an exclusive medium as it only allows the growth of E. coli O157:H7 colonies and will not support the growth of other coliform bacteria. It is a differentiating medium too, as the colonies of E. coli O157:H7 produce a yellow-green color with a metallic sheen on the agar, while other coliforms produce pink to red colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: The image shows the gram stain of Urethral discharge in a man. Which of the following is not a property of the organism?
questions.solution:
Gram-negative diplococci, which are indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, are visible in the polymorphs in the provided gram stain.
Neisseria is not always found inside cells; it can also exist extracellularly. Hence, it is facultative intracellular and not obligate intracellular.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 231.

questions.text: Most common inhalational anthrax's pulmonary manifestation -
questions.solution:
Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax.

Bacillus anthracis is the organism causing anthrax. It is a spore-producing, gram-positive rod found in sheep, cattle, horses, and goats. 

Inhalational anthrax also known as wool sorter's disease is acquired by inhalational of dust containing spores of the bacilli. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 250.

questions.text: The following bacteria toxin act by -
questions.solution:
The organism in the provided image is Corynebacterium diphtheriae because of the gram-positive rods' club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement.
 
The diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation of elongation factor 2- eF2, thus inhibiting polypeptide chain and protein synthesis by inactivating the elongation factor 2 (EF-2).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 240.

questions.text: The maximum usefulness of polysaccharide vaccine 23 for streptococcal pneumonia infection is observed in which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell disease are most likely to benefit from this vaccination.
The spleen must identify capsulated organisms like  Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, sickled cells in sickle cell anemia obstruct the spleen's blood arteries, which causes splenic infraction resulting in functional asplenia(no spleen).
As a result of this asplenia, pneumococcal infection risk is enhanced. Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV-23) is therefore administered to these patients as a preventive step to lower this risk.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 228.

questions.text: Out of the following options , which of the following is an exception for the giemsa stain
questions.solution:
Giemsa staining of a thin peripheral smear cannot be used to diagnose Coxiella burnettii; instead, serology, which demonstrates an increase in the titer of particular antibodies to C. burnettii, is used to make this diagnosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 690.

choices.text: A and R is true and is the correct explanation
A and R is true but not correct explanation
A is false and R is true
A is true and R is false

questions.text:
Assertion: A patient is admitted in a hospital for community acquired pneumonia. As a treatment, a combination therapy of Beta lactams and azithromycin is given.
Reason: This combination covers gram positive organisms and anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Beta lactams are used to treat gram-positive bacteria like pneumococcus in the case of a hospitalised patient with community-acquired pneumonia, whereas macrolides are used to treat atypical bacteria like mycoplasma, chlamydia, and legionella.

Macrolides do not cover anaerobic organisms. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 767.

questions.text: On the bacitracin sensitivity disc test, identify the organism:
questions.solution:
The results of the bacitracin sensitivity disk test are indicative of Streptococcus pyogenes, which generate large clear zones of B-hemolysis (approx 1 cm in diameter) surrounding colonies larger than 0.5 mm. S. pyogenes is also PYR-positive (hydrolytion of I-pyrrolidonyl-B-naphthylamide) and usually sensitive to bacitracin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 217.

choices.text: It differentiates lactose fermenting from non lactose fermenting
Promotes growth of staphylococcus aureus and candida

questions.text: CLED media is a preferred media in a patient with UTI for the following reason-
questions.solution:
MacConkey and CLED agar come under differential media. Lactose and non-lactose ferments can be distinguished using either agar medium. Both media prevent proteus from swarming. In both, pseudomonas colonies appear greenish. The crucial difference between MacConkey agar and CLEO agar is: CLED (Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte Deficient) promotes the growth of GPC species like Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, and candida species.

Reference: Jawetz, Melnick and Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 237.

questions.text: Which organism is represented by the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells in the illustration below?
questions.solution:
Entero Pathogenic E. coli (EPEC) is an organism that demonstrates effacement and attachment of the intestinal cells, as seen in the image. The precise cause of diarrhea associated with EPEC is yet to be determined. These pathogens are not invasive and do not generate enterotoxins. EPEC adherence factor (EAF), a protein coded by a plasmid, has been linked to attachment in the case of infantile enteritis. The other mechanism by which EPEC attaches to the enterocyte membrane is through a chromosomally regulated locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE). This pathogenicity island, which houses a gene coding for the intimin protein, causes disruption of the intestinal brush borders and microvilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: Lymphogranuloma venereum's (LGV) incubation period is:
questions.solution:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LG), which is the time from when the infection is contracted until the initial symptoms appear, is typically estimated to be between 10-30 days though it can range anywhere from 3-6 weeks. This longer window of time needs to be taken into consideration when diagnosing and treating an LG infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 428.

questions.text: The figure depicts Pathogenesis of which of the following
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulism. Clostridium botulism- gram-positive organism producing sub terminal, oval and bulging spores. The botulinum strains are categorized into 8 different types according to their toxin production- Types: A. B, Cl C2, D, E, F and G Acetylcholine (Ach) generation or release at the NM junction and synapses is blocked by proteolysis of the SNARE proteins by botulism toxin. The poison does not impact the central nervous system or cross through the blood-brain barrier. The SNARE proteins include syntaxin, SNAP 25, and synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 265.

questions.text: The vector shown in the figure transmits which of the following?
questions.solution:
Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted by the Trombiculid mite is shown in the picture, is an obligate intracellular bacteria. In humans, it results in scrub typhus disease.

Hard ticks have a chitinous shield, or scutum, covering their dorsal surface. They have an anterior end with a head or capitulum that can be seen from above.

Hard ticks can spread illnesses such hemorrhagic fever, tick typhus, and viral encephalitis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

choices.text: Group of bacilli arranged in chain form
bacteria adherent to lining vaginal epithelial cells

questions.text: What will the microscopic finding suggestive of in a 26 year old pt. c/o foul smelling greyish white discharge and diagnosed to be Gardnerella Vaginalis?
questions.solution:
Epithelial cells with bacteria attached to them, known as clue cells, are the microscopic discovery
These vaginal epithelial cells have several associated bacteria that result in a border that is poorly defined and stippled.
The presence of clue cells in one of the four conditions listed in Amsel's criterion (>20% of vaginal epithelial cells with adhering bacterial clusters, as seen by saline microscopy).

Amsel Criteria: Diagnostic Criteria for Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Abnormal gray discharge
  •  Vaginal pH > 4 .5
  • Positive amine/whiff test (release of fishy, amine-like odor when vaginal fluid is alkalinized with KOH)
  •  20% of the epithelial cells are clue cells.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text:
A child returned from the beach with intractable diarrhoea. The faeces are watery and have a rice-like odour.
Which cell adhesion molecule is impacted by the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Cholera is the cause of the child's illness. 

A cleavage product from the ZOT protein is used by V. cholera to alter tight junctions. 

CT toxin- made up of A and B subunits. B binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors in intestinal mucosal cells. A causes production of Aden ye cyclase, this increases cAMP which activates CFTR causing increased secretion of chloride ions. 
Zot toxin- zona occludens toxin, alters the tight junctions. Induces a transitory reduction in transepithelial electrical resistance and an increase in transepithelial flux, increasing the permeability of TJs.
ACE toxin - integral membrane protein that affects ion transport, builds up in ligated rabbit ileal loops, and produces moderate diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 282.

questions.text:
The image below shows a CSF gram stain from a child who was admitted with meningitis-like symptoms.
Which of the following best describes the bacteria's characteristics?
questions.solution:
Optochin test: S. pneumoniae can be distinguished from streptococci by their 1/500,000 sensitivity to optochin (ethyl hydrocupreip).The catalase test is used to identify the catalase enzyme that is produced by different Mycobacteria.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: Identify the location of lipid A in the provided gram-negative bacterial cell wall.
questions.solution:
Gram negative bacteria has certain special structures in their cell wall when compared to gram positive bacteria. They are : Outer membrane , Periplasmic space and Endotoxin/LPS.
Lipid A is a part of the structure of endotoxin, embedded in outer membrane and has the actual endotoxic activity.
https://images.app.goo.gl/R5Ae6ij5uemqvqp4A Image for explanation.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the attachment effacement lesion depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
E.coli is a gram negative bacteria which is the most common facultative anaerobe present in human GIT.

EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli) is an example of diarrheogenic E. coli. It is the most common cause of infantile bacterial diarrhea. It consists of enterocyte effacement plasmid which causes attachment - effacement effect leading to secretory diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms results in a painful glans ulcer?
A. Chlamydia trachomatis
B. Hemophilus dureyi
C. Herpes simplex
D. Neisseria gonorrhea
questions.solution:
Among the given options, painful ulcer on glans penis are seen in genital herpes caused by HSV2>HSV1 and hemophilus ducreyi which causes chancroid.

However, there is painless lymphadenopathy in genital herpes whereas painful lymphadenopathy is seen in chancroid cause by H.ducreyi.

Memorizing Trick: -
Organisms starting with H cause painful genital ulcer 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 337.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is correct about chancroid?
A. School of fish appearance
B. Bleeds on touch
C. Painful
D. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Groove sign of Greenblatt is not seen in chancroid, it is seen in LGV.

Chancroids are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. IP is 1-14 days. Their features include:

i. School of fish/ rail road track appearance on smear examination.
ii. Bleeds on touch (soft sore)
iii. Painful, non-ulcerative ulcer

Drug of choice is azithromycin/ceftriaxone

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 337.

questions.text: A young man with painful sores as seen in the picture arrives at the STD clinic. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The microscopic finding of herpes genitalis is multinucleated giant cells.

Pund cells ae seen in Granuloma inguinale.

Henderson Peterson bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Halberstaedler prowazek bodies  seen in Trachoma

Herpes genitalis is caused by HSV 2 > 1.

Features:
i. Multiple painful vesicles or ulcers with painless lymphadenopathy. 
ii. Non-suppurative
iii. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with margination and moulding. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 475.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct options.
A. ETEC 1. Produce a heat stable toxin and cause activation of guanylyl cyclase
B. EIEC 2. Invades intestinal mucosal cells
C. EHEC 3. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cell
D. EPEC 4. Adhere to the mucosal surface and cause effacement of microvilli
questions.solution:
A. ETEC -> 1. Produce a heat stable toxin and cause activation of guanylyl cyclase
B. EIEC ->  2. Invades intestinal mucosal cells
C. EHEC -> 3. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells
D. EPEC -> 4. Adhere to the mucosal surface and cause effacement of microvilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: A disruption of which of the following causes diarrhea in Vibrio cholera?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea in V. Cholera is due to disruption of zonula occludens.

V. Cholera produces Zona occludens toxins ( apart from usual cholera toxin ), which disrupts the tight junctions between the enterocytes and increases the permeability, this causes leakage of fluid, resulting in diarrhoea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 282.

questions.text: Which pneumonia is caused by a catalase and oxidase positive, gram negative, pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar?
questions.solution:
H.influenza is  gram negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which causes pneumonia in younger age group. 

H. Influenzae:

i. Gram negative pleomorphic bacillus
ii. Grows on chocolate agar
iii. Is catalase and oxidase positive
iv. Causes pneumonia, meningitis, croup, suppurative lesions, bronchitis
v. Fildes' agar is best for primary isolation of Haemophilus species.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 333.

questions.text: A patient in his 30s shows in with urethral discharge. Below is a photo of a gram stain. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Neisseria gonorrhoea is the probable cause of urethral discharge with the given histology as intracytoplasmic diplococci could be seen.

N. Gonorrhea features- 

i. Gram-negative aerobic,
ii. non-sporulating, non-motile
iii. oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci).
iv. Cultured in Stuart's transport medium, chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar, Thayer-Martin medium.
v. Disease acquired by sexual contact.

Drug of choice for treatment of gonococcal urethritis is combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 234.

choices.text: 50% of cases resolve spontaneously after bacillus exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than adults
Indeterminate leprosy resolves more spontaneously than tuberculoid leprosy
Most clinical cases do not resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement about leprosy?
questions.solution:
Leprosy is a chronic infectious granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and nerves. Corrected options—

Option A : 95% of cases resolve spontaneously 

Option B : Children recover better from leprosy than adults. 

Option C : Indeterminate leprosy resolve better than tuberculoid 

Option D : Leprosy doesn’t heal by itself in multibacillary type. Even though option B is correct, Option C is more acurate and factual.

Audio explanation of the above.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 373.

questions.text: Late at night, a group of friends got together for a celebration and had pastries from a bakery. Early that morning, everyone started vomiting. Choose the organism that is most likely to be the cause.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Staph aureus

Food poisoning caused by consuming bakery products and the one that is manifested in around 6-9 hours is mostly indicative of staphylococcus aureus-mediated food poisoning. It is manifested as vomiting and diarrhoea with the absence of fever.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: An X-ray of a known AIDS individual with a productive cough and fever revealed consolidation in the right intralobar area, along with CD 4 counts of 55 per microliter. What is the most commonly cited reason for this?
questions.solution:
In an individual with AIDS, especially with a CD4 count of 55 per microliter and symptoms like a productive cough and fever, the most commonly cited reason for pneumonia in this context is 4. Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS and is characterized by specific radiographic findings such as consolidation or ground-glass opacities.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 226.

questions.text: 70% of the patient's body had burned. A sample that was taken from the burn site was tested for the presence of an obligate aerobe, which is thought to be the likely culprit. What exactly is the microbe?
questions.solution:
In burn patient care settings, invasive burn wound sepsis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a substantial concern.
Typically a low invasiveness and pathogenicity organism, PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA (Bacillus pyocyaneus) is usually observed as a local dweller of burns, surgical sites, and the genitourinary tract. Yet, this gram-negative, motile rod can act as a potentially fatal infection when the right host conditions are present.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 320.

questions.text: A little boy complained of abdominal ache and bloody stools. Identify the culture medium for the causal organism in the provided image.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests the diagnosis if Shigellosis which can be confirmed by using Selenite F broth for culture.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 294.

questions.text: A newborn who is 14 days old and with fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, and rapid breathing comes to the OPD. An X-ray of his chest revealed infiltrates on both sides. Which infection is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given history is suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum (B/L Conjunctivitis) progressing to pneumonia. (Rapid breathing and infiltrates on chest X-Ray)

Neonatal Conjunctivitis is also known as ophthalmia neonatorum.
It can arise due to various causes (bacterial conjunctivitis, viral etc). Most common infectious cause is Chlamydia trachomatis infection. It usually occurs with 5 - 14 days of birth. Neonatal conjunctivitis + pneumonia with bilateral infiltrates strongly suggests Chlamydia trachomatis infection. 

Other options

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae - Rare in neonates, occurs in older children & adolescents. Hence, unlikely.
  • Haemophilus influenzae - Uncommon in newborns; usually causes epiglottitis, otitis media, or meningitis
  • Streptococcus - Can cause neonatal pneumonia but does not cause conjunctivitis

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 427.

questions.text: A newborn who is 14 weeks old and with fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, and rapid breathing comes to the OPD. An X-ray of his chest revealed infiltrates on both sides. Which infection is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Chlamydia

Chlamydia trachomatis is indicated in neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis that is caused within 4 weeks of birth. It later progresses to cause pnuemonia.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 427.

questions.text: According to a gene expert, resistance is caused by mutation in:
questions.solution:
Gene Xpert tells resistance due to mutation in Rpo B gene. 

Whereas Line probe assay detects INH-Kat G as well as rPOB - rifampicin resistance.

So, based on common antibiotic resistances:

• RpoB is associated with rifampin resistance.

• GyrA is associated with fluoroquinolone resistance.

• InhA is associated with isoniazid resistance.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: Symptoms of a fever, chest pain, and dry cough in an older male were present. Gram negative organism was discovered when his sputum was cultivated on charcoal yeast medium. Which organism is more likely?
questions.solution:
Presence of fever with respiratory symptoms and growth on BCYE( Buffered charcoal yeast extract) media confirms the diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia. Culture of the organism is the single most definitive diagnostic test for Legionella. Growth of Legionella pneumophila on buffered charcoal-yeast extract (BCYE) medium is dependent on l-cysteine, which is added in excess over what is required for nutrition.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 408.

choices.text: Most common mechanism is production of neutralizing substances
Alternation of target binding site leads to pneumococcal resistance
Complete removal of target is the mechanism of resistance to vancomycin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true in relation to antibiotic resistance?
questions.solution:
Plasmid mediated resistance is a type of horizontal transmission, not the vertical.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 60.

choices.text: B. fragilis is the most frequent anaerobe isolated from clinical samples
B. fragilis is not uniformly sensitive to metronidazole
The lipopolysaccharide formed by B. fragilis is structurally and functionally different from the conventional endotoxin
Shock and DIC are common in Bacteroides bacteremia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with reference to Bacteroides fragilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:Shock and DIC are common in Bacteroides bacteremia

Bacteroides fragilis group comprises the most important anaerobic pathogens in human infections. These pathogens are often associated with polymicrobial infections such as intra-abdominal, obstetric-gynecologic, diabetic foot, and skin and skin structure infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 275.

questions.text: A young male presents to OPD with urethral discharge. On urine examination, pus cells were found but no organisms. Which of the following media would be the best culture for the organism?
questions.solution:
Urine examination in a patient of urethral discharge demonstrating only pus cells but no gram-negative diplococcic suggest "non-gonococcal urethritis". The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis. Chlamydia trachomatis is cultured on McCoy cells, HeLa cells or Hep-2 cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 426.

questions.text: Having pustular lesions on the lower legs, a 5-year-old from a remote location presented to the OPD. Beta Hemolytic colonies (clear and complete hemolysis) of Gram-positive cocci were visible on the blood agar in the lesion's culture. Which of the following responses could help tentatively confirm the diagnosis of group A streptococcal pyoderma?
questions.solution:
The correct option is option (2) - Bacitracin sensitivity.

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is one of the common causative agents of pyoderma, an acute superficial skin infection that causes pustules and vesicles on the skin. Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic feature of GAS, and it can be used to differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. GAS is susceptible to bacitracin, while other beta-hemolytic streptococci, such as Group B streptococci, are resistant to bacitracin.

Optochin sensitivity is a test that helps to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and other alpha-hemolytic streptococci, including viridans streptococci.

Catalase positivity is a characteristic feature of staphylococci, a group of Gram-positive cocci that are catalase positive, while streptococci are catalase-negative.

Bile solubility is a test that helps to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. S. pneumoniae is bile-soluble, while other alpha-hemolytic streptococci are bile-insoluble.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 211.

questions.text: An ICU patient has been connected to a central venous line for the past week. He is on Amikacin and Ceftazidime. After taking antibiotics for 7 days, he experiences a fever spike and learns that gram-positive, chain-forming, catalase-negative cocci are present in his blood culture. After that, Vancomycin was started, but the culture continued to show the same infection. who are the infectious organisms?
questions.solution:
The common source of nosocomial infection is Enterococcus faecalis, a gram-positive chain-forming, catalase-negative cocci. Unlike other streptococci, enterococci species exhibit penicillin resistance, and they are inherently resistant to all cephalosporins. A high level of resistance to aminoglycosides is also present in enterococci. Vancomycin resistance is a widespread problem.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 220.

questions.text: Which of the following gram-negative bacteria's endotoxin does not contribute to the pathogenesis of the natural disease?
questions.solution:
Endotoxin of vibrio cholerae does not play any part in the pathogenesis of a natural disease (cholera).

Endotoxin of vibrio cholerae plays no role in pathogenesis of cholera but is responsible for immunity induced by killed vaccines.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 314.

choices.text: B. fragilis is the most frequent anaerobe isolated from clinical samples
B. fragilis is not uniformly sensitive to Metronidazole
Lipopolysaccharide formed by B. fragilis is structurally and functionally different from the conventional Endotoxin
Shock and DIC are common in Bacteroides bacteremia

questions.text: With reference to Bacteroides fragilis, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
With reference to bacteroides fragilis all of the following statements are true except
d) shock and DIC are common in bacteroides bacteremia

Endotoxins produced by B. fragilis have lower biological potency than endotoxins produced by aerobic gramme negative bacteria. The clinical symptoms of sepsis are less typically seen in infections caused by Bacteroides as a result of this relative biologic inactivity.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: High fever, discomfort, intestinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting, diarrhoea, and hypotension are the symptoms that the farmer exhibits. Which stain is going to aid in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watson's stain will help in it's diagnosis

The clinical features are suggestive of bubonic plague. It is caused by yersinia pestis.
Yersinia pestis is best demonstrated by polychromatic stains like wayson's stain and wright-giemsa stain.
Bubonic plague is the most common variety of the disease. It is named after the buboes meaning swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite. Other clinical features include sudden onset of fever and chills, headache and fatigue.

On staining with Giemsa stain or methylene blue (Wayson's stain), the bacteria has bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear. This is the characteristic "Safety pin appearance" seen in yersinia pestis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 325.

questions.text: An abattoir worker presented with a malignant pustule on his hand that progressed to form an ulcer. The smear was taken from the ulcer and sent to a laboratory for investigation. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is cutaneous anthrax.

Malignant pustule is present in cutaneous anthrax and animals are infected by ingestion of spores present in soil.

Other options:- 
  • Carbuncle will have multiple pustules but is not malignant in nature
  • Melanoma and rodent ulcer don't have pustule 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 250.

questions.text: Faget sign is not a seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome

Faget sign also called sphygmothermic dissociation—is the unusual pairing of fever with bradycardia. It is seen in conditions like :
  • Yellow fever
  • Typhoid fever
  • Dengue fever
  • Tularemia
  • Brucellosis
  • Colorado tick fever
  • Legionella pneumonia
Online reference: Ostergaard L, Huniche B, Andersen PL. Relative bradycardia in infectious diseases. J Infect. 1996 Nov;33(3):185-91. [PMID 8945708]

questions.text: Urinary tract infection signs and symptoms are being displayed by a 30-year-old sexually active female. The organism has been identified as ESBL-producing E. coli through sensitivity and culture testing. What antibiotic is preferred for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Imipenem

ESBL-producing E.coli has developed resistance to most antibiotics. The most effective against these organisms is carbapenems among which the drug of choice would be imipenem.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 783.

questions.text: Of the following, which is not an intracellular organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Vibrio cholerae 

Vibrio cholera is an extracellular organism. They are gram-negative, non-sporing and non-capsulated. They are mostly found in marine environments and surface waters. It is non invasive. Cholera toxin acts on zona occludens and causes rice water diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 310.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for carrier of typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ciprofloxacin

Ciprofloxacin is the drug of choice for carriers. In cases of resistance, ceftriaxone can be given.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 306.

questions.text: Which of the following species can cause the appearance of white blood cells without organisms in urine during a urinary tract infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: GU Tuberculosis
 
Sterile pyuria is the persistent finding of white cells in the urine on routine and microscopy but no growth within 48 hours on culture and sensitivity. Most common cause of sterile pyuria is genitourinary tuberculosis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, 23rd edition, Page no 1165.

questions.text: The pustular lesion's culture revealed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. One can make a tentative diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Bacitracin sensitivity

Group A strep is beta haemolytic cocci which are sensitive to bacitracin. It is used to differentiate it from Group B strep which is bacitracin resistant.
Other options- Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility are used to differentiate alpha haemolytic streptococci.
All streptococci are catalase negative.

questions.text: What is the primary factor causing St. Anthony's Fire?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Streptococcus
Audio explanation of the above.

  • St. Anthony's Fire, also known as ergotism, is a disease caused by the consumption of grains contaminated with the fungus Claviceps purpurea.
  • This fungus produces toxins known as ergot alkaloids, which can cause a range of symptoms including hallucinations, convulsions, gangrene, and even death.

questions.text: Which of the organisms is most frequently linked to breast abscesses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Staphylococcus Aureus

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism indicated in breast abscesses. The second most common cause is coagulase-negative staphylococci.
