questions.text: Which of the following statements about cutaneous anthrax is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4:Wool Sorter's Disease

Wool Sorter's Disease is a type of pulmonary anthrax 
Cutaneous anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis. Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:
1- Cutaneous anthrax( Hide porter's disease): Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
2- Pulmonary anthrax( Wool sorter's disease): Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
3- Intestinal anthrax: Hemorrhagic diarrhea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 250.

questions.text: What is the process by which DNA molecules inside a cell exchange genetic information by direct contact known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Conjugation
  • The process by which DNA molecules inside a cell exchange genetic information is known as recombination. Recombination can occur through several mechanisms, including transposition, transformation, conjugation, and duplication.
  • Conjugation is a process by which genetic material is transferred between bacterial cells through direct physical contact.Transposition refers to the movement of a DNA segment from one location to another within the genome.
  • This process can result in the insertion of new genetic material into a chromosome or the deletion of existing genetic material.
  • Transformation involves the uptake of foreign DNA by a cell, which can then be incorporated into the cell's genome through recombination.
  • This process involves the formation of a conjugation bridge between two cells, through which DNA can be transferred.
  • Duplication refers to the process of copying a segment of DNA, resulting in two identical copies of the genetic material. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 60.

choices.text: Produced catalase to negate effect of toxic oxygen radicals

questions.text: The strategy adopted by mycobacterium tuberculosis to avoid intracellular killing is:
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis survive inside the macrophages by the action of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) which impairs phagosome-lysosome fusion by inhibiting intracellular calcium and phosphatidylinositol 3-phospahte. If bacteria are successful in arresting phagosome-lysosome fusion, then they happily replicate inside the macrophages.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: A five-year-old child is diagnosed with lower leg pustules. The lesion's culture revealed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. What is a possible preliminary diagnosis of group A streptococcal pyoderma?
questions.solution:
Group A strep is beta hemolytic cocci which are sensitive to bacitracin. It is used to differentiate it from Group B Streptococci which is bacitracin resistant.

All streptococci are catalase negative.

questions.text: Which gram-negative bacteria's endotoxin  contribute to the aetiology of cholera?
questions.solution:

V. Cholera produces enterotoxin A and B which contributes to the aetiology of cholera by increasing cAMP and producing more intestinal secretions.

questions.text: Which of the following second messengers is stimulated in order to mediate the effects of cholera toxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  cAMP

The Cholera toxin molecule has two subunits, A and B. Out of which A, on being transported to enterocytes dissociates into A1 and A2. A1 fragment activates cAMP which causes an outpouring of secretions in the intestine ultimately leading to watery diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which of these "Vibrios" is most frequently connected to ear infections?

questions.text: Which of the following assertions is true about the use of gamma release assays to diagnose tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay used ESAT-6 and CFP-10

QuantiFERON-TB Gold (QFT) is an in vitro diagnostic test using a peptide cocktail simulating ESAT-6, CFP-10, and TB7.7(p4) proteins to stimulate cells in heparinized whole blood. Detection of interferon-γ (IFN-γ) by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is used to identify in vitro responses to those peptide antigens that are associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

questions.text: Bile esculin Agar is used to identify:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Enterococcus Faecalis

Bile Esculin Agar is used primarily to differentiate Enterococcus from Streptococcus. Members of the genus Enterococcus are capable of growing in the presence of 40% bile (oxgall) and hydrolyzing esculin to glucose and esculetin. Esculetin combines with ferric ions to produce a black complex.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 51.

questions.text: Which is the most common agent responsible for UTI in children ?

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus Pyogenes?

questions.text: Where do we see colonies with Bisected Pearl appearance ?

Bordetella shows colonies that are small, glistening, greyish white. They resemble bisected pearls or mercury drops which is characteristic on Regan-Lowe agar and Bordet-Gengou agar.
on gram staining they show small, ovoid coccobacilli arranged in Thumb print appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following Rickettsial Diseases is associated with fever, tunica reaction and scrotal necrosis on guinea pig inoculation?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1. Rickettsia rickettsii.
  • Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), which is a tick-borne disease that affects humans.
  • The disease is characterized by fever, headache, muscle pain, and a rash. Inoculation of guinea pigs with Rickettsia rickettsii causes fever, tunica reaction (inflammation of the tunica vaginalis, a membrane that covers the testes), and scrotal necrosis (death of tissue in the scrotum). This is a diagnostic test for the disease, as it helps to confirm the presence of Rickettsia rickettsii in the sample. Rickettsia prowazekii is the causative agent of epidemic typhus, which is transmitted by body lice.
  • Rickettsia akari is the causative agent of rickettsialpox, which is transmitted by mites. Rickettsia typhi is the causative agent of murine typhus, which is transmitted by fleas.
  • These diseases have different clinical presentations and diagnostic tests compared to RMSF.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

choices.text: Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar

questions.text: Which of the following CSF findings is associated with Pneumococcal meningitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection. The characteristic CSF findings of which are pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar.
  • Other options- Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar is seen in viral infections.
  • Lymphocytosis is seen in TB and similar conditions.
  • Option 2, i.e. Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar, is the correct CSF (Cerebrospinal Fluid) finding associated with Pneumococcal meningitis.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a type of bacterial meningitis caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In this condition, the bacteria infect the meninges (the protective membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord) and cause inflammation. This inflammation leads to an increase in the number of white blood cells (WBCs) in the CSF, which is called pleocytosis.
  • Additionally, the bacteria produce toxins that damage the blood-brain barrier, which is a specialized system of cells that regulates the movement of substances between the blood and the brain.
  • This damage leads to an increase in the amount of protein in the CSF, which is called hyperproteinemia.
  • However, the bacteria also consume glucose (sugar) present in the CSF as a source of energy, leading to a decrease in the glucose level, which is called hypoglycorrhachia.
  • This decrease in glucose level is an important diagnostic feature of pneumococcal meningitis and is seen in most cases.
  • Therefore, the correct CSF finding associated with Pneumococcal meningitis is pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar, which is option 2.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: A patient presented with rice water stools. Which of the ganglioside receptors is affected?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of passage of rice water stools is suggestive of cholera.
 
  • It is caused by Vibrio Cholerae which shows characteristic darting motility. 
 
  • It produces an enterotoxin which binds to GM1 ganglioside receptor in jejunum.
  • This results in persistent activation of cAMP which causes massive secretion of water and electrolytes causing watery diarrhea. 



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 309, 313, 314.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1307, 1308.

questions.text: Clostridium associated diarrhoea is best diagnosed by:

The diagnosis of clostridium difficile diarrhea is based on detection of toxin or the organism in stool smaples.

  • On endoscopy, it can be diagnosed by visualization of pseudo membrane. 
 
  • The drug of choice for pseudomembranous enterocolitis is Oral fidaxomicin. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1066-1069.

questions.text: A patient was given intravenous botulinum toxin. What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions shown below. All of the following organisms show Subcutaneous nodule/Lymphatic involvement except:

questions.text: Morulae within neutrophils on peripheral smear is seen in infection with?

questions.text: Which among the following is a mollicute?

Among the options provided, Ureaplasma urealyticum is a mollicute.

choices.text: Most important in the prevention of typhoid disease is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply and personal hygiene are more important than immunization in typhoid prevention and control
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that in TB

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Typhoid disease?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about typhoid disease is: Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunization in typhoid prevention and control.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. While immunization is an important preventive measure, it is not the most important aspect in the prevention and control of typhoid disease. The primary mode of transmission of typhoid is through contaminated food and water, usually from fecal contamination. Therefore, ensuring proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and practicing good personal hygiene, including handwashing, are crucial in preventing the spread of typhoid.

Statement 1 is incorrect because while immunization is important, it is not the most important aspect in prevention.

Statement 3 is incorrect because drug resistance in typhoid can be a significant issue, and multiple drug-resistant strains have emerged.

Statement 4 is incorrect because person-to-person transmission is the main mode of transmission for typhoid(Not 10%).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 258-260 .

choices.text: Satellitism in the presence of S. aureus

questions.text: A 5-year old patient was brought to the emergency room with high fever, headache and neck rigidity. CSF analysis revealed low sugars, high protein content with leukocytosis. Gram stain revealed pleomorphic gram negative bacilli. CSF culture is likely to show which of the following culture characteristics?
questions.solution:
The scenario depicts gram-negative bacterial meningitis.

  • Haemophilus and Proteus are the two gram-negative bacilli that have a pleomorphic appearance. 
  • Proteus is not known to cause meningitis in children, rather, it causes urinary tract infections. Thus, the most likely causative organism is Haemophilus influenzae. H. influenzae forms large colonies adjacent to the streak line of Staph. aureus, called satellitism - hence option (4) is correct.
Haemophilus Influenzae

It is a fastidious gram-negative bacilli i.e., it requires two factors for its growth:
  1. Factor X is a hemin, present freely in the blood
  2. Factor V is nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), which is present inside RBCs and could be released via hemolysis by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus.
This is responsible for its culture characteristics. When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, factor V is released from S. aureus, and thus, H. influenzae forms large colonies adjacent to the streak line, called satellitism.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 360.

questions.text: A person working in gutter holes presented with icterus, fever, and blood in the urine. On examination, conjunctival suffusion is noted. Which of these is useful in the diagnosis of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
A sewage worker presenting with icteric fever accompanied by hematuria and conjunctival suffusion likely has leptospirosis.

  • The three 3 R's - rodents, rainfall and rice field are important epidemiological exposures.
  • Similar to rice field workers, sewer workers are also at increased risk due to the exposure to rodent-urine infested surroundings, particularly with stagnant water.

The serovar-specific test called microscopic agglutination test, abbreviated as MAT is the gold standard method and the reference test for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 400.

questions.text:
A young female with multiple sexual partners, has vaginal discharge. Gram-staining is shown below. What is the treatment of choice?

1. Ceftriaxone
2. Doxycycline
3. Penicillin

questions.solution:
Answer:(1). Ceftriaxone

The young female with multiple sexual partners and vaginal discharge likely has a sexually transmitted infection.
The image shows microscopic findings of gram-negative intracellular diplococci indicating infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 250.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms act by inhibition of Elongation Factor-2 ?

Anthrax bacilli and Cholera- Increased cAMP
ETEC- Heat stable- Increased cGMP

questions.text: Which of the following pathogen exhibits cell to cell transfer via Actin filaments?
questions.solution:
Listeria exhibits cell to cell transfer via Actin Filaments of the host. It produces Act A , a listerial protein that induces host cell actin polymerisation and propels them towards host cell membrane.

Listeria is a short gram positive non spore forming bacteria it enters the body through the GIT after ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese or vegetables, it has two cell surface proteins internalins A and B which interacts with the epithelial E-cadherin and promote its own phagocytosis into the gut epithelial cells leading to the formation of the phagolysosome.

Reference: Temel JS, Greer JA, Muzikansky A, et al. Early palliative care for patients with metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. New England Journal of Medicine 2010; 363(8):733-742.
