questions.text: In the case of a suspected infective endocarditis patient, microscopic examination reveals the presence of gram- positive cocci arranged in chains as shown in the image below. What will be the etiological responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus viridans is a group of gram-positive cocci that typically form chains and are a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in cases of subacute bacterial endocarditis. This group is part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and upper respiratory tract. They are classified as alpha-hemolytic, meaning they cause partial hemolysis on blood agar, resulting in a greenish coloration—hence the name "viridans," which means "green" in Latin.

While Viridans streptococci are usually susceptible to penicillin, some strains may exhibit resistance. It is therefore essential to identify the specific strain responsible for endocarditis and assess its antibiotic sensitivity. This ensures the selection of appropriate antibiotics at effective bactericidal levels for optimal treatment.
 

Key differentiating points:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive diplococci, not chains; causes pneumonia, meningitis.

  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep): Gram-positive cocci in chains; β-hemolytic; causes pharyngitis, cellulitis, not endocarditis.

  • Staphylococcus aureus: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, not chains; causes acute endocarditis, especially in IV drug users.

  • Streptococcus viridans: Gram-positive cocci in chains; causes subacute infective endocarditis, especially on damaged valves.

Hence, the etiological agent is Streptococcus viridans.

choices.text: 8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The patient developed diarrhea and abdominal pain shortly after clindamycin therapy, along with fever and leukocytosis, which is highly suggestive of antibiotic-associated colitis caused by Clostridium difficile.

Key points:

  • Clindamycin is a high-risk antibiotic for C. difficile infection.

  • Clinical features: Watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, leukocytosis, and in severe cases, pseudomembranous colitis.

  • Pathophysiology: C. difficile produces toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin) → mucosal injury and inflammation.

  • Diagnosis: Detection of toxins in stool (ELISA or PCR).

  • Management: Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin; stop the offending antibiotic if possible.

Other options:

  • Escherichia coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but not typically post-antibiotic.

  • Norovirus/Rotavirus: Cause viral gastroenteritis; usually community-acquired, not antibiotic-associated.

questions.text: What is the primary identification determined by a CBNAAT/Gene-Xpert?
questions.solution:
CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) / Gene-Xpert is a rapid molecular test for tuberculosis.

Key points:

  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) DNA in clinical samples.

  • Simultaneously identifies rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene, which is a key marker for multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB).

  • Advantages: Results in 2 hours, higher sensitivity than smear microscopy, useful for pulmonary and extrapulmonary TB.

  • Does not detect resistance to isoniazid or ethambutol.

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods with square ends with a central spore. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis suggested by the clinical scenario is cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Key Characteristics of Bacillus anthracis:
Morphology: It is a large, gram-positive rod that exhibits a characteristic "boxcar" or "bamboo stick" appearance.
Structure: Bacillus anthracis is endospore-forming (with non-bulging spores), non-motile, and encapsulated with a distinctive polypeptide capsule.
Infection: It causes zoonotic infections in humans.
Microscopic Appearance:
The provided image demonstrates the typical boxcar or bamboo stick appearance of Bacillus anthracis on Gram staining, reinforcing its identification in the context of cutaneous anthrax.
 

Other options:

  • Bacillus cereus: Causes food poisoning, spores are usually not square-ended, less characteristic lesion

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Gram-negative rod, opportunistic infections, green-blue pigment

  • Brucella abortus: Small gram-negative coccobacilli, causes undulant fever

choices.text: Faucial diphtheria can cause death due to myocarditis
Corynebacterium diphtheria causes myocarditis due to bacteremia.
Patient can develop dyspnea due to obstruction secondary to pseudomembrane formation
Bull's neck appearance is due to cervical lymphadenitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false
questions.solution:
Diptheria is caused by Corynebacterium diptheriae. This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane.
Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis
Complications of C. diphtheriae:
damage to the heart (myocarditis)
kidney (tubular necrosis)
liver and adrenal glands can be affected due to the toxin
In respiratory diphtheria patients, cardiac complications, particularly myocarditis, arise in around 10-25% of cases.
Myocarditis caused us due to the toxins released causing toxaemia.
Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death in Diptheria

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 240-242.

choices.text: Tetanospasmin released by the bacteria causes presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Extoxin A released by the bacteria causes inhibition of acetyl choline release
Exotoxin released by the causative agent causes increased release of glycine and GABA neurotransmitter

questions.text: Following injury by a rusted iron nail a construction worker presented with a locked jaw, muscle rigidity. Which of the following is the mechanism for this presentation?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a locked jaw and rigidity with a background history of injury from a rusted nail is suggestive of a diagnosis of tetanus.
  • The toxin responsible for muscle rigidity and lockjaw is Tetanospasmin.
  • It acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 264-268.

questions.text: The following is the most common pathogenic organism for neonatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
• S. agalactiae belonging to Group B streptococci are the most common cause of meningitis and neonatal sepsis followed by E. coli.
Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1087-88.

choices.text: Assertion(A) is true but Reason(R) is false
Assertion(A) is false but Reason(R) is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A) - Mycobacterium is detected in sputum samples with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) and NaOH.
Reason(R) - The sputum samples are treated by NAC to liquify the sputum and NaOH to kill contaminating bacteria.
questions.solution:
Sputum sample collection,
Mycobacterium is detected in sputum samples with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) and NaOH where N-acetyl cysteine is used for liquefaction of sputum and NaOH kills the contaminating bacteria. Therefore in the above question both assertion and reason are true.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  357-358.

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrives for an antenatal check-up. She has a history of a stillbirth at 28 weeks in her previous pregnancy and recalls having multiple sexual partners, as well as a painless ulcer on her vulva before her last pregnancy. What should be the initial investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test should be the initial investigation for this patient, given her history of a stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, which likely suggests syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete with distinctive corkscrew-like motility.

Primary syphilis follows the sexual transmission of Treponema pallidum and presents as a painless, non-tender papule on the genitalia that quickly becomes eroded and indurated, forming a hard chancre. It may also be accompanied by lymphadenopathy. The chancre usually heals within 10-40 days even without treatment, leaving a scar.

In untreated syphilitic women, obstetric outcomes may improve with subsequent pregnancies. Initial pregnancies may result in abortions or stillbirths, while later pregnancies may lead to live births with syphilitic manifestations. Ultimately, healthy infants may be born after several pregnancies.

Syphilis can be diagnosed with VDRL and RPR tests, and confirmed with FTA-ABS, TPHA, or TPI testing.

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive method for diagnosing syphilis when an active chancre or condylomalata is present. Since the ulcer is inactive in this patient, dark ground microscopy is not appropriate here.

Smear specimens can be stained with Fontana stain, while pathological tissues can be stained using Levaditi stain. The silver impregnation technique is also applicable.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 375 .

questions.text: ACSF sample of an elderly male presenting with meningitis is subjected to gram staining and revealed gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following is true regarding the motility of the causative agent?**
questions.solution:
The scenario of an elderly male with meningitis and a gram-positive bacillus on smear is indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria monocytogenes is motile at 25°C and non-motile at 37°C, displaying a characteristic slow tumbling motility at temperatures between 22°C and 28°C. This differential motility is due to the production of peritrichous flagella, which are most effective between 20°C and 30°C.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), as well as in acidic conditions and high salt environments. This ability allows it to overcome food preservation barriers, making it a significant foodborne pathogen. Its primary virulence factor is listeriolysin O, which helps the bacteria escape from phagocytes and can lead to septicemia.

The bacterium is catalase-positive, does not produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), and demonstrates beta-hemolysis, which helps differentiate it from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeria monocytogenes typically enters the body through the consumption of contaminated food such as refrigerated milk, cheese, fruit, or vegetables. While healthy individuals may experience mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis with symptoms including fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, this illness usually lasts 1-3 days and has an incubation period of 6-48 hours.

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 402-403 .

questions.text: Which of the following organism is transferred by the parasite shown below?
questions.solution:
The trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for transmitting Orientiatsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus. Humans become infected when bitten by the mite‘s larvae, known as chiggers. The disease has an incubation period of 1 to 3 weeks.

Patients typically develop a distinctive eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymph node swelling (lymphadenopathy) and a maculopapular rash. Symptoms can include fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. In severe cases, complications such as meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia may occur.

Diagnosis is primarily made through serologic assays. One commonly used test is the Weil-Felix reaction, a heterophile agglutination test in which sera are examined for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain *Proteus* strains (OX19, OX2, and OXK). In scrub typhus, only the OXK strain is agglutinated.

The preferred treatment for scrub typhus in both adults and children is doxycycline.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 977 .

questions.text: The given image of the cell wall belongs towhich of the following organism?
questions.solution:
An image showing a cell wall with a capsule and lipooligosaccharides (LOS) suggests the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.

Unlike lipopolysaccharides (LPS), LOS lacks a long O-antigen side chain but remains a key virulence factor. It is found in several organisms, including Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus ducreyi.

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative, aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci that typically appear in pairs (diplococci). It includes two major pathogens: Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A crucial distinction between them is that N. Meningitidis has a capsule, while N. Gonorrhoeaedoes not.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Page no 29,295,297 .

questions.text: A patient presented with a lesion on the left buttock. He has a history of heart transplant 15 years back. Aspirate from the lesion shows gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario presented involves a local abscess with aspirate findings indicating filamentous, gram-positive bacteria, suggestive of Nocardia species. Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive branching, and they are aerobic, gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease-positive. They are weakly acid-fast, which means they stain with carbolfuchsin and retain the stain even after decolorization with 1-4% sulfuric acid, unlike the stronger acid-alcohol decolorizer used for other acid-fast organisms.

Infections caused by Nocardia can manifest as cutaneous, subcutaneous, or systemic lesions, including local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. Systemic nocardiosis is more common in immunocompromised individuals and often presents as pulmonary disease, such as pneumonia or lung abscesses, resembling tuberculosis. Extrapulmonary manifestations can affect the brain, kidneys, and other organs.

The provided image depicts a smear stained with modified acid-fast Kinyoun staining, showing filamentous, red-stained, partially acid-fast rods consistent with Nocardia

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 400 .

questions.text: A microorganism is resistant to meropenem and aminoglycoside and sensitive to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. What is the likely microorganism?
questions.solution:
Stenotrophomonasmaltophila, formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia. This bacterium is known to be sensitive to co-trimoxazole.

Intrinsic resistance refers to a bacterial species‘ natural ability to resist the effects of certain antimicrobial agents due to inherent structural or functional characteristics. This built-in resistance allows the bacteria to tolerate specific drugs or classes of antimicrobials.

Burkholderiacepacia,formerly referred to as Pseudomonas cepacia,is an opportunistic pathogen that can lead to fatal necrotizing pneumonia. Strains within the B. Cepacia complex are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymyxins, and first- and second-generation cephalosporins. However, they are sensitive to meropenem, co-trimoxazole, doxycycline, minocycline, chloramphenicol, and ceftazidime.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 322 .

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair Medium:

  • Selective medium used for the isolation and identification of Salmonella typhi

  • Appearance: Colonies of S. typhi appear black due to HS production

  • Contains bismuth sulfite and brilliant green to inhibit gram-positive and many gram-negative bacteria

  • Commonly used for typhoid diagnosis

    Other options: 

    Medium Use
    1. BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) Used to culture Legionella pneumophila
    2. PLET medium Selective for Bacillus anthracis
    4. Stuart’s medium A transport medium, not for culture or identification

questions.text: A truck driver comes with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely indicative of a syphilitic chancre (hard chancre) caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of Treponema pallidum can be demonstrated using dark-field (dark ground) microscopy, a cost-effective method suitable for low-resource settings.

Dark-field microscopy is commonly used for the diagnosis of syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present, allowing visualization of Treponema pallidum. In dark-field microscopy, the background is dark, and the organism appears refractile. The microscope is designed to enhance the contrast of unstained bodies but has relatively low sensitivity.



Appearance of various spirochetes under dark-field microscopy:
Treponema species: short, slender, with regular, sharp spirals.
Leptospira: numerous closely wound spirals with characteristic hooked ends.
Borrelia: large with irregular, wide-open coils.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid-fast organism?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium avium is an acid-fast organism that belongs to the Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which includes multiple nontuberculous mycobacterial species (NTM). These species are indistinguishable in the microbiology laboratory and require genetic testing for identification. The two original members of this complex are M. avium and Mycobacterium intracellulare.


Characteristics:
Nonmotile
Non-spore-forming
Gram-positive
Acid-fast bacillus

Clinical Significance:
MAC infection is considered an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection and typically occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <50/?L.
The most common presentation of MAC infection is disseminated disease, which may manifest as:
Fever
Weight loss
Night sweats

Treatment:
The recommended treatment regimen includes:
Clarithromycin or Azithromycin
Ethambutol or Rifabutin

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods with square ends with a central spore. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis is cutaneous anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive, rod-shaped bacterium that forms endospores (non-bulging) and has a distinctive boxcar or bamboo stick appearance due to its squared ends. It is a non-motile, capsulated organism with a unique polypeptide capsule, and is responsible for zoonotic infections in humans.



Other options:

  • Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods but associated with food poisoning, not cattle lesions.

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Gram-negative rod.

  • Brucella abortus: Gram-negative coccobacillus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation of a maculopapular rash, flu-like symptoms, and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is indicative of secondary syphilis.



Secondary syphilis typically develops within 6 to 8 weeks following the appearance of the primary chancre. It is characterized by:

The onset of systemic manifestations, which may include symptoms such as malaise, headache, loss of appetite, and sore throat.
A generalized, symmetric, and asymptomatic maculopapular rash that can be found on the palms and soles.
Generalized lymphadenopathy occurring in 50% of cases.

Condyloma lata, which are classic findings. These are highly contagious, exophytic, broad lesions that can ulcerate and are commonly located on the vulva, perianal area, and upper thighs.
 

Other options:

  • Steven Johnson syndrome: Painful target lesions, mucosal involvement, usually drug-related.

  • Meningococcemia: Petechial/purpuric rash, often with fever, meningitis, shock.

  • Psoriasis: Chronic scaly plaques (silvery-white), may affect palms/soles but not associated with epitrochlear nodes or sexual history.

questions.text: A young girl presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of rice watery diarrhea following consumption is bakery food 2 days ago. Selective culture media is shown below. Identify the likely organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of food poisoning with rice watery diarrhea and yellow-coloured colonies on thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar
(TCBS) is suggestive of vibrio cholera.
Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus and causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice-water stools) associated with effortless vomiting.
Vibrio cholerae produces an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results, in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ref -Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition • Page no
313,314,318

questions.text: A 4 year old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. On oral examination, a pseudomembrane is seen over the tonsils. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution: The given history with pseudo-membrane formation is suggestive of diphtheria. The causative organism being cornybacterium diptheriae which release an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Ref- Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition • Page no 240- 242, 322

questions.text: A young girl was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous diarrhea with rice water stools. A microscopic examination of a stool sample is shown in the image below. Which of the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of rice water stools with fish in stream appearance of bacteria on microscopy is suggestive of a vibrio cholerae infection.
Transport media for Vibrio cholerae include:
• Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
• Cary Blair medium
• Autoclaved seawater.
Enrichment media for Vibrio cholerae include:
• Alkaline peptone water at a pH of 8.6
• Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water at a pH of 9.2.
Stuart medium is used for Neisseria app. Buffered glycerol saline medium is used for recovery of Salmonella spp. Shigella spp. and E.coli in fecal sample. Ref- Ananthnarayan textbook of microbiology 10th edition Page 309-315

questions.text: A 20 year old female presented with history of diarrhoea, abdominal pain. On evaluation she was found to have stepladder pyrexia, blanching small red spots on the abdomen and chest and hepatosplenomegaly. She is in her third week of illness, what is the test of choice for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and best test to screen a patient for typhoid in the third week is urine culture.
Diagnosis of enteric fever:
• Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week than in the subsequent weeks. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.
• Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titers of H and O agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.
• Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.
• Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.
• Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week.
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition • Page no 304

questions.text: Which if the following organisms is not a part of the normal conjunctival flora
questions.solution:
The normal flora of the conjunctiva consists of a variety of microorganisms that exist harmlessly and help maintain ocular health by preventing the colonization of pathogenic organisms. The most commonly found bacteria in the conjunctiva include:
Staphylococcus epidermidis (most common), staphylococcus aureus, corynebacterium species, streptococcus viridans, propionibacterium acnes, etc.
Jawetz, Melnick, & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology- 28th Edition • Page no:206-208

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is associated with R. Prowazeki
questions.solution:
Organism disease vector Reservoir clinical features
Typhus group
R.prowazekii Epidemic typhus &
Brill-Zinsser
disease		 louse humans Rash+
No eschar
R.typhi Endemic typhus Rat flea Rodents Rash+
No eschar
Spotted fever group
R. rickettsii Rocky mountain spotted fever Tick (Dermacentor andersoni) Rodents, dogs Rash+
No eschar
Many systemic manifestations
R. conori Indian tick typhus Tick Rodents, dogs Tache noire +
Rash +
R. akari Rickettsial pox Gamasid mite mice Vesicular rash
Eschar
scrub typhus
.
tsutsugamushi		 scrub typhus Trombiculid
Mite		 Rodents Rash+
Eschar +
Atypical lymphocytes+

Rickettsia prowazekii is an obligate, intracellular, gram-negative coccobacillus belonging to the genus Rickettsia. It is the causative agent of epidemic typhus which is transmitted by the human body louse. Epidemic typhus presents with a high fever, myalgias, headache, dry cough, delirium and a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads peripherally. Ref- Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 977

questions.text: A neonate was diagnosed with meningitis. The organism showed resistance to bacitracin. What is the most likely cause for this neonate's condition?
questions.solution:
• Neonatal meningitis is most commonly caused by Group B Streptococcus (GBS / Streptococcus agalactiae).

  • Laboratory clue: Resistance to bacitracin helps differentiate GBS from Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes), which is bacitracin-sensitive.

  • Other features of S. agalactiae:

    • β-hemolytic on blood agar

    • Commonly causes early-onset sepsis in neonates (<7 days) and late-onset disease (7–90 days).

Other options:

  • Enterococcus: Can cause neonatal infections but rare for meningitis; usually resistant to many antibiotics.

  • Pneumococcus (S. pneumoniae): Can cause meningitis in children/adults, less common in neonates.

  • Streptococcus pyogenes: Group A Streptococcus; bacitracin-sensitive, not typical in neonatal meningitis.



Reference
1. Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition - Page no: 218, 219

2. Jawetz, Melnick, & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology 28th Edition - Page no:222

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with acute gastroenteritis after consuming raw seafood or shellfish, which is typical for Vibrio parahaemolyticus infection.

  • Kanagawa phenomenon:

    • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar due to thermostable hemolysin (Kanagawa hemolysin) produced by pathogenic strains.

    • Characteristic diagnostic feature for V. parahaemolyticus.

  • Incubation period: 12–24 hours, watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and mild fever.

Other options:

  • Vibrio cholerae: Causes rice-water diarrhea, usually epidemic; does not show Kanagawa phenomenon.

  • Vibrio mimicus: Can cause diarrhea, but rare and no Kanagawa hemolysis.

  • Vibrio alginolyticus: Causes wound infections or otitis externa, not typical gastroenteritis with Kanagawa phenomenon.



Reference:
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition - pg no 318

questions.text: A male patient presented with fever persisting for 3 weeks. He gives a history of prosthetic valve implantation 6 months before. Investigations reveal mitral valve vegetation and is diagnosed with endocarditis. Which of the following is the most common cause of endocarditis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Following a six-month interval following the implantation of a prosthetic valve, the patient now exhibits fever and mitral valve vegetations, indicating the possibility of early prosthetic valve endocarditis. The coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are the most likely causal bacterium in this instance.

The most frequent cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis is Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS).

Depending on when the prosthetic valve was implanted, the following common pathogens cause prosthetic valve endocarditis:

Coagulase-negative staphylococci > <2 months Aureus Staphylococcus

Coagulase-negative staphylococci, 2–12 months

>12 months: Staphylococcus aureus > Streptococci

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Table 123-1

questions.text: A female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The picture depicts a Clue cell, an epithelial cell whose border is blurry as a result of bacterial adhesion. This points to bacterial vaginosis when paired with the given clinical characteristics.

Haemophilus vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, Gardnerella vaginalis, and Mobiluncus curtisii are a few of the species that can cause bacterial vaginosis, a polymicrobial infection. Usually, there is little vulval discomfort and a foul-smelling, fishy vaginal discharge when it first appears.

Amsel's Criteria, which necessitates at least three of the following four indicators, can be used to confirm the diagnosis:

Thin, uniform, white vaginal discharge

pH of vaginal fluid > 4.5

Discharge with a fishy smell, especially after adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)

Clue cell presence during microscopy




Reference
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 16th Edition - Page no 384

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by exotoxins?
questions.solution:
• Exotoxins are secreted proteins by bacteria that cause specific diseases by targeting host cells or tissues. Examples:

    • Pseudomembranous colitis: Caused by C. difficile exotoxin

    • Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by S. aureus or S. pyogenes superantigen exotoxins

    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Caused by Shiga toxin from E. coli

  • Meningitis, however, is usually caused by invasion and inflammation of the meninges by bacteria (e.g., Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae) or viruses. Exotoxins are not the primary cause of meningitis.

Other options:

  • Pseudomembranous colitis: Exotoxin-mediated damage to colonic epithelium.

  • Toxic shock syndrome: Exotoxin-mediated systemic illness.

  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Exotoxin-mediated endothelial injury.





Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 13th Edition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. A lumbar puncture was taken in view of meningitis which showed reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with predominant neutrophils. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37 degrees and tumbling motility at 25 degrees. What is the most likely organism Causing this?
questions.solution:
• Fever, headache, photophobia, neck rigidity → signs of meningitis

  • Immunosuppressed patient (post-heart transplant on immunomodulators)

  • CSF findings:

    • ↓ Glucose

    • ↑ Protein

    • ↑ WBCs (predominantly neutrophils)

  • Microscopy:

    • Tumbling motility at 25°C,

    • Non-motile at 37°C

These findings point to Listeria monocytogenes, a Gram-positive facultative intracellular bacillus.
 

  • At-Risk Groups:

    • Neonates

    • Elderly

    • Pregnant women

    • Immunocompromised patients (like this transplant patient)

      Why not the other options?

  1. Streptococcus (esp. S. pneumoniae):

    • Common cause of meningitis in adults

    • But no characteristic tumbling motility

    • No temperature-dependent motility pattern

  2. Staphylococcus:

    • Can cause brain abscesses or meningitis (rare)

    • Non-motile, no temperature-dependent motility

  3. Giardia lamblia:

    • Protozoan parasite

    • Causes GI symptoms, not meningitis

    • Shows “falling leaf” motility, not tumbling motility in CSF


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. On examination, splinter hemorrhages were seen. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves and thus a blood culture was done. The organism in the culture was seen as cocci in chains that showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Fever, fatigue, and splinter hemorrhages → suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE)

  • Echocardiography: Valve vegetations

  • Blood culture:

    • Cocci in chains

    • Alpha hemolytic on blood agar

    • Optochin-resistant

    • Bile-resistant

      Organism Identification:

Feature Finding Suggests
Morphology Cocci in chains Streptococci
Hemolysis Alpha hemolysis Viridans streptococci
Optochin resistance Resistant Not S. pneumoniae
Bile resistance Resistant Not S. pneumoniae
This profile matches Viridans group streptococci, specifically Streptococcus sanguis (a part of the Streptococcus viridans group), which is a major cause of subacute bacterial endocarditis.


Why Not Others?

  • Streptococcus pyogenes:

    • Beta hemolytic, Group A streptococcus

    • Causes pharyngitis, skin infections, not typical for endocarditis

  • Enterococcus:

    • Gamma (non)-hemolytic or weakly alpha hemolytic

    • Can cause endocarditis but shows growth in bile and salt and differs morphologically

  • Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B):

    • Beta hemolytic

    • Common in neonatal sepsis, not typical in subacute IE in adults


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 7th edition page no 211,220,221

choices.text: 8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/I. What is the most probable etiological agent?

questions.text: A 70-yearold woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/I. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
This vignette provides a detailed overview of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI), particularly its presentation, diagnosis, and treatment. 

Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI)
Overview:

Most common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea and nosocomial infections.
Occurs due to disruption of normal gut flora following antibiotic use, allowing C. difficile to colonize.

Symptoms include:
Lower abdominal pain
Watery diarrhea
Fever
Leukocytosis
Can progress to pseudomembranous colitis, which may be life-threatening.
Investigations:

Stool Tests:
Nucleic acid amplification tests (e.g., PCR for toxin genes A or B).
Stool culture on selective media.
Toxin detection via Hep-2 cell cultures.
Enzyme immunoassays for toxin gene identification.
Endoscopic Findings:
Colonoscopy/sigmoidoscopy may reveal erythema, white plaques, or pseudomembranes.

Treatment:

First-Line Options:
Oral Vancomycin: Preferred for initial mild to moderate cases.
Fidaxomicin: Alternative option.
Metronidazole: Now reserved for non-severe cases when first-line options are unavailable due to cost or access issues.
Note: Metronidazole is less effective than vancomycin and fidaxomicin, often requiring longer treatment.
Other Causes of Nosocomial Diarrhea:

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 19th edition page no 918

questions.text: A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with some difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils which bleeds on scraping the lesion. A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is as shown below. What is the organism associated with the disease?
questions.solution:
• Fever + mild headache

  • Dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing)

  • Throat exam: Swollen lymph nodes, thick white membrane over tonsils

    • Bleeds on scraping → classic hallmark of diphtheria

  • Gram stain image: (Not visible here, but presumably shows gram-positive bacilli)

    Diagnosis: Diphtheria

  • Causative organism: Corynebacterium diphtheriae

  • Key Features:

    • Gray-white pseudomembrane that bleeds on removal

    • Gram positive rods, often in palisade arrangement ("Chinese letters")

    • Non-motile, non-spore forming

    • Club-shaped ends

      Why Not the Others?

  • HHV-6:

    • Causes roseola infantum in infants (high fever, then rash)

    • Not associated with pseudomembranes or exudative pharyngitis

  • Parvovirus B19:

    • Causes erythema infectiosum (slapped cheek syndrome) in children

    • Can cause aplastic crisis in sickle cell patients

    • No throat membrane or classic pharyngitis

  • Beta-hemolytic streptococci (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes):

    • Can cause pharyngitis (strep throat)

    • But no pseudomembrane formation

    • Lesion does not typically bleed on scraping

      Additional Diagnostic Points:

  • Culture on Löffler's medium or Tellurite agar

  • Elek’s test → detects diphtheria toxin

  • PCR for tox gene

  • Toxin-mediated complications: Myocarditis, neuritis, renal failure


Reference: Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition - Page no 239-245, 256, 257, 261, 210, 214, 274, 275

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Tuberculosis and while testing for resistance he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and Ofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.solution:
The patient's Mycobacterium tuberculosis strain shows resistance to:

  • Isoniazid (INH)

  • Rifampicin (RIF) → qualifies as MDR-TB

  • Amikacin → a second-line injectable aminoglycoside

  • Ofloxacin → a fluoroquinolone

    Definition Recap:

Type Definition
Rifampicin-Resistant TB (RR-TB) Resistant to RIF, with or without resistance to other drugs
Multi-Drug Resistant TB (MDR-TB) Resistant to at least INH and RIF
Poly-Drug Resistant TB Resistant to more than one first-line anti-TB drug but NOT both INH and RIF
Extensively Drug-Resistant TB (XDR-TB) MDR-TB plus resistance to any fluoroquinolone (e.g. Ofloxacin) and at least one second-line injectable (e.g. Amikacin, Kanamycin, Capreomycin)

Other options: 

  • Option 1: RR-TB – This patient has resistance beyond just RIF.

  • Option 2: Poly-drug resistant TB – This would mean resistance to multiple drugs excluding both INH and RIF.

  • Option 3: Multi-drug sensitive TB – Incorrect, as the strain is clearly resistant to several drugs.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no 363

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
ZIEHL-NEELSEN STAINING: OVERVIEW
Feature Details
Purpose Detects acid-fast bacilli (AFB) like Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Principle Acid-fast organisms resist decolorization by acid-alcohol due to high mycolic acid content in their cell walls.
Staining Method Differential staining: Acid-fast bacilli retain the primary stain even after acid-alcohol wash.
Common Organisms Stained - Mycobacterium tuberculosis
- Mycobacterium leprae
- Nocardia spp. (partially acid-fast)

Steps of ZN staining: 
Procedure Reagent Used Purpose
Smear preparation and fixation Heat or alcohol Fixes bacteria to slide
Primary stain Carbol fuchsin (with heating) Penetrates waxy cell wall
Decolorization Acid-alcohol (3% HCl + ethanol) Removes stain from non–acid-fast bacteria
Counterstain Methylene blue or malachite green Stains background and non–acid-fast organisms

Observation Meaning
Red bacilli (rod-shaped) Acid-fast bacilli present
Blue background Non–acid-fast cells and background stained by counterstain
 

  • Samples used:

    • Sputum (most common)

    • Bronchoalveolar lavage

    • CSF

    • Lymph node aspirates

  • Often first step before GeneXpert or culture on Löwenstein-Jensen medium.





Other options: 
Stain Usage
1. Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS) Fungi (e.g., Pneumocystis jirovecii, Aspergillus)
3. Perl's Prussian Blue Iron in tissues (e.g., sideroblasts in anemia)
4. Masson-Fontana Melanin (e.g., in pigmented tumors)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no
358.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following can be used to diagnose the condition in a low-resource setting when an active ulcer is present?
questions.solution:
A painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe sexual contact is highly suggestive of primary syphilis, which is caused by Treponema pallidum.

Diagnostic Tools:

In primary syphilis, when the chancre (ulcer) is still present, direct detection methods are preferred:

Dark field microscopy:

  • This is the most effective and rapid diagnostic method in early/primary syphilis when the active ulcer is present.

  • It involves visualizing live spirochetes (Treponema pallidum) from the serous fluid of the ulcer under dark-field illumination.

  • Highly specific and quick.

  • Ideal in low-resource settings, since it doesn’t require complex lab setups or serologic reagents.

    Why not the others?

  1. Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS):

    • Serologic test for syphilis.

    • Treponemal test—highly specific but not helpful in acute primary stage unless seroconversion has occurred.

    • Requires sophisticated lab equipment.

  2. Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test:

    • A non-treponemal serological test.

    • Can be negative in very early primary syphilis.

    • Also requires laboratory infrastructure.

  3. Treponema pallidum immobilization test:

    • Very specific but rarely used now due to technical complexity and cost.

    • Needs live organisms, complement, and specific antibodies.

    • Not feasible in low-resource settings.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no
10-12,378-383,385,387.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl who presented with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers over the vulval region is diagnosed with granuloma inguinale. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation describes a 21-year-old girl with multiple beefy-red painless ulcers on the vulva, which is highly characteristic of granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis.

The causative organism of granuloma inguinale is Klebsiella granulomatis, previously known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It is a Gram-negative bacillus that causes a chronic, progressive, sexually transmitted infection.

The hallmark of granuloma inguinale is the development of painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily on touch. These ulcers are highly vascular and tend to be indolent but progressive. Unlike chancroid or LGV, lymphadenopathy is usually absent in granuloma inguinale.

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying Donovan bodies — intracellular inclusions found in mononuclear phagocytes — on tissue smear stained with Giemsa or Wright stain.

Now, let’s briefly consider the incorrect options:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis (Option 2) is the causative agent of Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which usually begins with a small, often unnoticed genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

  • Herpes simplex virus (Option 3) causes painful, grouped vesicles or shallow ulcers on the genitalia, often with systemic symptoms like fever and malaise.

  • Haemophilus ducreyi (Option 4) is responsible for chancroid, which presents with a painful, soft genital ulcer and painful unilateral lymphadenopathy (bubo formation).

Thus, the only option that matches painless, beefy-red ulcers with no lymphadenopathy is Klebsiella granulomatis.

Treatment of Granuloma Inguinale (Donovanosis)

First-line treatment (CDC 2021 and WHO guidelines):

  • Azithromycin 1 g orally once a week or 500 mg orally daily
    → Duration: at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have completely healed.

    Alternative regimens:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for at least 3 weeks

  • Ciprofloxacin 750 mg orally twice daily

  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally four times daily

  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) DS twice daily
    → All for a minimum of 3 weeks or until complete healing.


Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 16th edition page no 158-160

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite ina godown presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Farmer with flea bite history

  • High fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)

  • Vomiting, diarrhea, hypotension (suggesting sepsis)

  • Bipolar-staining bacilli seen on smear

All this is highly suggestive of plague, caused by Yersinia pestis.

Diagnostic Feature:

Yersinia pestis appears as:

  • Gram-negative rod

  • Shows bipolar staining (resembles a “safety pin”)

The stain that highlights this:

  • Wayson’s stain (a polychrome methylene blue stain)
    → stains the poles of Yersinia pestis more intensely than the center
    → giving it the "safety pin" appearance
    → rapid and inexpensive; useful in low-resource settings or endemic regions

    Other Options (Incorrect):

  1. Albert's stain – Used to detect metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae

  2. Neisser stain – Also used to detect volutin/metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae

  3. McFadyean's stain – For Bacillus anthracis (anthrax), highlights capsule


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no 329

choices.text: Maximum levels are seen within one week

questions.text: Pick the option that is true for viral antibodies.
questions.solution:
Viral antibodies

Viral antibodies develop after Interferon and tend to reach considerable levels only after one week.
They are aimed at the surface proteins of the viruses (not Nucleic acid) as protein is most antigenic. 

Hence, only option (3) is a true statement. 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 455.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about dengue
questions.solution:
For the treatment of dengue, fluid replenishment is most important. There is no role for any drugs. If platelet count goes below 10000/mm3 then platelet transfusion can be given. The rest of other options are correct statements. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 530.

questions.text: Reverse transcriptase is a DNA polymerase that is RNA dependent. Which of the following employs reverse transcriptase?
questions.solution:
Reverse transcriptase is used by the hepatitis B virus.

Polymerase (Pol) of the hepatitis B virus demonstrates both DNA polymerase and reverse transcriptase activity.

Through a special replication cycle, genomic replication takes place using an intermediary RNA template: DNA-RNA-DNA.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 548.

questions.text: What causes tropical spastic paresis?
questions.solution:
TSP is known as HTLV-1 associated myelopathy which leads to inflammation of spinal cord.

HTLV-1 is a retrovirus that primarily affects T-cells and can lead to a chronic neurological condition, which manifests as tropical spastic paresis, characterized by spasticity, weakness, and sensory disturbances, particularly in the lower limbs.

 

Other options:

• HIV (option 1): While HIV can cause neurological complications, it does not typically cause tropical spastic paresis. However, HIV-associated myelopathy or HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders can occur in some cases.

• HBV (option 2): Hepatitis B virus (HBV) primarily affects the liver and does not cause tropical spastic paresis.

• EBV (option 4): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with infectious mononucleosis and other conditions like certain cancers, but not with tropical spastic paresis.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 571.

questions.text: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection does not cause which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection causes oropharyngeal carcinoma, not nasopharyneageal carcinoma.
Audio explanation of the above.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 557.

choices.text: Withhold vaccine and observe dog for 10 days
Kill dog and send brain for biopsy

questions.text: A 10-year boy with unprovoked dog bite comes to you. Appropriate action is:
questions.solution:
According to updated Thai red cross regimen (2-2-2-0-2) for post exposure prophylaxis, reconstituted rabies vaccine is given as follows: •0.1ml intradermally •Two sites at the same visit. It is given in both the deltoids. •Schedule - Days 0,3,7 and 28.Post-exposure prophylaxis: Patients who were bitten by an allegedly rabid animal make up the great majority of patients in need of anti-rabies therapy.
The goal is to prevent the virus from entering the nervous system by neutralising the vaccine.
Every case of exposure to humans needs to be handled as an emergency.
It is now widely accepted that the best particular prophylactic treatment following a man's exposure to rabies is the combination of the delivery of a single dose of rabies immunoglobulin, if needed, with a course of vaccination, along with local care of the wound.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 540.

choices.text: Reassure patient that he does not have any disease

questions.text: What course of action should be taken if a person tests negative for anti-HBc Ab but positive for HBsAg?
questions.solution:
This is a case of chronic Hepatitis B because the patient has HBsAg but no Anti-HBc Ab. Before starting treatment, an HBV-DNA load should be performed. In general, for both HBeAg-reactive and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B, the quantity of HBV DNA corresponds with the severity of liver damage and risk of progression. Chronic HBV infection can occur in the presence or absence of serum hepatitis B antigen (HBeAg).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

questions.text: After being bitten by a dog, a patient presents with hydrophobia, tearing, and altered sensory perception. You believe that this patient has rabies. An impression of the cornea has been made. Which tests need to be run on it to ensure the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
To ensure the most accurate diagnosis of rabies in a patient with corneal impressions, the most appropriate tests to run are **1. Direct immunofluorescence** and **2. RT-PCR for virus**.

- **Direct immunofluorescence** allows for the detection of rabies virus antigens directly in the corneal sample.
- **RT-PCR** can detect the presence of rabies virus RNA, providing a highly sensitive and specific diagnosis.

While histopathological examination for Negri bodies is important, it is not typically performed on corneal impressions. Antibodies against the rabies virus are generally assessed in serum, not corneal tissue.

Direct Immunofluorescence is the best option as it's a quick and less costly investigation. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 457.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who had previously experienced fever, sore throat, and swollen neck lymph nodes was seen. A Paul-Bunnell test was mandated for him due to a possible case of infectious mononucleosis. What immunological principles underpin the application of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Heterophile antibody test

This test is based on the principle of heterophile antibody test wherein the presence of sheep agglutinins in the sera of infectious mononucleosis patients, which are absorbed by OX-ready cells but not by guinea pig kidney extract. It is performed to confirm Infectious Mononucleosis and also during the treatment and after the treatment. 

Examples of Heterophile antibody test: -
  • Paul Bunnel test 
  • Monospot test
  • Weil Felix test 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: A vesicle was discovered on the shin of a patient. The Tzanck smear microscopy revealed enormous cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Vesicles on shin and giant cells(enormous cells) on Tzanck smear suggest the diagnosis of Herpes Zoster.


Herpes zoster, commonly known as shingles, is a reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the same virus that causes chickenpox.

Clinical Diagnosis: Primarily based on the characteristic appearance of the rash and associated symptoms.
Laboratory Tests: PCR testing of vesicular fluid can confirm the diagnosis if necessary, but it’s usually not required for typical cases.

Treatment-Antiviral Medications: Acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir can reduce the severity and duration of the illness if started within 72 hours of rash onset.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 451.

questions.text: A patient arrives at your clinic complaining of three days of loose, watery stools. After more investigation, you discover that these episodes began three days after he consumed shellfish at a nearby restaurant and that other people who ate at that restaurant experienced identical symptoms. What is the most prevalent cause of viral diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most typical cause of viral gastroenteritis in people is norwalk virus. 
The virus can spread from person to person, by direct contact with feces-contaminated food or drink, and through aerosolization of the virus and subsequent surface contamination.
Infection with norwalk virus is characterized by watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and, occasionally, loss of taste. There may be a general weakness, muscle aches, headaches, and mild fever.
The foods that cause norwalk virus outbreaks the most frequently are shellfish and salad elements.
Consuming shellfish that has not been heated adequately increases the chance of contracting norwalk virus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 565.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in Zika fever
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Petechial rash

Zika virus is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito and is manifested as fever, arthralgia, headache, conjunctivitis and a rash which aren’t petechial. It is also known to be associated with Guillain-Barre syndrome.
A petechial rash is not a primary feature of zika virus infection. Though petechiae may rarely appear in zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of zika virus disease. Petechial rash point towards a diagnosis of dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a zika virus disease. The complications of zika virus are Guillain - Barre syndrome and fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 530.

questions.text: Which muscle is involved in the hand-to-knee gait in polio?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Quadriceps

Poliomyelitis often leads to quadriceps paralysis which causes muscle imbalance. The patient characteristically supports his thigh with his hand in order to walk.

Reference: Essentials of orthopaedics, Maheshwari and Mhaskar, 7th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: Which among the following viral hemorrhagic fevers have occurred in India?
questions.solution:
Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever has been reported in India.

Viral hemorrhagic fevers are zoonotic diseases brought on by viruses that live in arthropod vectors or animal reservoirs.
The Ebola and Marburg virus infections in Africa, as well as yellow fever in Africa and South America, are only a few instances of the diseases that affect the entire world yet are only present where the host species is present.

Geographically, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is widely distributed. The first confirmed case of CCHF in India was noted in January 2011 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, during a nosocomial outbreak.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 531.

questions.text: Identify the virus using the provided cycle?
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is of HIV virus. It has ssRNA and undergoes reverse transcription as shown in the image. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 570.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B infection with Hepatitis E super infection
Co- infection with Hepatitis B & Hepatitis E

questions.text: The patient has increased SGPT and SGOT, positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM, and positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM. Their Bilirubin level is 0.9 mg/dl. The patient suffers from:
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient was already infected with hepatitis B and after that gets  infected with an acute strain of hepatitis E virus as the patient 's lab reports show 
  • positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM- suggestive of chronic infection  of hepatitis B
  •  positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM- suggestive of acute hepatitis E infection
This is known as  superinfection of hepatitis E on hepatitis B and can cause a more severe form of illness than if the patient had only been infected with either virus alone.

Superinfection occurs when a person is already infected with a particular virus and is then infected with a different strain of the same virus.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

choices.text: Viral culture and isolation in C6/36 cell line

questions.text: All of these are acceptable studies on day three of presentation in a patient suspected of having dengue, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
ELISA for Dengue virus antibody detection often produces diagnostic results only after 5 days, or the acute period of illness. IgM ELISA, paired serology, or antigen-detection ELISA, or RT-PCR, are used to make the diagnosis during the recovery phase, or during the acute phase.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 529.

questions.text: A patient with acute hydrophobia is brought to the hospital. You took corneal scrapings from the patient and suspect rabies. What test should be performed on this sample to determine whether rabies is present?
questions.solution:
To determine whether rabies is present in corneal scrapings, the most appropriate test to perform is 4. Direct immunofluorescence.

This test allows for the detection of rabies virus antigens in the sample, providing a rapid and specific diagnosis of rabies. Negri bodies are typically identified in brain tissue rather than corneal scrapings, and while RT-PCR can be used, direct immunofluorescence is more commonly employed for clinical samples in suspected rabies cases.

questions.text:
A male patient, 42 years old, has jaundice. His ALT was 51 U, AST 48 U, ALP and GGTP were all within normal range. The liver's ultrasound suggested cirrhosis. Following the use of viral markers, the results were as follows. 
Test Result
Anti-HAV Negative
Anti-HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBeAg Negative
Anti-HBcAg lgG Positive
Anti-HBcAg lgM Negative
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HCV Positive
Anti-HEV Negative

What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Both the anti-HCV and anti-HBcAg IgG antibodies in this patient are positive.

Anti-HBcAg IgG positive in this case is only a sign of prior Hepatitis-B infection. Anti-HCV antibodies indicate the presence of a hepatitis-C infection.

In order to establish a diagnosis of Chronic Hepatitis-C prior to beginning Interferon therapy, HCV-RNA levels should be assessed by RT-PCR.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: During the autopsy of an AIDS patient, a lung segment was stained with hematoxylin and eosin to reveal type 1 pneumocyte desquamation with conspicuous intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies encircled by a clear halo. Before it died, the CD4 count was less than 100 cells/mm3. What is the diagnosis in this situation?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario of an immunocompromised individual with intra-nuclear basophilic inclusion bodies, the most likely diagnosis is CMV pneumonia. 

The major biological characteristic of CMV as with other herpes viruses is its ability to become latent in the human host and therefore, the potential for reactivation.

Drug of choice for CMV pneumonia is valganciclovir. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease secondary to polycystic kidney disease underwent a living donor kidney transplant 4 months ago. The patient is on immunosuppressive therapy (tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil).The patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for the past week. She also mentions a decrease in appetite and unintentional weight loss of about 5 pounds. On further examination , the patient's histopathological examination shows as given below. What is the most likely the root of this  infection?
questions.solution:
CMV is the most reasonable option out of the given choices considering that it is the most common type of infection in renal transplant recipients.
  • Prophylaxis against CMV infection is possible with ganciclovir, valganciclovir, or valacyclovir.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: In which year was the causative organism for AIDS identified?
questions.solution:
HIV virus was discovered in 1983, it was isolated from a patient with lymphadenopathy, and by 1984 it was demonstrated clearly to be the causative agent of AIDS.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 574.

questions.text: Postherpetic neuralgia is classified as pain lasting for more than:
questions.solution:
4 Weeks 

Post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN), which is defined as considerable pain or dysesthesia present 3 months or more after HZ, is the most typical side effect of HZ. 

It is the best answer since there are several criteria for defining PHN, but none of them result in a period of less than four weeks.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 220.

questions.text: In the T3 dermatome region of the trunk, a 60-year-old man is diagnosed with painful, clustered vesicles over erythematous plaques. Which of the following organisms are most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Varicella Zoster can recur in Immunocompromised elderly patients who have had Chickenpox in the past. This is called Shingles. It is characterised by Painful Vescicular rash ,Unilaterally present mostly, along a single dermatomal area.
Varicella Zoster virus (VZV) causes Zoster or shingles following reactivation of latent VZV, present in the trigeminal ganglia that occurs mainly in adult life. Vesicular rashes are painful, unilateral and segmental being confined to skin innervated by a single sensory ganglion.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 478.

choices.text: It is seen only in influenza virus type A
It is a result of frameshift mutation
It is responsible for seasonal epidemics of influenza

questions.text: Pick the option that is true about antigenic drift.
questions.solution:
Antigenic drift- involves the accumulation of a series of minor genetic mutations- point mutatiion- gradual change-causes endemics/ seasonal epidemics. Antigenic shift -mixing of genes from influenza viruses from different species casuing "reassortment" or frameshift mutation - sudden change- causes Pandemics.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 505.

questions.text: What is the correct diagnosis of a patient whose serum has positive HBsAg and HBeAg?
questions.solution:
Correct diagnosis of patient whose serum has positiveHBSAg a n d HBeAg is acute infective hepatitis.
The various viral antigen-antibody markers used in the diagnosis and monitoring of hepatitis infection include:

1. Hepatitis A IgM antibody: This antibody is present during the acute phase of hepatitis A infection, indicating recent infection.

2. Hepatitis B Surface Antigen (HBsAg): This is the first and most important marker for detecting active hepatitis B infection. If this antigen is present in the blood, it indicates the presence of the virus in the body.

3. Hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc): This antibody is produced in response to the core (interior) of the hepatitis B virus and indicates current or recent infection.

4. Hepatitis B e Antigen (HBeAg): The presence of this antigen in the blood suggests an active hepatitis B infection with high viral load and can be used to determine the need for treatment.

5. Hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs): This antibody indicates immunity to the virus, either due to past infection or vaccination.

6. Hepatitis C antibody (anti-HCV): This detects infection with the hepatitis C virus and can be used to diagnose the infection and monitor response to treatment.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

questions.text:
What is the primary cause of shingles?
A. Varicella-zoster
B. Herpes simplex
C. CMV
D. None
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Varicella-zoster

Reactivated varicella zoster infection is the primary cause of shingles. Varicella zoster lies dormant in the dorsal root ganglion of mainly trigeminal nerve which when activated manifests as shingles.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 478.

questions.text: For hepatitis B, the Australian antigen is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hb S ag

HbsAg is known as the Australian antigen. It is known so as it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian aboriginal person.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 547.

questions.text: Which enterovirus type is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Enterovirus-70 is the cause of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. It is characterised by rapid onset of severely painful conjunctivitis and subconjunctival haemorrhage.

Enterovirus 68- causes pneumonia.
• Enterovirus 70- causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.
• Enterovirus 71-causes aseptic meningitis encephalitis,
hand-foot and mouth disease, herpangina, pulmonary
edema and paralysis resembling poliomyelitis.
• Enterovirus 72 is reclassified as hepatitis A virus.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 499.

questions.text: Which species are more likely to cause infection after a kidney transplant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  CMV

CMV is the most common causative organism of infections post-organ transplantation. It is especially indicated in kidney transplant patients.
The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus. The most common cytomegalovirus presentation in kidney transplant patients are fever(common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia and arthralgia.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: The approximate period between contracting HIV and developing AIDS is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 10 yr 

The median time between primary HIV infection and the development of AIDS has been stated as approximately 10 years. It extends beyond 15 years in some cases and they’re known as long-term survivors.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 578.

questions.text: Which virus is responsible for genital warts?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Human papilloma

Genital warts are most commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11. Types 16 and 18 cause relatively serious disease which may progress to cancer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 566.

questions.text: Which mechanism does a virus or viral vector use to deliver foreign DNA into a cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Transduction

Transduction is known as the transfer of a portion of the DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.
Other options- Transcription – This is the process by which information in DNA is copied to RNA for the coding of proteins.
Lysogenic conversion- Here, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome as the prophage, which multiplies along with the host DNA and is transferred to the daughter cells.
Transformation- It is the process of transfer of genetic information through the agency of free DNA.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 59.

questions.text: Varicella zoster is still dormant in:
questions.solution:

Varicella zoster remains dormant in dorsal root ganglion and trigeminal ganglion. When reactivated, it causes shingles.

questions.text: What is the most common genital lesion in HIV patients?

questions.text: Select the Zika virus's vector.
questions.solution:
Zika virus is transmitted primarily by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito species, commonly known as the yellow fever mosquito and Asian tiger mosquito, respectively. These species are known to be primary vectors for Zika, meaning they can acquire the virus by feeding on an infected individual, and then transmit it to other individuals by biting. Additionally, Zika can be transmitted by sexual contact with an infected individual, through transfusion of contaminated blood, and from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy. Finally, laboratory-acquired Zika virus infections have been reported.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 660.

questions.text: Which of the following is not connected to HHV8
questions.solution:
HHV-8 does not cause T-cell leukemia. It's known to cause 1. Kaposi sarcoma 2. Primary effusion lymphoma 3. Castleman disease HTLV-1 is associated with Adult T-cell Leukemia.

questions.text: Choose the creature according to its life cycle:
questions.solution:
The given  life cycle of Influenza A virus. It  is divided into four distinct stages:

1. Attachment: Also known as the adsorption phase, this is the stage in which the influenza virus attaches to a suitable host cell. This is done through the influenza virus surface glycoproteins, haemagglutinin and neuraminidase.

2. Penetration: The virus then penetrates the host cell membrane and begins to uncoat, releasing its genetic material inside the host cell.

3. Replication: The virus then begins to express its enzymes, allowing it to replicate within the host cell and create daughter virus particles.

4. Release: In the final stage, the viral particles will spread and infect new cells, allowing the virus to continue to spread and accelerate infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 503.

questions.text: Pick the one which is incorrect about J.E.
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infectious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus which is primarily transmitted through the bites of Culex mosquitoes. These mosquitoes feed on infected birds, mammals and pigs, acting as the reservoirs for the virus. Humans are not reservoirs because they are dead-end or dead-cycle hosts for JE virus. This means that when a human is bitten by an infected mosquito, the virus will not reproduce in his/her body and can not be spread directly to other humans. Japanese encephalitis is also transmitted indirectly through contaminated food and water products, especially pork and poultry, due to the virus's presence in the salivary glands of pigs and birds. Thus, the indirect transmission of the virus is through the ingestion of insufficiently cooked contaminated animal products.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 527.

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of an HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300 cells/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen.
questions.solution:
The given image is of Oral Thrush(Candidiasis) which can be scrapped off and microscopy showing pseudohyphae confirms the diagnosis. HIV patients are at an increased risk of developing Candidiasis due to lower levels of CD4+ cells and/or antiretroviral therapy (ARV) treatments, which can lead to an overgrowth of the Candida fungus. The fungi can either cause infection when it enters through openings in the skin, or due to a weakened immune system, penetrate through mucosal surfaces and enter the bloodstream.

 

Signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients: The most common signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients are oral thrush (discolored patches in the mouth), as well as skin infections such as red/irritated rashes and itchy skin. In addition, HIV patients can experience persistent coughs, mucus production, and chest discomfort. Candidiasis can also lead to more severe issues such as meningitis and esophagitis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 616.

questions.text: Name the strain of influenza which got declared as pandemic in 2009.
questions.solution:
The H1N1 strain of influenza, also known as swine flu, was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) in June 2009. The declaration was made after the virus had spread rapidly around the world and began to cause significant levels of illness and death in many countries. The decision to declare it a pandemic was based on the fact that the virus had caused significant disruption in many countries and had been transmitted easily between people and between countries.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 509.

questions.text: Name the organism which causes reactivation d/s within 1-4 months after renal transplant surgery.
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a virus from the herpesvirus family that is associated with immunosuppression in people with HIV/AIDS and organ transplant recipients. CMV can cause cytopathic effects such as cytomegaly and nucleomegaly, as well as the formation of large intranuclear inclusions, which have an Owl’s eye appearance (Cowdry type A inclusion). These inclusions stain positively for PAS and GMS. CMV can be congenitally transmitted through the placenta or perinatally through cervical or vaginal secretions.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infections in post transplant patients?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. CMV (Cytomegalovirus).

Cytomegalovirus is the most common cause of infection in post-transplant patients due to immunosuppression required to prevent graft rejection. CMV infection can cause a wide range of complications, including pneumonitis, hepatitis, gastrointestinal disease, and CMV syndrome, which presents with fever, malaise, and leukopenia.

Other options

  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) but is not the most common post-transplant infection.
  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause shingles due to reactivation, but it is less common than CMV.
  • BK virus primarily affects renal transplant patients, leading to BK virus nephropathy, but it is not as common as CMV infection overall.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Identify which virus has the lifecycle listed below.
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is that of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). Steps of HSV replication cycle— 1. Binding to cell surface. 2. Entry after fusion of the membranes. 3. Capsid transport to the nucleus. 4. Transcription and translation. 5. Replication followed by capsid assembly. 6. Glycosylation 7. Glycoprotein export to the cell surface 8. Glycoprotein - containing plasma membrane endocytosis. 9. Envelopment : Glycoproteins within early endosomes fare with capsids in the cytoplasm. 10. Viral release.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases, once clinically evident, has the highest fatality rate?
questions.solution:

questions.text:
A patient admitted for COVID 19 was receiving oxygen assistance in critical care. After receiving steroids, she has since totally healed and is preparing for discharge.
