A. Nasal obstruction and discharge
B. Anosmia
C. Diplopia
D. Repeat RT-PCR positive
questions.solution:
Mucormycosis is a fungal infection that primarily affects persons who are taking medicine for other health issues that weakens their defences against microorganisms in the environment. 

When these people breathe in fungus spores from the air, their sinuses or lungs become infected. 

Occurs within three weeks of the start of Covid-19 symptoms. 

warning signs and symptoms: 

1. Pain in the face, the sinuses, the teeth, and the gums 

2. Paraesthesia, a loss of sensation in the upper half of the face. 

3. A blackish discoloration of the skin around the alae nasii/nasolabial groove. 

4. Nasal crusting and blood- or blackish-tinted nasal discharge. 

5. Chemosis or conjunctival injection. 

6. Swelling around the eyes. 

7. Diplopia or blurred eyesight. 

8. Teeth loosening, palate discoloration, and gangrenous inferior turbinates.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 614.

choices.text: Triad of SNHL, enamel hypoplasia and calcification in 20-30%
Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease
asymptomatic CMV have high risk of SNHL later

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (2).
Lets rule out the options.

  1. Triad of SNHL, enamel hypoplasia and calcification in 20-30%: . The classic triad associated with congenital CMV infection includes sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), microcephaly, and chorioretinitis, but not typically enamel hypoplasia. Enamel hypoplasia can occur, but it's not part of the classic triad.

  2. Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease: This is true. Mothers who have IgG antibodies (indicative of past infection) typically have a lower risk of transmitting CMV to their infants compared to those with a primary infection.

  3. Asymptomatic CMV have high risk of SNHL later: Asymptomatic congenital CMV infection can still be associated with a risk of developing SNHL later in life but not higher risk than symptomatic patients 

  4. Only 20-30% CMV infection is symptomatic:Most congenital CMV infections are asymptomatic, with symptomatic cases representing a smaller percentage (about 10-20%)

Hence, statement regarding CMV infection is (2) Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease is true.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with AIDS clinical stage 3?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 3:EBV causing oral Hairy Leukoplakia

  • According to the WHO clinical staging of HIV/AIDS, stage 3 is characterized by the presence of advanced symptomatic disease. One of the conditions associated with AIDS clinical stage 3 is oral hairy leukoplakia, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Oral hairy leukoplakia is a white, corrugated, and hyperkeratotic lesion that usually appears on the lateral borders of the tongue, but it can also affect other parts of the mouth. It is considered an indicator of severe immunosuppression and is often seen in people with HIV/AIDS. Therefore, option 3 is the correct answer.
  • Option 1, seizures due to toxoplasmosis, is associated with AIDS clinical stage 4.
  • Option 2, skeletal tuberculosis, is associated with AIDS clinical stage 4.
  • Option 4, esophageal candidiasis, is associated with AIDS clinical stage 4.

questions.text: All of the following are linked to EBV except ?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 4, MALT Lymphoma. EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) is a member of the herpesvirus family and is known to be associated with several types of cancers and diseases.
It is a common virus that infects most people at some point in their lives, usually causing mild symptoms or no symptoms at all.
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) and Hodgkin's lymphoma are two types of cancers that have a strong association with EBV.
Infectious mononucleosis, also known as glandular fever, is a viral infection caused by EBV. MALT (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that arises from lymphocytes in mucosal tissues such as the stomach, intestines, or lungs.

questions.text: How does the Epstein-Barr virus produce autoimmunity?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is thought to produce autoimmunity primarily through 1. Molecular Mimicry.

This mechanism occurs when the viral antigens resemble host tissues, leading to cross-reactivity of the immune response and potentially resulting in autoimmune conditions. However, EBV can also contribute to autoimmunity through 4. Polyclonal B cell Activation, as it stimulates B cells in a way that can lead to the production of autoantibodies. Both mechanisms are involved, but molecular mimicry is a key factor.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 481.

questions.text: What is Rabies vaccine encephalitis an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Molecular mimicry 

Molecular mimicry plays an important role in immune responses to infection and in autoimmune diseases. Infection may induce autoimmune responses which attack and destroy body tissues or organs. Normally, the body is tolerant to self-antigens which are present in individual tissues. Rabies vaccine encephalitis is a prime example of this.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 557.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered best for diagnosing HIV infection in a baby born to an HIV infected mother?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of HIV in a newborn baby born to an HIV-infected mother is done using a polymerase chain reaction. Antibody, ELISA are not used due to maternal transmission causing false-positivity.

Recommended testing:
  • HIV DNA or RNA PCR should be performed at birth, 1–2 months, and 4–6 months in high-risk infants.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made when two separate PCR tests are positive.

Other options:
 
  • Detection of HIV-antibodies in neonate: Not reliable because maternal HIV antibodies can cross the placenta and persist in the infant’s circulation for up to 18 months, even if the baby is not infected.
  • PCR: Detects HIV DNA or RNA and is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing HIV infection in neonates. It can identify the virus directly, even in the presence of maternal antibodies.
  • ELISA: Not suitable for neonates for the same reason as antibody detection — it primarily detects antibodies, which may be maternal in origin.
  • p24 antigen: Has lower sensitivity in neonates and is not as reliable as PCR for early diagnosis.


Reference: Essenrial Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: SARS-COV2 diagnosis can be done by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Southern blot is used for DNA detection and hence cannot be used for the detection of an RNA virus. Rest ( RT-PCR, Real-Time PCR, and Immunoassays) can be used for SARS-COV2 diagnosis. 
 

  • RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction): This is the most widely used and gold-standard method for diagnosing SARS-CoV-2. It detects viral RNA.

  • Real-Time PCR: A specific type of PCR that provides quantitative detection of viral RNA in real-time.

  • Immunoassays: These detect antibodies (serology) or antigens of SARS-CoV-2, commonly used for evaluating exposure or infection history.

  • Southern blot: This technique is used to detect DNA sequences, not RNA. Since SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus, Southern blot is not applicable for its diagnosis.




Reference: Freeman, Brandi et al. “Validation of a SARS-CoV-2 spike protein ELISA for use in contact investigations and serosurveillance.” bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology 2020.04.24.057323. 25 Apr. 2020, doi:10.1101/2020.04.24.057323. Preprint. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7239067/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1512.

4.
questions.solution:
• 1- Rotavirus
  • 2- Ebola virus
  • 3- Adenovirus
  • 4- Rabies virus

Rota virus is the virus that exhibits the genetic reassortment similar to that of an influenza virus.

The rotavirus genome is a segmented, double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genome, belonging to the family Reoviridae.
 

  • Segmented Genome:

    • Facilitates reassortment during co-infection with different rotavirus strains, contributing to genetic diversity.

  • Triple-Layered Capsid:

    • Protects the dsRNA genome from host immune responses and facilitates efficient replication and transmission.

  • Replication Factories (Viroplasms):

    • Host cell cytoplasmic structures where replication and assembly occur, avoiding detection by host defenses.

  • Cap-Independent Translation:

    • NSP3 competes with host translation factors, redirecting ribosomes to synthesize viral proteins.


Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 400, 401.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Henderson-Patterson bodies are characteristic to Molluscum contagiosum.
 
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), a poxvirus.
 
  • It is characterized histologically by the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies within the keratinocytes of the epidermis.
 
  • These inclusion bodies contain viral particles and are a hallmark of this infection.

Other options:
 
  1. Donovan bodies: Seen in Klebsiella granulomatis infections (granuloma inguinale).
  2. Halberstadter-Pravazek bodies: Found in Chlamydia trachomatis infections (trachoma or inclusion conjunctivitis).
  3. Negri bodies: Found in Rabies virus infections, located in the cytoplasm of neurons.



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 367, 733, 964, 1168.

questions.text: The oncogenes  of HPV are:
questions.solution:
The oncogenic HPVs encode accessory proteins: E4, E5, E6 and E7.
These proteins modulate the cellular environment to make it more conducive for viral replication, and are important for immune evasion.
 
  • The main oncogenes of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) are E6 and E7, which play a critical role in the pathogenesis of HPV-associated cancers, particularly cervical cancer.
 
  • These proteins disrupt key tumor suppressor pathways in the host:
    • E6: Binds to and promotes the degradation of p53, a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.
    • E7: Binds to and inactivates pRb (retinoblastoma protein), leading to uncontrolled cell cycle progression.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 647-650.

questions.text: Receptor for EBV ?
questions.solution:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) initiates infection of normal B lymphocytes by binding to CD21/CR2, a complement receptor.

Pathogenesis of EBV infection:
 

  1. Entry and Initial Infection:

    • EBV infects humans via saliva, targeting oropharyngeal epithelial cells and B cells.
    • It binds to CD21 (CR2) on B cells and integrins on epithelial cells.

  2. Viral Replication:

    • EBV undergoes lytic replication in epithelial cells, releasing virions that infect B cells.

  3. Latent Infection:

    • Establishes latency in memory B cells, expressing latency-associated proteins like EBNA1 and LMP1.
    • Different latency programs (I, II, III) influence disease outcomes and malignancy risk.

  4. Immune Response:

    • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) control infection, causing symptoms of infectious mononucleosis.
    • EBV evades immunity by reducing MHC expression and minimizing viral protein production.

  5. Persistent Infection:

    • EBV persists lifelong in latent form within memory B cells, with periodic reactivation.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 486.

questions.text: All of the following cause non-immune hydrops fetalis except?
questions.solution:
• Hydrops fetalis is a condition in which large amounts of fluid build up in a baby's tissues and organs, causing extensive swelling (edema).
  • HIV does not cause hydrops fetalis but rest all the given options do.

Causes of Non-immune Hydrops Fetalis:





Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 361.

questions.text: AIDS defining illness include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma, Cervical carcinoma, and Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma are Malignancies associated with HIV which are considered to be AIDS-defining in nature. HIV is also associated with other malignancies like Hodgkins, Melanoma etc. but they are not considered AIDS-defining illnesses. 





     Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 1581, 1527 .

questions.text: Serum markers in a person diagnosed as chronic hepatitis B are all except?
questions.solution:
• Anti HBs antibody is not a marker of chronic hepatitis B infection.
  • It is a marker of immunity to hepatitis B infection. It is produced in response to a hepatitis B vaccination or a patient who has recovered from a Hepatitis B infection and is now immune. 
  • A person with chronic hepatitis B will have HBsAg, Anti-HBC, and HBV DNA in their blood. They will not have Anti HBs antibodies in their blood.





 

 Reference : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 2571 table 339-2 .

questions.text:
Human papilloma virus infection can cause which of the following? 
(i) Cervical cancer 
(ii) Anal cancer
(iii) Oropharyngeal cancer 
(iv) Laryngeal papillomatosis
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus(HPV) infection can cause all of the following - Cervical cancer/Anal cancer/Oropharyngeal cancer/Laryngeal papillomatosis. It can also cause vulval/penile cancer. 



 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 998,818,735,743 .

questions.text: In which airborne disease is isolation recommended to prevent the spread?
questions.solution:
Isolation precautions are recommended for the prevention of the spread of airborne diseases that are highly contagious and can easily spread through the air. Among the given options, Measles is an airborne disease for which isolation is recommended to prevent its spread.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 132,159-161 .

choices.text: Pneumocystis prophylaxis is mandatory if CD4 count <200
Mycobacterium Avium prophylaxis is mandatory if CD4 count <50
Cytomegalovirus prophylaxis is mandatory if CD4 count is <50

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement regarding chemoprophylaxis in HIV positive patients?
questions.solution:
The wrong statement regarding chemoprophylaxis in HIV-positive patients is:

  1. Pneumocystis prophylaxis is only given if CD4 count >200

The correct approach is to provide pneumocystis prophylaxis when the CD4 count is below a certain threshold, not only when it is above a specific value. Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) prophylaxis is typically recommended when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/mm³ or when the patient has a history of previous PCP infection. Therefore, option 4 is the incorrect statement.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1563,1565,1566,1567 .

questions.text:
Which among the following virus can undergo genetic reassortment like the influenza virus? 

1. 


2. 

3. 


4.
questions.solution:
Among the given options - only 1 has a segmented genome capable of reassortment. Image 1 shows segmented ds RNA of rotavirus. 
The following viruses show genetic reassortment:
1. Arenavirus
2. Rotavirus
3. Reovirus
4. Bunyavirus
5. Orthomyxo virus


Reference : Jawetz Melnick, & Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology , 28th Edition, Page no 400,401 .

choices.text: Maximum dose is given in deltoid muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Rabies immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about Rabies immunoglobulin is: 20 IU/kg dose is given.

Rabies immunoglobulin is given along with the rabies vaccine to provide passive immunity against the rabies virus after exposure. The dose of Rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU/kg body weight(HRIG, the dose is 40IU/kg for equine). It should be administered at the site of the bite and infiltrated into the wound as much as possible. If the full dose cannot be infiltrated, the remaining volume should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine administration.

The other statements mentioned are incorrect:

  1. Rabies immunoglobulin is most effective when given as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 24 hours. However, it can still be beneficial even if administered later up to 7 days. 

  2. The maximum dose of Rabies immunoglobulin is not given in the deltoid muscle. It is usually infiltrated into the wound or administered intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine administration.

  3. Human Rabies immunoglobulin is preferred over equine immunoglobulin due to its lower risk of anaphylaxis.


    Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 305-306 .

questions.text: Which among the following is true about WHO-SAGE criteria HPV vaccination in 9-14 years of age?
questions.solution:
WHO recommends: A one or two-dose schedule for girls aged 9-14 years. A one or two-dose schedule for girls and women aged 15-20 years. Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21 years.


 

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd Edition, Page no 630 .

questions.text: Which of the following is used to diagnose Rotavirus?
questions.solution:
• Antigen detection in stool using ELISA/ ICT is a useful test for the detection of Rotavirus infection.
  • VP6 epitopes are the most commonly detected Rotavirus antigens.
  • Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 month of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low grade, fever and temporary lactulose Intolerance.
  • The Antigen enzyme immunoassays and PCRs are used for genotyping of rotavirus nucleic acids from stool specimens.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 546.

questions.text: A patient from Delhi presented with high grade fever, and petechiae. CBC report shows a WBC count of 3,000; platelet count is 20,000. The Hb is 11g/ dL. Bleeding time is increased while coagulation time is normal. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
A febrile patient from North India with bleeding manifestations of petechiae, with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia in the presence of a near-normal Hb with increased bleeding time and normal coagulation profile, indicating a quantitative platelet defect, most likely has dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Aedes aegypti is the principal vector followed by Aedes albopictus. They bite during the day time.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 509.

Reference: Hadinegoro SR. The revised WHO dengue case classification: does the system need to be modified? Paediatr Int Child Health. 2012 May;32 Suppl 1(s1):33-8. doi: 10.1179/2046904712Z.00000000052. PMID: 22668448; PMCID: PMC3381438.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Herpes Encephalitis on MRI. Which investigation should be done next?
questions.solution:
• In this patient with encephalitis, a provisional diagnosis of herpes encephalitis is based on neuroimaging by MRI.
  • The gold standard for establishing the diagnosis is the detection of herpes simplex virus DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
  • The T2 weighted MRI of the brain will show Hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in the most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.
  • Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephaliis. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1095.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with headache, high-grade fever and features suggestive of encephalitis. Bilateral temporal hemorrhages are seen. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
A 25-year old female presents with infectious encephalitis with findings of bilateral temporal hemorrhages.

  • The clue to the etiology arises from the affinity of the pathogen for the temporal lobes, as they are affected bilaterally and there is extensive destruction progressing to hemorrhage.
This correlates most closely with the presentation of HSV-encephalitis, usually caused by HSV-1. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 451.

questions.text: A child presented with a rash, a few days after the onset of fever. The child also has a cough and coryza. On examination of buccal mucosa, Koplik’s spots were seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Koplik’s spots are pathognomonic of measles, and thus, the child is affected by measles virus, an RNA virus, belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family.

Koplik's spots are pathognomonic of measles, appear after two days following fever (i.e. on 12th day of infection) and are characterized by:
  • White to bluish spot (1 mm size) surrounded by an erythema
  • Appear first on buccal mucosa near second lower molars.
  • Rapidly spread to involve the entire buccal mucosa and then fade with the onset of rash.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 485.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms require the use of reverse transcriptase in PCR?
questions.solution:
Among the given viruses, Reverse transcriptase is required by RNA virus, respiratory Synctial virus -RSV is the only RNA virus among the options given.
RSV is linear , single stranded non segmented virus.



Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page. No: 453, 460.

questions.text: Which of the following helps Human Immunodeficiency virus to penetrate the host cell?
questions.solution:
HIV virus can penetrate host' CD4+ cells with the help of Gp120 also known as spike antigen . Spike antigen is present in the envelope of the virus.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 248.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has the least teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Herpes Simplex Virus - has the least teratogenic effect as transplacental route of spread is uncommon.
Caesarean delivery is recommended in cases with active Primary Genital HSV infections.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th Edition, Page No- 480.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and drowsiness. He later developed dizziness and altered consciousness. His mother reports that he had consumed palm fruit on their recent trip to Kerala and has not been feeling well since then. Keeping the patient's history in mind, which of the following viruses should be considered in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nipah virus infection is a zoonotic disease caused by a Paramyxovirus (genus Henipavirus).

  • It is endemic in Kerala, India, and outbreaks are often linked to consumption of raw date palm sap or fruit contaminated with bat saliva or urine.

  • The reservoir host is the fruit bat (Pteropus species).

  • Clinical features:

    • Initial: Fever, headache, myalgia, and drowsiness

    • Progression: Dizziness, disorientation, and altered consciousness due to encephalitis

    • Severe cases may show respiratory distress or coma

  • Mode of transmission: From bats → humans via contaminated fruit/palm sap, or human-to-human through respiratory secretions.

Differential Exclusions:

  • Ebola virus: Seen in Africa; causes hemorrhagic fever, not associated with palm fruit consumption.

  • Dengue virus: Causes high fever and hemorrhagic manifestations, no encephalitis or palm fruit link.

  • Chikungunya virus: Causes fever and severe joint pain, no CNS involvement.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with:

  • “Slapped cheek” erythema on the face

  • Rash spreading to trunk and limbs

  • Low-grade fever and mild URI symptoms

  • Age: 3 years

These features are classic for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by Parvovirus B19, a single-stranded DNA virus.

Key points:

  • Incubation period: 4–14 days

  • Transmission: Respiratory droplets

  • Complications: Transient aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic anemia; hydrops fetalis in pregnant women

Other options:

  • Scarlet fever: Caused by Streptococcus pyogenes; diffuse fine sandpaper-like rash with circumoral pallor; not a DNA virus.

  • Rubeola (measles): Caused by measles virus, an RNA virus; presents with Koplik spots and cephalocaudal rash.

  • Exanthema subitum (Roseola infantum): Caused by HHV-6/7 (DNA virus); high fever for 3–5 days, followed by truncal rash, usually in 6–24 months age group.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is erythema infectiosum (Parvovirus B19 infection).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical manifestation of Parvovirus B19 infection?
questions.solution:
• Charecterstic rash seen in Parvovirus infection is Erythematous rash and not petechial rash.
  • Parvovirus is smallest single stranded and non enveloped DNA virus.
  • Clinical manifestations include-
  1. Erythema Infectiousum,
  2. Arthropathy,
  3. Aplastic crisis,
  4. Pure red cell aplasia and
  5. Hydrops fetalis.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 558-559.

questions.text:
Match the following
1.Hepatitis C virus A.Double stranded DNA virus
2.Rota virus B.Single-stranded DNA
3.Human papilloma virus C.Double-stranded RNA virus
4.Parvovirus D.Single stranded RNA virus
questions.solution: Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 446.

questions.text:
Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period.
Column I Column II
1 Hepatitis A a 10 days
2 Chickenpox b 90 days
3 SARS c 21 days
4 Syphillis d 50 days
questions.solution:
The incubation period is the duration between the entry of an infectious agent into the body and the onset of the first symptoms or signs.

For syphilis, the incubation period ranges from 10 to 90 days and is inversely related to the size of the Spirochaete inoculum.

SARS infection typically has an incubation period of 5 to 10 days.

Hepatitis A infection has an incubation period ranging from 10 to 50 days, with a common range of 14 to 28 days.

Chickenpox, caused by the varicella zoster virus (HSV-3), has an incubation period of 10 to 21 days.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 379,477,563 .

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis viruses is likely to get transmitted via feco-oral route?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

In contrast, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and Hepatitis D can be transmitted through sexual contact, as well as via blood-to-blood contact and other body fluids.

questions.text: The image shown here is used for the diagnosis of
questions.solution:
The Tzanck smear is a rapid diagnostic method primarily used for the diagnosis of Herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Key Features of Tzanck Cells:
Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei.
The nuclei exhibit ground-glass chromatin with a homogenous appearance.


Procedure for Tzanck Smear:
Cytological examination of skin blisters: After the blister is ruptured, the floor is scraped and the material is transferred onto a slide.
The slide is then stained using Giemsa, Wright's stain, or toluidine blue and examined microscopically.

Other Conditions Diagnosed by Tzanck Smear:
Hailey-Hailey disease
Darier's disease
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease
This test is a useful tool in quickly identifying viral infections like HSV based on characteristic cellular features.

questions.text: A retro positive individual presented with cough fever and pneumonitis. His urine examination showed basophilic inclusion bodies. Which of the following is the causative organism
questions.solution:
The following image shows characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as an owl's eye appearance which is seen in cytomegalovirus infection.
CMV is the largest virus in the herpes family of viruses. It causes the following conditions:
• Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection such as fever and rash
• Neonates - devastating systemic infections
• Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-
threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis). Ref -Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition • Page no: 479, 480-481, 474-475

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with primary effusion lymphoma. Which of the following is the causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) is a rare B-cell lymphoma presenting as lymphomatous effusions in body cavities without a solid tumor mass.

  • It is strongly associated with HHV-8 infection (also called Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus).

  • Most cases occur in immunocompromised patients, especially HIV-positive individuals.

Other options:

  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Predisposes to PEL by causing immunosuppression, but not the direct causative agent.

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV): Associated with cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers, not PEL.

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): May co-infect some PEL cases, but HHV-8 is the primary causative agent.


Reference
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition - Page no. 473, 478, 479, 481, 483

questions.text: A male patient presents with hydrophobia, tearing, and altered sensorium after a dog bite. You suspect rabies in this patient and take corneal scrapings to confirm the same. What test is performed to obtain the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Rabies is suspected in a patient with hydrophobia, altered sensorium, and history of animal bite.

  • Corneal or skin biopsies can be used for laboratory confirmation.

  • Reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) is the most sensitive and specific test:

    • Detects viral RNA directly from corneal scrapings, saliva, or cerebrospinal fluid.

    • Allows early and accurate diagnosis before death.

Other options:

  • Antibodies against rabies virus: Appear late in disease, not reliable for early diagnosis.

  • Histopathological examination for Negri bodies: Classical finding in neurons, but low sensitivity and usually postmortem.

  • Indirect immunofluorescence: Can detect viral antigens in tissue but less sensitive than RT-PCR.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition, Page 1302.

questions.text: Healthcare workers should be vaccinated against
questions.solution:
Healthcare personnel (HCWs) ought to receive vaccinations against Hepatitis B, since biomedical waste management is a typical way for the virus to spread. It is advised to have yearly physical examinations, with booster shots offered if needed.

HBV post-exposure prophylaxis:

When the source patient's status regarding Hepatitis B is uncertain, the healthcare worker should handle the patient as though they were HBsAg-positive.

In the event that the source patient has HBV:

In case HCWs do not respond to one round of HBV vaccination, give them 0.06 ml/kg of HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) as soon as feasible, preferably in less than 24 hours. Restart the HBV immunization series at the same time as three doses of the hepatitis B vaccine.

For healthcare workers who do not respond to two doses of HBV vaccination: Give HBIG 0.06 ml/kg as quickly as you can, ideally within

Reference
Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition - Page no: 830

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture suggests Erythema infectiosum (also known as Fifth disease), caused by Parvovirus B19, which is a single-stranded DNA virus.

Key features:

  • Age group: Common in 3–10 years

  • Prodrome: Low-grade fever, headache, malaise, mild upper respiratory symptoms

  • Rash:

    • Begins with "slapped cheek" appearance (bright red rash on the cheeks)

    • Followed by a lace-like erythematous rash on the trunk and limbs

    • Rash may wax and wane with temperature, sun exposure, etc.

  • Virus: Parvovirus B19, a non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus

    Other options:

  1. Rubeola (Measles)

    • Caused by: Measles virus (RNA virus)

    • Features: High fever, Koplik spots, confluent maculopapular rash starting behind ears and spreading down

    • Not associated with "slapped cheek"

  2. Exanthema subitum (Roseola infantum)

    • Caused by: HHV-6 (double-stranded DNA virus)

    • Features: High fever for 3–5 days → sudden drop in fever → rash appears

    • Age: Common in <2 years

  3. Scarlet fever

    • Caused by: Group A Streptococcus (bacteria)

    • Features: Sandpaper rash, strawberry tongue, pharyngitis

    • Rash begins in groin/axilla, not on face first


Reference:Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 9th edition page no 558

questions.text: Condyloma Accuminata is most commonly caused by __.
questions.solution:
Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are benign exophytic (outward-growing) lesions that typically appear in the genital and perianal regions. These warts are caused by infection with the Human Papillomavirus (HPV), a DNA virus that infects epithelial tissues.

Among the more than 100 types of HPV identified, types 6 and 11 are most commonly responsible for condyloma acuminata. These two types are classified as low-risk HPV types because they are not typically associated with malignant transformation or cancer. They lead to benign growths like genital warts, respiratory papillomatosis, and other non-cancerous epithelial lesions.

These lesions usually appear as soft, skin-colored or pink, cauliflower-like growths. They can vary in size and may be asymptomatic, or they may cause itching, burning, or discomfort depending on their size and location.

While HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk types associated with cervical cancer and other anogenital or oropharyngeal cancers, they are not the usual cause of condyloma acuminata. Similarly, types like 31 and 33 are also high-risk, oncogenic strains associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cancer, but not typically with benign warts.

Because of the strong link between HPV 6 and 11 and condyloma acuminata, the prophylactic HPV vaccines (such as Gardasil 9) include coverage against these types. The vaccine not only helps prevent cervical and other cancers (from high-risk types like 16, 18) but also protects against genital warts caused by types 6 and 11.



Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 25.56-25.58

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling and his jaw is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• 12-year-old boy

  • Fever, ear pain

  • Difficulty in swallowing

  • Testicular swelling (orchitis)

  • Jaw swelling (image likely shows parotid swelling)

The most likely diagnosis is Mumps, a viral illness caused by the Mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It typically affects unvaccinated children and adolescents.

Key Features of Mumps:

  • Parotitis: Classically presents with painful swelling of the parotid glands, located near the angle of the jaw, giving the characteristic “hamster face” or chipmunk-like appearance.

  • Ear pain: Due to parotid gland inflammation near the ear.

  • Difficulty swallowing (odynophagia): Due to salivary gland swelling.

  • Orchitis: Testicular inflammation, especially in adolescent males. It may follow parotitis by a few days and is a hallmark complication.

  • Fever: Common constitutional symptom.

Mumps can also affect:

  • Pancreas – causing pancreatitis

  • CNS – leading to aseptic meningitis or encephalitis

  • Ovaries – oophoritis in females (rare)

    Why other options are incorrect:

  1. Herpangina:

    • Caused by Coxsackie A virus.

    • Presents with vesicles and ulcers on the posterior oropharynx, high fever, sore throat — no parotid or testicular involvement.

  2. Croup:

    • Caused by parainfluenza virus.

    • Characterized by barking cough, stridor, and respiratory distress — not parotid or testicular swelling.

  3. Infectious mononucleosis:

    • Caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

    • Presents with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, but not testicular or parotid swelling.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1483

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease lasting a few days at a time, leaving slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and a diagnosis of Mollaret's meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent meningitis (multiple episodes over years)

  • Short duration, but neurological sequelae (visual/memory loss)

  • CSF: Lymphocytic pleocytosis

  • Diagnosis: Mollaret’s meningitis

    Mollaret’s Meningitis:

  • A rare, benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis

  • Classically caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2)

  • Episodes resolve spontaneously in a few days

  • May present with headache, fever, neck stiffness, and sometimes neurological deficits

  • No bacterial growth, but HSV DNA may be detected by PCR in CSF

    Other Options – Incorrect:

  1. Mumps virus – Can cause viral meningitis, but usually non-recurrent

  2. Measles virus – Causes subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), not recurrent meningitis

  3. Rubella virus – Associated with congenital rubella syndrome, not recurrent meningitis


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1350

questions.text: What medication is prescribed  for Pneumo-cystis jirovecii infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cotrimoxazole

Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for the prevention and treatment of pneumocystis jirovecii infections. Pentamidine isethionate can also be used alternatively. It is also the DOC in the prophylaxis of HIV-affected individuals.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 618.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be identified by the 1,3-beta D-glucan assay?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Invasive cryptococcosis

Cryptococcus is a unicellular yeast. It is devoid of the cell wall polysaccharide 1,3-b-D-glucan and hence gives a negative result.

Memorizing Trick of 1,3-b-D-glucan test positive : - CAP
Candidiasis 
Aspergillosis
Pneumocystis carnii

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 384.

questions.text: Which of the following groups does Rhinosporidium Seeberi belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Aquatic protistan protozoa

It neither belongs to the class of fungi nor bacteria. It comes under the class of fish pathogens and is best classified as aquatic protistan protozoa.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 607.

questions.text: Multiple discharge-producing cervical sinuses are seen in a 35-year-old farmer man. Which one of these stains will help with the diagnosis? Normally, where does this organism colonise the body?"
questions.solution:
Audio explanation of the above.


  

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 398.

questions.text: A patient arrived with a headache, projectile vomiting, and altered sensorium. The parasite that caused the India ink staining was shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An India Ink-stained cryptococcus capsule is depicted in the diagram above. Both nigrosin and mucicar­mine are alternative staining techniques.
Cryptococcus neoformans:
Causes Cryptococcal cryptococcosis.
Encapsulated.
Not dimorphic.
Found in soil, pigeon droppings
Acquired through inhalation with hematogenous dissemination to meninges.
Culture on sabouraud agar.
Stains with India Ink and mucicarmine.
Latex agglutination test detects polysaccharide capsular
antigen and is more specific.
'Soap bubble' lesions in the brain.
C. neoformans grows as yeast (unicellular) and replicates by budding.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: A child had scaly plaques on his head, itching, minor discharge, and hair loss. What investigation should be carried out next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: KOH mount

Scaly plaques on the head along with itching, minor discharge and hair loss are indicative of dermatophytosis. The investigation of choice, in this case, is KOH mount.
Other options – Gram stain is used for bacteria.
Slit skin preparation is used for Hansen’s disease.
Tzanck smear is used for viral infections and the pemphigus group of diseases.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 600.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to the dimorphic fungi group?
questions.solution:
Dimorphic fungi have two growth forms that emerge under various development circumstances, such as a mould and a yeast.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus closely related to ascomycetes, not a dimorphic fungus.

Dimorphic fungi include:
• Blastomyces dermatitidis
• Coccidioides immitis
• Coccidioides posadasii
• Histoplasma capsulatum

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 593.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA)

questions.text:
A known seropositive patient presented with complaints of severe intractable diarrhea. He received care using the medication trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His stool examination revealed Isospora Belli. 
The fever remained, but the diarrhea stopped. Examination of the bone marrow revealed the following image of an intracellular fungus:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this fungus?
questions.solution:
It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) is a wrong statement for this fungus.

An HIV positive patient's presence of intracellular fungus on bone marrow examination (in tissues) is strongly predictive of disseminated histoplasmosis brought on by Histoplasma capsulatum. Specimens are cultivated on rich media, such as SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) or IMA Inhibitory Mold Agar) at 25–30°C, and on glucose–cysteine blood agar at 37°C.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 610.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given shows septate hyphae, with acute angle branching suggestive of Aspergillus.

Aspergillus hyphae are hyaline, narrow, and septate, with branching at 45° (acute angle branching).

So, it is Acute angle branching aspergillus.

Note- Mucor will show broad ribbon like aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text:
A female from Himachal Pradesh who had experienced thorn pricks a year prior presented with verrucous lesions in the skin and the microscopic
results listed below. Identify the agent.
questions.solution:
History of thorn prick and the image showing sclerotic bodies also known as medlar bodies or copper penny bodies; is highly suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

The methods of conidiation are used to distinguish the chromoblastomycosis agents.

In tissue, they resemble one another and produce muriform or sclerotic bodies, which are spherical brown cells (4–12 um in diameter) that divide by transverse septation. A cluster of four to eight cells could form as a result of delayed separation and septation in several planes.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605.

questions.text: What can be identified from 1,3-beta-D-glucan?
questions.solution:
1,3-beta-D-glucan is helpful for identification of invasive candidiasis.

Most fungi have 1-3-Beta-D-glucan (BG) as part of their cell walls. The primary exceptions are cryptococci and the Mucorales (Rhizopus, Mucor, and Absidia), which don't emit enough BG to be seen in human serum.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 384.

questions.text: With a fever, neck ache, and vomiting, a 40-year-old HIV-positive patient was brought to the emergency room. He eventually passed away, and the micrograph and autopsy image of his brain are displayed here along with staining. Which pathogen is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

Given clinical features are suggestive of meningitis  in HIV pt. The organism responsible is cryptococcus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: The pap smear below reveals an infestation by:
questions.solution:
The given pap smear shows Actinomycetes.Identified cytologically as ball-like clusters of bacteria, with radiating filaments. • ‘Cotton-ball’ clusters: Tangled clump of filamentous organisms, with acute angle branching • Radial distribution of filaments or irregular ‘wooly body’ appearance (also known as “Gupta bodies”) • Inflammatory perinuclear halo may be seen. • Masses of leukocytes adherent to micro-colonies of the organisms with swollen filaments or ‘clubs’ at the periphery.

Other options: -
1. Candida- will show ger tube formation
2. HSV- Multinucleated giant cells mainly in Tzanck smear
3. Trichomonas- pear shaped cells with lancet nucleus seen.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 400.

questions.text: Pick the option that is a special stain used to diagnose fungal hyphae in tissues?
questions.solution:
Gomori's methenanime silver stain is used to diagnose fungal hyphae in tissues. 

Option B- Masson trichome is used to visualize collagen and muscles.

Option C- Congo red stain is used for amyloid protein. 

Option D- Alcian Blue is used to demonstrate acid mucin. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596.

questions.text:
In individuals with diabetic ketoacidosis, what fungal species is most frequently linked to orbital cellulitis?
1. Candida spp.
2. Mucor spp.
3. Aspergillus spp.
4. Rhizopus spp.
questions.solution:
Trick question

The most common orbital fungal infection in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis is mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is caused by fungi in the order of Mucorales, of which Rhizopus species is the most common. (Mucormycosis is the most common infection but the most common species causing mucormycosis is Rhizopus oryzae, not Mucor.)
(Name of the infection is mucormycosis - the most common species is not Mucor but Rhizopus)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 614.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is experiencing pain, edema, and bloody nasal discharge. The periorbital pus culture revealed branching septate hyphae. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Aspergillus The condition describes invasive aspergillosis. Aspergillus has branching, septate hyphae and is most commonly indicated in infections of DM patients. It is also quite common in immunocompromised. Other options – Candida has pseudohyphae and both rhizopus and mucor have aseptate hyphae.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612.

questions.text: A young woman has had bilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and recurrent rhinitis for one year. Moreover, she had a history of allergies and asthma. Multiple polyps, mucosal thickness, and impacted secretions can all be detected in the nasal cavities upon examination. Following a biopsy, cultured material revealed many hyphae with dichotomous branching that was often at a 45-degree angle. Which of the following organisms is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Aspergillus

The given case scenario is of invasive aspergillosis. It is caused by aspergillus species which is septate and has dichotomous branching at 45-degree angle.
Other options – Mucor branches at the right angle. Candida and Rhizopus aren’t indicated in nasal infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612.

questions.text: Choose the one caused due to traumatic inoculation.
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii is a thermally dimorphic fungi known to cause a chronic fungal infection called sporotrichosis. It is most commonly found in gardeners through infection with a rose prick, therefore called rose gardener's disease. The incubation period for this infection is usually between 1-3 weeks. A sample of the fungus can be examined under a microscope and will show an asteriod body when observed with a KOH/HE solution, or cigar-shaped bodies on tissue sections. Immunohistochemical staining can show a Splendore-Hoppli phenomenon which is an immune complex deposition around the organism. In addition, the mycelial form of the fungi shows a 'flowerlike pattern.' To test for this infection, skin tests involving Sporotrichin or peptido-rhamno-mannan antigen can be used. It spreads through lymphatic route this lesions are spaced and linear in distribution, this pattern is known as Sporotrichoid pattern. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is applied to tissue sections to study fungal morphology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: PAS 

Periodic acid Schiff staining is used to study fungal morphology.
Other options- Von Kossa- Used to stain calcium deposits in tissue sections.
Masson’s trichome- Used to stain collagen fibres.
Alizarin red- Used to stain calcium containing cells and tissues.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596.

questions.text: Identify the exception to  1,3 Beta D glucan testing:
questions.solution:
For mucormycosis, beta 1-3 glucan assay test is not used to make a diagnosis.
(1-3)-d glucan (BDG), an abundant cell wall polymer is present in most fungi with the exception of:
  • Zygomycetes
  • Blastomyces dermatidis
  • Cryptococci
Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes (Rhizopus and Mucor) that don't make (1-3)- -d-glucan. Therefore, it cannot be diagnosed with the beta 1-3 glucan assay test.

Memorizing Trick of 1,3-b-D-glucan test positive : - CAP
Candidiasis 
Aspergillosis
Pneumocystis carnii


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 384.

questions.text: Which layer of the fungal cell wall is missing in mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
In patients suspected of having an invasive fungal infection, serum tests like the 1,3-beta-D-glucan assay and the Aspergillus galactomannan assay are being used more frequently. 
Both tests come back negative in patients with mucormycosis because the agents that cause the disease do not share these cell wall components.

Memorizing Trick of 1,3-b-D-glucan test positive : - CAP
Candidiasis 
Aspergillosis
Pneumocystis carnii


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 388.

questions.text: After a dental procedure, a patient exhibits swelling and lump formation in the submandibular region. There are yellow particles in the discharge. Below is a picture of gram stain. What pathogen is to blame for this disease
questions.solution:
The condition is a chronic granulomatous infection that affects both humans and animals. The growth of indurated swellings, mostly in the connective tissue, suppuration, and the ejection of "sulphur granules" are its defining features. The granules are actually bacterial colonies, and they have the appearance of sun rays due to their thick network of thin, Gram-positive filaments and peripheral zone of inflated, radiating, club-shaped structures. It is thought that the "clubs" are antigen-antibody complexes. Characteristics of Actinomyces species identification: Bacilli that are gram-positive. Bacilli that are nonmotile, non sporing, and acid-fast. Create colonies with molar-tooth shapes. The direct fluorescent antibody test and the gel immunodiffusion test are used to identify species. Microaerophilic or anaerobic conditions are preferable for facultative anaerobe growth with the addition of 5-10% CO2.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 604.

choices.text: Dichotomous branching at an acute angle; Aspergillus

questions.text:
A persistent smoker who also has pneumonitis and hypertension visits the OPD
He has a persistent cough, and fungal hyphae are visible when examining sputum after staining.
Which branching pattern is present and likely fungus?
questions.solution:
1. Aspergillus infection is the cause of the patient's condition. 

Aspergillus infection is characterized by typical dichotomous branching at acute angles. 

Several clinical syndromes can be brought on by Aspergillus species: 

  • Aspergillus bronchopulmonary allergy 
  • Aspergilloma
  • Invasive aspergillosis 
  • External ear superficial infections (otomycosis)
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal species is dematiaceous
questions.solution:
Dematiaceous moulds contain melanin in their hyphae walls. Eg : Madurella, Piedra, Cladosporium.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605.

questions.text:
Where is galactomannan seen in serum?
A. Invasive aspergillosis
B. Systemic candidiasis
C. Mucormycosis
D. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Galactomannan in serum is seen only in invasive aspergillosis. It is a component of cell wall of Aspergillus and can be detected in serum as well as in bronchoalveolar lavage.

Diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis-

Positive culture from the affected organ
Detection of galactomannan antigen.
On microscopic examination, narrow acute angle branching septate hyphae
Halo and reverse halo sign on CT.
Drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis is voriconazole.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: A patient complained of having trouble swallowing. The diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made during a UGI endoscopy. The organism that was collected from the sample was cultivated on a specific medium, and the culture's microscope revealed the findings listed below. The phenomenon depicted below is what?
questions.solution:
After incubating colonies of Candida albicans or Candida dubliniensis in serum at 37°C for between 60 to 90 minutes, the image demonstrates the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon occurring in the form of germ tube formation. This is a rapid way of identifying C. albicans.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: Following a work-related prick injury, a rose gardener had the following alterations to their skin. What might be the causing factor?
questions.solution:
The given image is showing nodulo - ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics suggestive of sporotrichosis( Rose gardener’s disease) caused by Sporothrix Schenkii. Infection arises following traumatic implantation of the fungus (rose prick). H & E shows cigar shaped yeast arranged in structures called asteroid bodies. Culture reveals hyaline septate molds at 25°C - 28°C, dimorphism can be proved by yeast conversion test.

Treatment : Itraconazole.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: As seen in the figure below, a patient presents with linear lesions and subcutaneous lymphatic spread. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is sporotrichosis.

The image shown is of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. At the site of cutaneous inoculation, generally in the distal upper extremities, the main lesion manifests.
After a few weeks, fresh lesions start to develop along the lymphatic pathways, resulting in the linear lesions as seen in the image.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: A sub-Himalayan farmer arrives to the hospital with several leg ulcers. The cause most likely to be responsible is:
questions.solution:
Most likely causative agent is sporothrix schenkii.

Diagnostic features of sporotrichosis caused by  sporothrix schenkii is presence of multiple ulcers in leg along with lymphatic channels in a outdoor worker (like farmer) from the sub-himalayan region.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: Identify the Candida species that has the highest level of resistance against fluconazole.
questions.solution:
The Candida species that has the highest level of resistance against fluconazole is 4. Candida krusei.

Candida krusei is known for its intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, making it less susceptible compared to other species like Candida albicans, Candida glabrata, and Candida tropicalis.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 616.

questions.text: Fever, jaundice, and conjunctival hyperemia are observed in a farmer who has been working in a rice field with bare feet in standing water. Which of the following serological tests must be done to determine the condition's cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Microscopic agglutination test

The given features are suggestive of Weil’s disease caused by Leptospira. Among the given options, the Microscopic agglutination test is the appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Leptospirosis can present with a wide range of symptoms, from mild flu-like illness to severe manifestations such as jaundice, renal failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
    • Symptoms typically appear 5-14 days after exposure to the bacteria (Leptospira spp.).

  • Risk Factors and History:

    • Patients with a history of exposure to contaminated water (e.g., floodwaters, recreational activities in lakes or rivers), contact with animals (especially rodents, livestock), or occupations involving such exposures (e.g., farmers, sewage workers) are at higher risk.
    • A detailed history of travel, activities, and animal contact is important for clinical suspicion.

  • Laboratory Tests:

    • Serology: Serological tests are commonly used for diagnosis. These include enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), microscopic agglutination test (MAT), and indirect hemagglutination assay (IHA). These tests detect antibodies (IgM and IgG) produced in response to Leptospira infection.
    • PCR: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays can detect Leptospira DNA in blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) during the early phase of illness, typically within the first week of symptoms.
    • Culture: Culture of Leptospira bacteria from blood or urine is challenging and less commonly used due to slow growth and technical requirements.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 390.

questions.text: Gram-stained periorbital exudates from a diabetic elderly patient with severe panophthalmitis and cellulitis show irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Apophysomyces sp
  • Apophysomyces sp. Is known to cause infection in immunocompromised individuals. Although, 80% of mucormycosis is caused by Rhizopus and Mucor, Apophysomyces is on the rise. Also, it is different from the above two in being aseptate.
  • Other options- Candida is a pseudohyphae.
  • Aspergillus and Pencillium are septate.
  • The given scenario describes a case of severe panophthalmitis and cellulitis in an elderly diabetic patient.
  • Gram-stained periorbital exudates from the patient show irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae.
  • Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis is Apophysomyces sp.
  • Apophysomyces is a type of fungus that belongs to the order Mucorales. It is commonly found in soil and decaying organic matter. Apophysomyces infections are rare but can be life-threatening, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with diabetes.
  • The fungus can invade blood vessels, leading to tissue necrosis and rapid deterioration of the affected area.
  • The characteristic irregular branching, aseptate, and wide hyphae seen in the gram-stained periorbital exudates are consistent with the morphology of Apophysomyces.
  • Other fungal infections, such as Candida and Aspergillus, typically show different morphological features. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 614.

questions.text: Multiple leg ulcers are seen in a farmer from the sub-Himalayan area. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sporothrix Schenckii

Sporotrichosis is common in the sub-himalayan belt. It presents as diffuse erythema, multiple leg ulcers and abscess in a linear pattern due to lymphatic spread. 
Other options- Trichophyton rubrum causes dermatophytosis.
Aspergillus mostly causes respiratory infections like ABPA, Fungal ball and is also indicated in paranasal infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: A woodworker developed a chronic localized lesion over the legs. The lesion was irregular and cauliflower like. Histopathology of the lesion showed the presence of 'copper penny' as shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with histopathological finding of copper penny/sclerotic bodies is suggestive of Chromoblastoycosis.
 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal skin infection caused by pigmented fungi found in soil and decaying plant material, prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. It occurs when fungi enter through minor skin injuries.

  • Symptoms: Starts as small warty lesions that grow into larger, nodular, or crusted plaques over time. Lesions may lead to disfigurement but are typically painless.
 
  • Diagnosis: Identified through microscopy (Copper-penny bodies or Medlar bodies or Sclerotic bodies), fungal culture, or biopsy.
 
  • Treatment:
    • Antifungals like itraconazole or terbinafine.
    • Physical therapies like cryotherapy or surgical excision for localized lesions.
 
  • Prevention: Wear protective gear during outdoor activities in endemic areas and promptly treat skin injuries.

Although slow-progressing, early treatment significantly improves outcomes.




Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1666, 1688-1692.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612-614, 616-618.

choices.text: Can be caused by fungi or bacteria

questions.text: A farmer presented to the OPD with the complaints of multiple discharging granules from the leg. Which of the following statement is true in relation to his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of maduramycosis/actinomycosis.

The correct answer is option 2- It can be caused by both fungi or bacteria.
 
  • Option 1- It spreads by direct traumatic inoculation into the skin and subcutaneous tissue.(Not hematogenous)
 
  • Option 3- It can spread up to the underlying muscles and bone and cause osteomyelitis.
 
  • Option 4- Sulphur granules contain bacterial/fungal colonies. (not sulfur)

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1342, 1688

questions.text: A truck driver, who is a known case of HIV-1 develops sudden onset of breathlessness, fever and lymph node enlargement. There was pleural effusion as well. His vitals were stable. Culture showed a dimorphic fungi with mold form at 25 degrees C and yeast form at 37 degrees C. Colonies show red pigmentation. What is the likely causative agent and drug used for treatment?
questions.solution:
The most likely organism based on clinical history and histopathological findings is Penicillium marneffei. 
 
  • It is dimorphic fungus which causes talaromycosis commonly seen in people with advanced AIDS. On blood culture, the organism shows mold with powdery surface and red pigment which diffuses in the agar. 
 
  • On HPE, it shows yeast like organisms with central septation. 
 
  • Treatment- Itraconazole is used for treatment for mild to moderate cases whereas for severe cases, amphotericin B is used. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1666, 1688, 1692.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612-614.

questions.text: A young female presented with pruritus and white curdy discharge per vaginum. Direct microscopy showed budding yeast cell with pseudo-hyphae. Which of the following is used to identify the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is diagnostic of candidiasis.
 
  • For rapid identification of Candida species, CHROMagar is used.
  • It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.
  • Candida albicans colonies appear green. 



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 680, 700, 702-704.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596, 616.

questions.text: A forest worker has a H/O warty cauliflower lesion on his foot. The histology of the lesion is shown below. The histology image is of?
questions.solution:
• The forest worker is likely suffering from a fungal infection known as chromoblastomycosis.
  • Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues caused by various dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungi.
  • The most common fungi responsible are Cladosporium carrionii, Phialophora verrucosa, and Fonsecaea pedrosoi.
  • The given histopathology image is of sclerotic bodies which are consistent with this diagnosis
  • Sclerotic bodies are the diagnostic feature of chromoblastomycosis. They are thick-walled, copper-colored fungal cells that are typically found in the infected tissue. These bodies are a result of the chronic inflammatory response to the fungal infection. The cells typically tend to divide into multiple planes of division by thick septa. There is marked pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the epidermis. 
 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605,606,608,610,611 .

questions.text: Identify the pathogen based on the cell wall shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus, a common species of Aspergillus, contains several constituents. The major components of the cell wall include:

  1. Chitin: Chitin is a polysaccharide composed of N-acetylglucosamine units. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

  2. Glucan: Glucan is a polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It contributes to the integrity of the cell wall and provides structural support.

  3. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins that contain mannose residues. They are important for cell wall organization, adhesion, and immune modulation.

  4. β-(1,3)-Glucan: Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall also contains β-(1,3)-glucan, which is another type of polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It is an important target for immune recognition.


    Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 352,393,593,594,612,613 .

questions.text: An HIV positive patient presented with cough and dyspnea. CXR showed bilateral lung infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done. GMS staining of the lavage shows black crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• An immunocompromised HIV-positive patient with respiratory complaints and infiltrates on radiograph with BAL stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain revealing a typical appearance of darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts is classical of Pneumocystis jirovecii.
  • Histopathological examination of lung tissue or fluids obtained by bronchoscopy, bronchial lavage, or open lung biopsy reveals cysts.
  • Gomori's methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black colored crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background. 
  • Pneumocystis is not cultivable and there is no serological test available
  • PCR assay has been developed for detection of P. jirovecii specific genes.
  • Detection of 1, 3 ~-D-glucan in serum.





Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 600.

questions.text:
An HIV positive patient, with CD4+ counts 160 cells/mm3 presented with a history of fever and weight loss. Ground glass opacities are noted in the lungs.  Bone marrow aspirate is performed, and following findings are obtained. The patient is suffering from?

   
1. Histoplasmosis
2. Coccidioidomycosis
3. Paracoccidioidomycosis
4. Leishmaniasis
questions.solution:
• The immunocompromised patient has constitutional symptoms of fever and weight loss with infiltrates in the lung. The bone marrow aspirate reveals a macrophage cell filled with Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Clinically, the classical histoplasmosis ranges from asymptomatic infection (in immunocompetent people) to life-threatening illness seen in people with low CMI. The various clinical types include: Pulmonary histoplasmosis: It is the most common form.
  • Acute form presents with mild flu like illness, pulmonary infiltrates in chest X-ray with hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy
  • Chronic cavitary histoplasmosis may be seen in smokers with underlying structural lung disease.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 586.

questions.text: 65y old diabetic detected to have COVID-19 and was treated with Steroids for one week. He comes to the ENT OPD after two weeks with Nasal discharge. The HPE- Broad, aseptate, ribbon like hyphae with right angled branching. Which among the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
TRICK QUESTION

Given clinical history and HPE-broad, aseptate, ribbon like hyphae with right angled branching is suggestive of Mucormycosis. The most common cause of mucormycosis is Rhizopus - not Mucor. (Mucor is 2nd most common organism) (Answer confirmed by Microbiology and Infectious Disease Faculty at AIIMS, Delhi)Uncontrolled DM and Steroids are major risk factors along with COVID-19.
DOC- Amphotericin B and surgical Debridement.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page. No: 183.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain which shows acute angle branching and septate hyphae.
questions.solution:
The slide shows:

  • Septate hyphae

  • Acute angle branching (~45°)

  • Stained with Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain

These are classic features of Aspergillus species.

Key differentiating points:

  • Aspergillus: Septate hyphae, acute angle branching (45°), GMS-positive.

  • Rhizopus / Mucormycosis: Broad, aseptate or sparsely septate hyphae, right-angle (90°) branching, often ribbon-like.

  • Penicillium: Rarely causes human disease; resembles Aspergillus but with brush-like conidiophores, not tissue hyphae.

Hence, the organism showing septate hyphae with acute angle branching is Aspergillus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old women presented to your OPD with complaints of non-foul-smelling curdy white vaginal discharge accompanied by itching and burning microscopic examination revealed gram positive budding yeast and Pesudohyphae. What is the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
he patient presents with curdy white, non-foul-smelling vaginal discharge accompanied by itching and burning, and microscopy shows Gram-positive budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae — these findings are diagnostic of Candidal vulvovaginitis.

Key identifying features:

  • Discharge: Thick, curdy, white

  • Odor: Absent (non-foul-smelling)

  • Microscopy: Gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae on wet mount or KOH prep

  • Causative organism: Candida albicans

Other options:

  • Bacterial vaginosis: Thin, gray discharge with fishy odor; clue cells on microscopy

  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Frothy, yellow-green discharge with foul smell and motile trophozoites

  • Mucor mucedo: Causes mucormycosis, not vaginitis

Hence, the causative organism is Candida albicans

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of infection of the organism given below?
questions.solution:
• The given image is that of Cryptococcus.
  • It most commonly infects the lung but presents clinically as chronic Meningitis.
  • It is an Oppurtunistic infection.
  • Occurs by inhalation of yeast cells.
  • Lung infection can be asymtomatic or mild infection a flu like illness that resolves spontaneosly.
  • It can disseminate in Immunocompromised individuals causing Meningoencephalitis.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 616-617.

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who underwent a kidney transplant 10 years ago is on immunosuppressive therapy. He reports a history of cough and dyspnea for the past week, and sputum microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?**
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and sputum microscopy showing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae are indicative of invasive candidiasis.

Candida is a leading cause of opportunistic fungal infections worldwide. Individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy, are at a higher risk for systemic candidiasis, which can include conditions like candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

The most common Candida species involved in these infections are *Candida albicans*, *Candida parapsilosis*, and *Candida glabrata*. Candida infections can present in several forms, including cutaneous and mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, or, less commonly, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections may manifest as oral thrush, characterized by white, patchy or confluent pseudomembranous lesions on the tongue, lips, gums, and palate, and are often associated with AIDS. Candida can also cause vulvovaginitis, affect the nails leading to onychomycosis, and invade the surrounding nail plate.

Morphologically, Candida appears as yeast-like fungi, existing as both yeast and pseudohyphae. On wet films and smears, they appear as budding, gram-positive cells. Mycelial forms suggest colonization, and Candida albicanscan form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596,616 .

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image:
questions.solution:
Microscopy revealing broad, aseptate, ribbon-like hyphae with irregular branching is indicative of mucormycosis. This opportunistic infection, also known as zygomycosis, is primarily caused by species of *Rhizopus* (the most prevalent), *Mucor*, and *Absidia*. The common clinical presentation is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, characterized by invasion of blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain, leading to thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The blackish discoloration observed is a result of arterial and venous thrombosis, leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is confirmed through staining with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar incubated at 30-37°C, the fungi grow as grey-white colonies with a thick, cottony, fluffy surface. Microscopic examination reveals irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores ending in sporangia containing spores.

In contrast:

- Aspergillus and Talaromyces (formerly known as Penicillium) exhibit septate hyphae with conidiophores.
- Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus that appears as thick-walled, round yeast cells with single broad-based budding (giving a figure of 8 appearance) at 37°C in body tissues and cultures, and as a filamentous mold at room temperature (25°C).


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 611,613,614,615 .

questions.text: A patient with a history of bone marrow transplant presented with a lesion in the lung. On microscopic examination, the lesion is shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described—a lung lesion in a patient with a history of bone marrow transplant—along with the image showing septate hyphae with branching at acute angles, is indicative of Aspergillosis.
 
  • Invasive aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus species and is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, with the lungs being the primary site of infection. Symptoms often include fever, productive cough, chest discomfort, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. The drug of choice for treatment is Voriconazole.
 
  • In addition to invasive aspergillosis, other forms include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (which typically presents with central bronchiectasis), aspergilloma, and superficial infections such as otomycosis or mycotic keratitis.
 
  • Histopathological examination of tissue typically reveals characteristic dichotomous branching at acute angles. The hyphae do not stain well with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) but are better visualized with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain.
