  • Diagnosis can also be supported by detecting galactomannan, an Aspergillus cell-wall component, and by culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus produces dark green colonies, Aspergillus niger forms black colonies, and Aspergillus flavus generates yellow-green colonies. Microscopic examination of these colonies, stained with lactophenol cotton blue, reveals septate hyphae and conidiophores.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous mycosis caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii is a thermally dimorphic fungus, i.e it can exist in two forms depending on the temperature:
At room temperature (25°C), it grows as a mold.
At body temperature (37°C), it transforms into a yeast.

This fungus typically resides on vegetation such as soil, moss, and decaying plant matter. A traumatic inoculation of this fungus via the skin results in the subcutaneous mycosis known as Sporotrichosis or Rose-gardener's disease.

Clinical Features:

Granulomatous nodule: The initial lesion appears as a small nodule, which can later become necrotic or ulcerative.
Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: The infection can spread along the lymphatic channels, leading to nodules and ulcers along the lymphatic drainage path, which is a hallmark of the disease.

Occupational risk: Commonly seen in individuals like gardeners or forest workers who handle plants or soil frequently.
This fungal infection is often referred to as "rose gardener's disease" due to its association with plant matter handling.

Other Options:

Option A: Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis (a.k.a Ohio fever or darling's disease), a systemic fungal infection. It primarily affects the lungs, but can disseminate, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Option C: Penicilliosis marneffei also known as Talaromyces maneffei, is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in the regions of Northeast India and China. It results in pneumonia and molluscum like lesions in severely immunocompromised individuals.

Option D: Blastomyces dermatitidis is common in parts of North America. It is also a dimorphic fungus resulting in systemic mycoses commonly referred to as the Gilchrist's disease or North American Blastomycoses.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diabetic patients presenting with localized tissue destruction and blackish nasal discharge typically show signs of invasive mucormycosis. The characteristic blackish discoloration results from direct fungal invasion, which leads to arterial and venous thrombosis and subsequent gangrene. Mucormycosis is primarily an opportunistic infection caused by fungi from the genera Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia, with Rhizopus oryzae being the most common species involved.

The most frequent form of mucormycosis is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Patients typically present with rhinitis, facial or eye pain, and facial numbness. This is often followed by conjunctival suffusion, swelling, and blurry vision.

Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histopathological examination, which reveals the presence of characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae that branch at right angles.

Risk Factors:

Diabetes, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis
Immunocompromised status
Treatment of mucormycosis involves four key steps:
Initiation of Antifungal Therapy: Administer amphotericin B as early as possible. Posaconazole may also be considered in management.
Surgical Debridement: Removal of necrotic tissue is crucial.
Reversal of Underlying Conditions: Address and manage any underlying risk factors.
Treatment of Underlying Malignancies: If applicable, address any coexisting malignancies.

questions.text: Pencil-shaped macroconidia is a feature of
questions.solution:
• Trichophyton species are dermatophytes that cause tinea infections.

  • Characteristic pencil-shaped (fusiform) macroconidia are seen in culture or microscopic examination, especially in T. mentagrophytes.

  • Microconidia are also seen, but macroconidia help in species identification.

Other options:

  • Epidermophyton: Produces club-shaped macroconidia, no microconidia.

  • Microsporum: Produces thick-walled, spindle-shaped macroconidia, usually with rough walls.

  • None of the above: Incorrect, because Trichophyton shows pencil-shaped macroconidia.



Reference Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology - 9th Edition - 10th Edition, Pg 603

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is HIV-positive, which predisposes to opportunistic infections.

  • Oral findings: White mucosal plaques that can be wiped off (as opposed to hairy leukoplakia).

  • Microscopy: Shows budding yeasts and pseudohyphae, characteristic of Candida species.

  • Common in immunocompromised patients, especially with CD4 counts <200/µL.

Other options:

  • Lichen planus: Presents as reticular white striations; no budding yeast on microscopy.

  • Hairy leukoplakia: Caused by EBV, presents as white corrugated lesions on lateral tongue, cannot be scraped off; histology shows ballooned epithelial cells, not yeast.

  • Diphtheria: Upper respiratory infection with pseudomembrane, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not yeasts.



Reference
Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology 27th Edition - Page nos. 685 and 687

questions.text: A farmer presented with a traumatic ulcer in his right eye. Microscopy was done which showed septate hyphae. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The patient has post-traumatic fungal keratitis.

  • Microscopy: Shows septate hyphae.

  • Key differentiator:

    • Aspergillus → septate, branching hyphae at acute angles (45°)

    • Mucor/Rhizopus → broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching (cause mucormycosis)

    • Candida → Yeast and pseudohyphae, not true septate hyphae

Other options:

  • Mucor / Rhizopus: Cause rapid, invasive infections; hyphae are aseptate.

  • Candida: Typically causes systemic or superficial infections; hyphae are pseudohyphae, not true septate hyphae.



Reference
Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition , Page no. 612, 613, 614, 615, 616

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branched filaments like a ‘Spaghetti and meatball appearance'. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This young woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest, which is classic for Tinea versicolor. It is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species, especially Malassezia furfur. These lesions are common on the upper trunk, neck, and shoulders, especially in warm and humid environments.

The diagnostic clue lies in the KOH preparation, which shows abundant yeast-like cells and short curved hyphae that together give the “spaghetti and meatballs” appearance. This finding is pathognomonic for Malassezia infection.

Now let's look at the other options and why they are incorrect:

  • Trichophyton is a dermatophyte and causes tinea corporis, tinea cruris, etc., but it typically shows septate hyphae on KOH, not the spaghetti and meatball pattern.

  • Chlamydospores are thick-walled fungal spores, commonly seen in Candida albicans, and not a causative feature in this case.

  • Candida causes mucocutaneous infections and shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae on KOH, not the characteristic pattern described here.

So, based on the clinical presentation and KOH findings, the most likely causative organism is Malassezia.


Reference: Textbook of Microbiology and Immunology page no 597

questions.text: A patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate were seen. What is the most important risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described — black, foul-smelling nasal discharge, necrotic mass, and erosion of the nasal septum and hard palate — are classic for mucormycosis, a rapidly progressive and angioinvasive fungal infection.

Most important risk factor:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, especially with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)

    • Acidosis creates a favorable environment for Mucor species.

    • Impaired neutrophil function due to hyperglycemia enhances susceptibility.

      Causative Organism:

    • Mucorales order: Rhizopus (most common), Mucor, Rhizomucor

    • Broad, aseptate (or pauci-septate) fungi with right-angle branching

      Risk Factors:

    • Diabetes mellitus (esp. in DKA) → most important

    • Immunosuppression (post-transplant, leukemia, lymphoma)

    • COVID-19 infection (especially with steroid use and uncontrolled diabetes)

    • Iron overload or deferoxamine use

    • Burns, trauma, surgery

    • Malnutrition (especially in neonates)

      Diagnosis:

    • Nasal endoscopy/biopsy: broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching on KOH mount

    • Histopathology: tissue invasion and angioinvasion

    • Culture: Sabouraud’s dextrose agar (though diagnosis is mostly clinical + microscopic)

    • Imaging: CT/MRI to assess extent (esp. orbit, brain)

      Other options: 

  1. Hypertension

    • Common comorbidity but not directly associated with mucormycosis.

  2. Hypothyroidism

    • Does not predispose to fungal infections like mucormycosis.

  3. Foreign body

    • Can cause localized nasal discharge or infection, but not extensive necrosis as seen in mucormycosis.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 1681-1684

choices.text: Trophozoites in stool are essential for clinical diagnosis

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect with respect to amoebic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Most individuals with amoebic liver abscess do not have accompanying signs or symptoms of colitis, and most do not have E. histolytica trophozoites in their stools, therefore the presence of trophozoites is not considered essential for the clinical diagnosis of the disease.
Hence, option (1) is incorrect. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 21.

questions.text: Except _____ adult filarial worms are responsible for illnesses in all of the following.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3. Mansonella ozzardi.

While Brugia malayi, Onchocerca volvulus, and Wuchereria bancrofti are known to cause significant illnesses in adults, Mansonella ozzardi is generally less pathogenic and often associated with mild or asymptomatic infections.


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 208.

questions.text: To which helminth does the egg seen in the following fecal examination belong?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ancylostoma duodenale

Features of the egg of Ancylostoma duodenale include oval in size, and space between ovum and eggshell. It contains 4-8 blastomeres which can be easily made out.
Other options- Enterobius vermicularis- colourless, plano-convex, tadpole-shaped embryo.
Ascaris lumbricoides- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.
Trichuris trichura- Barrel-shaped with mucus plug at both ends.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Identify the protozoa whose cell division and life cycle are shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Entamoeba histolytica

Entaemoeba histolytica’s infective form is the quadrinucleated cyst which on ingestion undergoes excystation and releases four meta cystic trophozoites. They undergo multiplication and transform into uniucleated followed by a binucleated and ultimately quadrinucleated cyst.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: Determine the helminth life cycle from the illustration below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Fasciola hepatica

Metacercaria is the infective form of F. hepatica which develops into adult worms which lays unembryonated eggs that are released in the feces. This develops into miracidium and which forms two generations of redia which gets encysted to form metacercaria that is taken up by the definitive host.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 152.

choices.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with the egg of larva

questions.text: A patient's stool examination reveals the following finding. What is the most likely way for this parasite to infect you?
questions.solution:
The polar "plugs" at each end of the long, barrel-shaped eggs that characterize trichuris, which transmits trichuriasis by feco-oral transmission, are seen here.
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris. Its lifecycle involves infection after eating contaminated food with eggs.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 176.

questions.text: The genital ulcer was used to prepare a smear. Pick out the responsible organism.
questions.solution:
The above image is of trichomonas vaginalis.
Women who are infected typically have a translucent "halo" surrounding their superficial cell nucleus on a cervical smear.
It is unreliably detected by studying a genital discharge or with a cervical smear because of their low sensitivity.
A wet mount was previously used to diagnose T. vaginalis, and "corkscrew" motility was noted.

Currently, overnight cultures, which have a sensitivity range of 75–95 percent, are the most popular method of diagnosis. Even more sensitive techniques exist, but they are not commonly used.
Two examples are transcription-mediated amplification and fast antigen testing. PCR can be used to detect T. vaginalis if GENBANK/L23861-specific primers are used.
 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text: Which of these helminths' body structure is shown in this schematic diagram?
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

Two nuclei at the tip are characteristic of Brugia Malayi's microfilarae.

Wuchheria - No nuclei at tip of tail

Loa Loa - Nuclei till tip are present. 

Onchocerca - No sheath

  
Mnemonic trick: -
Love full- Loa Loa many nuclei at tail tip
Wedding nil- Wuchheria no nuclei at tail tip
Left is Brugia so it has 2 nuclei at tail tip


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 209.

questions.text: A patient complains of progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray indicated a cavitary lesion in lower lobe of right lung. The excision of the cavity had the following histological appearance. What is the most likely source of this condition, and how many layers can be seen in the parasite's wall?
questions.solution:
The following histopathological image represents a typical Hydatid cyst, which is caused  by the dog tapeworm Echinococcus.The larvae settle inside the capillaries of the various organs and first trigger an inflammatory response made up primarily of mononuclear leukocytes and eosinophils. Many of these larvae are killed, but some encyst.
An inner, nucleated, germinative layer and an outer, opaque, non-nucleated layer surround an opalescent fluid.
The characteristic outer non-nucleated layer features numerous thin laminations that give the impression that it is formed of multiple layers of gelatin.


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 130.

questions.text: This  blood smear indicates the presence of which species?
questions.solution:
The Plasmodium species shown in the image is Plasmodium falciparum, identifiable by the characteristic crescent/Banana-shaped gametocytes.

Other Plasmodium species, such as Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, or Plasmodium malariae, do not typically produce gametocytes with this distinct crescent shape. Instead, their gametocytes are usually round or oval.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: What is the name of the disease that this vector transmits?
questions.solution:
The image displayed is of a sandfly.
Primary vectors of Leishmaniasis are sandflies.
The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala azar.
Audio explanation for the above.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 55.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of passing tiny amounts of mucus-filled, frequent, thin stools, a sense of heat, lower abdominal pain, and leukocytes in the stool. Which of the following organisms is most likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Entamoeba is the most likely cause.
 
As a chronic condition, amoebiasis (caused by Entamoeba) can result in sporadic stomach pain and mucoid, bloody diarrhea.
 
WBCs can be seen in the feces in amoebiasis. Around 10% to 30% of patients with amoebiasis will experience fever. All illnesses—aside from amoebiasis—cause watery, non-bloody diarrhea.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 18.

questions.text:
A patient who is suffering from diarrhea  had kidney transplantation in the past. The figure provided information on the worms' motility. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the organism?

a. Monoecious and the organism is related with parthenogenesis
b. Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water
c. Loffler’s pneumonia is not caused by the same organism
d. Body gets this infection through filariform larvae
questions.solution:
Body gets this infection through filariform larvae.
 
  • Strongyloides stercoralis rhabditiform larvae are seen in the video. S. stercoralis is a parthenogenetic organism that is dioecious.
  • Infectious form is filariform larva (Eggs give rise to larvae and develop into filariform larvae) that penetrate the skin.
  • Loffler's pneumonia is caused by hookworms and Ascaris.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: A fecal smear revealed the following findings.Determine the organism's identity.
questions.solution:
The organism is Balantidium coli.

In the given illustration, cilia are present all around the trophozoite. Balantidium coli is the only ciliate known to infest humans.

It exists in two morphological forms-

1. Trophozoites- Oval and shape and contain two nuclei. Cilia covers the entire surface of the organism. It has a narrow anterior end and a broader posterior end. 

2. Cysts- Small and round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and contractile vacuoles. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 107.

questions.text: Identify the organism based on the stool microscopy provided.
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates quadrinucleated cyst of Giardia lamblia. 

The organism exists in Infective form which is the quadrinucleate cyst and tennis racket shaped trophozoite which is the motile form. 

Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces. These cysts are hardy and resistant to chlorination. Infection occurs by ingestion of cysts in contaminated water food or hands/fomites. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 33.

questions.text: Which one of the following malarial parasites exhibits relapse?
questions.solution:
Relapse is seen in Plasmodium vivax and ovale.

A fraction of the intrahepatic forms of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections are dormant for anywhere between three weeks and a year before reproducing.

The relapses that are typical of infection with these two species are brought on by these dormant forms, also known as hypnozoites.

Plasmodium falciparum and malaria exhibit recrudescence. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: A 32-year-old slum resident who has lost 2 kg over the past two months, complains of constipation and diarrhea. The patient showed low skin turgor and a dry mouth upon inspection. The following microscopic appearance was discovered during an endoscopic biopsy of the gut. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given biopsy suggests Giardiasis

In the biopsy : Sickle-shaped trophozoites that are tightly linked to the villus surface of the intestinal epithelial cells by the concave attachment disc can be seen suggestive of Giardiasis.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 34.

choices.text: Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood

questions.text: Why are schizonts and late trophozoite stages of plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
Schizont and late trophozoite stages of Plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smear because falciparum shows the property of CytoAdherence.

After the parasite infects RBCs it causes protrusion of ‘knobs’ on the surface of RBC which cause it to cling on to the capillary endothelium and stick to it.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most typical systemic symptom experienced by larval Helminths such Ancylostoma, Strongyloides, and Ascaris during migration?
questions.solution:
Audio explanation for the above.

During their lifecycle, Ascaris, Hookworm, and Strongyloides larvae travel through the lung and several other tissues. Local alveolar haemorrhage may result from them, although clinical pneumonitis is only found in severe infections. They are largely asymptomatic as a result.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has had chills and a fever for three days. Upon testing, it was discovered that he had dry oral mucosa and a delayed skin pinch time. The results of a peripheral blood smear were as follows. What pathogen is at play here?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation given in the case is consistent with Malaria.

The given image shows ring form parasite in normal sized RBCs as seen in case of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 73.

choices.text: Embryonated egg is the infectious stage for this worm
The adult worm usually lives in the small intestine

questions.text: Here are some pictures of an intestinal nematode. Which of the following statements regarding it are accurate?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura. Infectious stage of the worm is its embryonated egg.

It is transmitted through oral route. The adult lives within the large intestine and appendix.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 176.

choices.text: Same as relapse in P. vivax and P. ovale malaria
Recurrence of  parasitaemia after completion of treatment

questions.text: What does the term "malaria recrudescence" mean?
questions.solution:
Malaria recrudescence is a situation in which a person has an episode of malaria reappearance of asexual phase of parasitaemia despite having been treated for the infection previously.
  • It is caused when the infected person does not complete the full course of antimalarial treatment or when antimalarials used to treat the infection were not effective against the particular type of malaria parasite that infected that person.
  • It can also be caused by reinfection with the malaria parasite, as the immunity acquired from previous infection with the same strain of malaria is usually short-lived.
  • Recrudescence occurs in Plasmodium falciparum and malariae species. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 69, 81.

questions.text: A 23 years old male presented with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea of one-week duration. The following colonoscopic biopsy is diagnostic of infection with:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is amebiasis. It is one of the most common agents causing bloody diarrhea (dysentery) and enterocolitis. It is caused by entamoeba histolytica.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 19.

choices.text: a. Transmission is through ingestion of infected pork
Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans
The helminth causes a transient self-resolving infection in humans
Drug of choice for this condition is albendazole

questions.text: A helminth's ovum is shown below. What is accurate about the helminth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans

In H. nana infection, eggs are the infective form which hatch out and develop into larvae in 4-5 days. Thereafter, in the gut lumen, they transform into adult worms in 10-12 days.
Other options- Transmission is through food and water contaminated with eggs and autoinfection.
The infection isn’t self-resolving as the worm burden keeps increasing in untreated cases.
Praziquantel 25 mg/kg is the drug of choice.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 137.

choices.text: Transmitted through contaminated food and water usually

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive male patient complains of watery diarrhoea and odynophagia. An endoscopy was done which revealed esophageal and gastric candidiasis. The patient's stool was wet, and the results are shown below. What is accurate regarding this?
questions.solution:
• The given stool mount is showing severe infestation with Strongyloides rhabditiform larvae.
  • The infective stage is filariform larvae only.
  • It is usually transmitted through skin.
  • Infection occurs in immunocompromised patient.
  • Females show parthenogenesis in human intestine.
  • Drug of choice is ivermectin.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 182.

questions.text: All of the following can result in autoinfection, except:
questions.solution:
Autoinfection is the infection of a primary host with a parasite, particularly a helminth, in such a way that the complete life cycle of the parasite happens in a single organism, without the involvement of another host. Therefore, the primary host is at the same time the secondary host of the parasite.

Except Ascaris lumbricoides all the other options mentioned can cause auto infection.

Memorizing Trick :- Autoinfection causing parasites
CHEST
Capillaria phillipenisis
H. nana
E. vermicularis
S. stercoralis 
T. solium 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 4.

questions.text: The following helminths have been linked to pernicious anaemia:
questions.solution:
The pernicious anemia is caused by the fish tapeworm, Diphyllobothrium latum.

D. latum contains considerable amounts of vitamin B12. The host and the living tapeworm in the intestinal canal compete for vitamin B12 leading to Pernicious anemia. There is parasite-mediated dissociation of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex in the gut lumen making B12 unavailable to the host.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 120.

questions.text: The short incubation period of transfusion-associated malaria is caused by the blood's inclusion of:
questions.solution:
Trophozoites are present in infected RBCs in humans. When they rupture at Schizont stage, they release merozoites into the blood stream. Hence packed RBCs will be infected with trophozoites and these are directly transmitted to the recepient's blood during transfusion and start dividing. This causes Malaria with a much lesser incubation period.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 80.

questions.text: When does neurocysticercosis become nonedematous?
questions.solution:
There are four main stages of neurocysticercosis (also known as Escobar's pathological stages):

 1.Vesicular: viable parasite with intact membrane and therefore no host reaction. 

 2.Colloidal vesicular: parasite dies within 4-5 years untreated, or earlier with treatment and the cyst fluid becomes turbid. As the membrane
                                     becomes leaky edema surrounds the cyst. This is the most symptomatic stage.

3.Granular nodular: edema decreases as the cyst retract further
4.Nodular calcified: end-stage quiescent calcified cyst remnant; no edema.

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1493.

choices.text: Consumption of contaminated water with protozoa of Legionella
Breathing aerosols of environmental water sources such as air conditioning units

questions.text: Pick the option that best describes route of spread of Legionella pneumophila outbreak.
questions.solution:
Legionella is a gram negative pleomorphic motile bacillus which is strictly anaerobe. Reservoir for the organism includes aquatic environment which an be natural such as rivers, streams, oceans, hot springs and artificial such as cooling towers, decorative fountains and plumbing systems. Infection is acquired via inhalation of aerosols or microaspiration.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 408.

questions.text: A 15-year-old kid complains of loose stools and sporadic abdominal pain for the previous 12 months. Multiple ova that are larger than 100 micrometer were visible in the wet-mount stool samples. The pathogen that causes the disease cannot be which of the following:
questions.solution:
The eggs of opisthorchis viverrini measures less than 100 um ( ~ 30x12 um ) and hence it is the incorrect option.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is diagnosed with the help of the Sabin Feldman dye test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasmosis is detected by the Sabin Feldman dye test.  It is a serologic test to diagnose toxoplasmosis. Patient serum is treated with Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement and then incubated. The test measures the total amount of antibody in serum which is capable of complement-mediated killing of toxoplasma tachyzoites.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 95.

questions.text: Which of the following animals usually exhibit Echinococcus granulosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Dog

Echinococcus granulosus is also known as the dog tapeworm which has dog as its definitive host. Humans act as accidental intermediate hosts.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 4.

questions.text: What kind of organism is the cause of cutaneous larva migrans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Ancylostoma braziliense
Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by Ancylostoma brazilliense.

Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is caused by the larvae of animal hookworms, most commonly Ancylostoma braziliense (found in cats and dogs). The larvae penetrate human skin but cannot complete their life cycle, leading to serpiginous, itchy skin lesions as they migrate through the epidermis.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: Identify the organism responsible for the blood smear.
questions.solution:
The blood smear shows multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by plasmodium falciparum.
Falciparum malaria infects both young and mature erythrocytes. Binucleate rings( double chromatin) seen in RBCs are common and they resemble stereo headphones in appearance. Hypnozoites are not present in plasmodium falciparum infection.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 73.

questions.text: Which of the following is a carrier agent for the disease with the specified polarised microscopy characteristic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ixodes scapularis ticks .
The smear shows Borrelia burgdoferi which is seen as irregular spirals on microscopy.
It is transmitted by Ixodes scapularis tick.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text: Which of these causes biliary obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Clonorchis

Clonorchis is most commonly indicated in biliary obstruction. It can also lead to cholangiocarcinoma.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text: Which is an exception to hepatocyte infection?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Babesia does not infect hepatocytes. Rest of the organisms have a hepatocytic phase i their life cycle. 

Additional points about Babesia
  • Babesia is a parasite that resembles malaria but does not have hemozoin pigment.
  • The white-footed mouse is a reservoir
  • It's spread by ticks (Ixodes)
  • Has Maltese cross appearance on PBS.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text: Tafenoquine can be clinically used in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of malaria caused by vivax and ovale. It acts on the hypnozoite stage, or exoerythrocytic tissue stage, and inhibits relapse of malaria.

Tafenoquine 300 mg is used once on the first or second day of therapy with additional medications such as chloroquine, as opposed to primaquine, which must be administered for 14 days.

It is contraindicated in pregnant and lactating females, children and G6PD deficiency. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 878.

questions.text: A known HIV patient using anti-retroviral medication reported having diarrhoea for six months. Kinyoun stain was positive after stool microscopy revealed 10–30 micrometre cysts. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Cystoisospora (Isospora) belli is the causative agent of malabsorption, fever, and chronic diarrhoea in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) patients. Infections are characterized by sudden fever, abdominal pain, and watery (non-bloody) diarrhoea that lasts for weeks or months in those with severe immunosuppression. Diagnosis is usually made through detection of the large (~25-um) oocysts in stool with Kinyoun stain and modified acid-fast staining.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 96.

questions.text: A child who had been experiencing stomach pain for 10 days visited OPD. The results of stool microscopy are displayed. What medication is recommended for the illness brought on by the specified organism
questions.solution:
Praziquantel is the medication used to treat Hymenolepis nana. This parasite is characterized by its egg shape, which consists of a thin colorless outer membrane, an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere, and polar filaments and knobs along with yolk granules found between the two membranes. The infection is usually transient in humans and the eggs are non-bile stained and unable to survive for more than 10 days in the external environment. Treatment with praziquantel is necessary to eliminate the infection. In the given image egg shows polar filaments which differentiates it from the egg of H. diminuta.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Alveolar like tumor in liver which grows slowly is caused by:
questions.solution:
The liver develops many lesions that resemble alveoli as a result of Echinococcus multilocularis. It is the cause of alveolar hydatid cysts disease or malignant hydatid cyst. It manifests as numerous tiny liver cysts.
 
Echinococcus granulosus is the cause of unilocular hydatid cyst disease.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: HIV is diagnosed in a 35-year-old heterosexual patient who complaints of watery diarrhoea. Colonoscopic biopsy is displayed as follows. What is your most likely diagnosis out of the following
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidiosis is a common opportunistic infection in people living with HIV/ AIDS, and is usually experienced as a diarrheal illness. Diagnosis of cryptosporidiosis in an HIV patient typically requires laboratory testing as the symptoms can be quite similar to other conditions. A stool sample is usually collected and tested for the presence of parasites. Microscopy can reveal the presence of the parasite in stool samples, while molecular diagnostic methods such as PCR or antigen testing can offer greater accuracy. If a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of cryptosporidiosis, a doctor may also order blood tests and other imaging tests to rule out other potentially more serious conditions.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: A patient from NE India presents with U/L edema. He has had his PCI and is k/c/o CAD. Swelling is more distal than proximal. What is the next best investigation
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are indicative of lymphatic filariasis which is most commonly caused by W. Bancrofti. DEC provoocation test is the initial investigation of choice for detecting microfilariae in the patient’s blood.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 215.

choices.text: F. Hepatica infection is through infected water caltrops

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Fasciolopsis Buski 
Giant intestinal fluke is its common name.
In humans and pigs, the adult worm resides in the duodenum or jejunum. 

Hepatic Fasciola 
leaf-shaped with a body that is flattened dorsoventrally. 
parasite is hermaphrodite. 
Definitive host: Sheep serve as its primary definitive host, however it can also be detected in the human biliary tract. 
Freshwater snails are the first intermediate hosts (Lymnaea). 
Aquatic vegetations serve as a second intermediate host. 
Metacercariae encysted on unprocessed aquatic vegetation is the infectious form. 

Schistosomes
Schistosomes are dioecious, sexes are separate.

DOC for trematodes is praziquantel.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 157.

questions.text: What is indicated by the life cycle of this image?
questions.solution:
1. LIFE CYCLE OF TOXOPLASMA GONDII


Tachyzoites are seen in peripheral blood smear and Bradyzoites seen in tissue biopsy are key to identify the organism as Toxoplasma in such questions.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: A individual with fever and myalgia reported seeing a cutaneous lesion with erythema and a black necrotic centre. All of the following have this trait, except for
questions.solution:
Important differential diagnoses of Eschar forming illness are:
Spider bite
Post-trauma
Spotted fever Rickettsiosis
Scrub typhus
Tularaemia
Anthrax
Disseminated fungal infection

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 530.

questions.text:
A piece of the colon with worms buried in the mucosa was removed during emergency surgery for intestinal blockage.
Which of the following statements about the pathogen is true?
questions.solution:
The parasite Ascaris lumbricoides is depicted. Esophageal distal end bulb is present. In cestodes, proglottids are observed.Trematodes exhibit hooks. In flatworms, flame cells can be seen.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 193.

questions.text:
A person who travels extensively arrived with an unidentified fever.
The image of a bone marrow aspirate is shown below. What will be the next step?
questions.solution: Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 246.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option.
 
(a) Hymenolepsis nana (i)
(b) Ascaris (ii)
(c) Hookworm (iii)
(d) Taenia (iv)
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Hymenolepsis nana- Oval in shape with the presence of six hooklets. It is non-bile stained.



Taenia- Spherical thin hyaline embryonic membrane with the fully developed hexacanth embryo at the centre.



Hookworm- oval in size, space between ovum and eggshell and the presence of 4-8 blastomeres.



Ascaris- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.




Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: Which parasite is depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
The parasite shown in figure is ascaris.

a) Male worm: Is smaller in size, measures 15-30 cm in length and 2-4 mm in thickness. Its posterior end is curved ventrally to form a hook and carries two copulatory spicules

b) Female worm- Is larger, measuring 20-40 cm in length and 3-6 mm in thickness. Its posterior extremity is straight and conical.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 201.

questions.text:
Match the following and choose the correct option.
A. Balamuthia mandrillaris 1. Flagella
B. Balantidium coli 2. Cilia
C. Trichomonas vaginalis 3. Pseudopod
D. Toxoplasma gondii 4. No particular organ
questions.solution:
Organism Organ of locomotion
Balamuthia mandrillaris Pseudopod
Balantidium coli Cilia
Trichomonas vaginalis Flagella
Toxoplasma gondii No particular organ

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text:
Match the following and choose the correct option.
A. Diphyllobothrium 1. Sheep
B. Paragonimus 2. Cray fish
C. Brugia 3. Cyclops
D. Fasciola 4. Mansonia
questions.solution:
Organism -Hosts
  • Diphyllobothrium - 2 hosts : Cyclops and freshwater fish
  • Paragonimus  - 2 intermediate hosts : Snail and crayfish
  • Brugia  - Definitive hosts: humans (preferred), monkeys, domestic cats and forest carnivores
  • Fasciola  - 2 intermediate hosts: Snail and freshwater plants, Sheep and man are the definite hosts.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 4.

questions.text:
A patient who has been receiving long-term steroids for recurring eczema and chronic urticaria is now visiting the clinic with itching and nocturnal cough.
Alveolar lavage for bronchospasm revealed several tiny larvae. What is your medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's use of steroids, according to the query, suggests that his immune system is impaired. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis, a serious infection caused by Strongyloides stercoralis, is known to occur in immunocompromised persons. The larvae of this creature are found in many bodily organs, which defines it.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Identify the parasite whose microflariae have a sheath at the end without a nucleus.
questions.solution:
Wuchereria Bancrofti is the correct option.
It has a short neck that gives the appearance of being constricted, which connects the short cephalic or head region to the main body. With no nuclei at the tail tip, the dark patches have scattered nuclei throughout the body cavity.

Mnemonic trick: -
Love full- Loa Loa many nuclei at tail tip
Wedding nil- Wuchheria no nuclei at tail tip
Left is Brugia so it has 2 nuclei at tail tip


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 209.

questions.text:
A patient from Bihar who had a fever was brought to the OPD. When examined, hepatomegaly was discovered. He had a bone marrow biopsy, and the results showed macrophages that contained an organism in its kinetoplast stage.
What is the vector responsible for the condition?
questions.solution: Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 52.

choices.text: Most common cause of diarrhoea is C.parvum
Oocyst become infective immediately after being excreted in the stool

questions.text: A post-renal transplant patient has a chronic diarrheal illness. Upon inspection of the stool, cysts measuring 4 to 6 microns are found. These cysts are stained positively by the Kinyon method. Which statement about the above condition is  correct?
questions.solution:
The correct statement is option B- oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool. 

Option A- The most common organism implicated worldwide is cryptosporidium hominis.

Option C- It is not an obligate intracellular parasite.

Option D- Since the oocysts are immediately infectious after being excreted in stool, autoinfection is quite common. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: The condition in the liver according to the given image is caused by:
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Symmers Pipe-Stem Fibrosis or Bilharzial Clay Pipe Stem Fibrosis which is a form of periportal hepatic fibrosis caused by Schistosoma Mansoni infection.
 
In the image we see a longitudinal section showing large areas of fibrosis around the vessels and bile ducts.
The fibrosis is the result of granulomatous inflammation in the portal tracts caused by Schistosoma Mansoni eggs.

 S. japonicum: Leads to Katayama fever, liver fibrosis, liver cirrhosis, liver portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and ascites. 

S. haematobium schistosomiasis : includes hematuria, scarring, calcification, squamous cell carcinoma, and occasional embolic egg granulomas in brain or spinal cord.

 Clonorchis : C sinensis can live for years within the biliary system of humans and result in various symptoms, including cholecystitis, cholangitis, and cholangiocarcinoma. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 148.

questions.text: Person having heterozygous sickle cell trait is protected from infection of:
questions.solution:
Person having heterozygous sickle cell trait is protected from infection of plasmodium falciparum

Because the sickle cell trait does not allow the parasite to grow properly and they die due to low oxygen concentration.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 80.

questions.text: The following statement is false regarding Tungiasis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Caused by male Tunga penetrans

Tungiasis is caused by an adult, female sand flea variety of tunga penetrans. It causes immense pain and itching, difficulty walking, sleeping and concentrating on school or work. Tungiasis can be associated with abscesses caused by secondary bacterial infections.

Online reference: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tungiasis

questions.text: Which species of Plasmodium has the longest pre-erythrocytic schizogony?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Plasmodium malariae

This phase of malaria occurs after the introduction of sporozoites, the infective form of the parasite, through the skin of the Anopheles mosquito. In this phase the patient is asymptomatic and the patient is not infective.
Pre-erythrocytic schizogony:
P. vivax- 8 days
P. falciparum- 5 days
P. malariae- 13 days
P. ovale- 9 days

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: What species of Plasmodium exhibits Ziemann's stippling in infected RBCs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: P.malariae

While P. vivax and P. ovale selectively parasitize young cells, P. malariae shows an affinity for older cells, parasitizing about 0.2% of the victim’s total erythrocyte population.
Following incorporation into erythrocytes, early trophozoites begin to accumulate hemozoin, decrease in size and appear as pink-staining Ziemann’s dots. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: Which of the following helminths is not transmitted by a snail?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Trichinella spiralis 

Trematodes are transmitted by snails which includes all the options except Trichinella spiralis which is a nematode. It is transmitted by consuming undercooked meat or pork.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 171.

questions.text: Which of these causes Neurocysticercosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cysticercus cellulosae

C.Cellulose causes neurocysticercosis. It is the most common CNS parasitic infection and the most common cause of adult-onset epilepsy.
 Other options- C. Bovis causes intestinal cysticercosis.
Hydatid cyst of the brain, also known as neuro hydatidosis is a condition caused by E. granuloses.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 126.

questions.text: The most common cause of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: L. Major
  • L.Major is the most common cause of cutaneous leishmaniasis. This is followed by L.Tropica and L.Braziliens.
  • L.Donovan rarely causes cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • Out of the options given, the most common cause of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis is L. major, which is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies that have fed on infected rodents such as gerbils and jirds. L. tropica and L. donovani cause other forms of leishmaniasis, while L. braziliensis is the most common cause of the mucocutaneous form of the disease.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 53.

questions.text: What causes visceral larval migrans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Toxocara

Visceral larva migrans is caused by Toxocara canis. It usually affects children and is asymptomatic.

Other options- Loa Loa- Loiasis
Enterobius vermicularis- Enterobiasis (Pinworm infection)
Taenia- Intestinal taeniasis and cysticercosis

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 167.

questions.text: What is a typical Nocardia Asteroids infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Brain Abscess

Nocardia is not known to cause the other conditions given in the options.
Cerebral Nocardiosis is a rare, challenging, opportunistic infectious disease of the central nervous system occurring in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised hosts. It often results in intraparenchymal abscess formation, which represents only 2% of all cerebral abscesses.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 400.

questions.text: What causes Weil's disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Leptospira interrogans

Leptospira interrogans is indicated in Weil’s disease. It is characterized by ictohemorrhagic fever and hepatorenal syndrome.
Other options- Borrelia recurrentis- Relapsing fever
Treponema endemicum- Syphilis
Borrelia burdoferi- Lyme’s disease

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 388.

questions.text: The causative agent for Delhi Boil is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: L . Tropica 

Delhi boil is caused by L.Tropica. It is a type of cutaneous leishmaniasis characterised by ulcerative lesions of the skin. It was once very common in India, particularly Delhi and hence the name.
Other options: L. Donovani - VL
L. Braziliens - CL
L.Mexicana- CL

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 61.

questions.text: Which is the most common Helminthic disease associated with myocarditis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Trichinella 

Trichenella spiralis is most commonly associated with myocarditis.
Trichinella spiralis-associated myocarditis does not result due to the direct larval invasion of the myocardium with encystation but is caused most likely by an eosinophil-enriched inflammatory response which leads to eosinophilic myocarditis.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 173.

questions.text: Which of the following protozoa is not detected by Fecal Acid Fast Stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Microsporidia 

This technique is useful for the identification of oocysts of the coccidian species (Cryptosporidium, Cystoisospora, and Cyclospora), which may be difficult to detect with routine stains such as trichrome.
Microsporidia is an obligate intracellular fungus which is treated as protozoa. It is an unicellular parasite which can be detected with routine stain.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 105.

questions.text: Which of the following microfilaria has a sheath surrounding it and had two big nuclei at the tail tip?
questions.solution:
The organism based on the given description is Brugia Malayi. 

The microfilariae of B. Malayi are sheathed with kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei and the organism shows nocturnal periodicity. 
 
  • Option 2- Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed with absent nuclei at tail tip. It shows nocturnal periodicity.
 
  • Option 3-  Microfilariae of onchocerca are unsheathed and nuclei do not extend till tail tip. 
 
  • Option 4- Loa Loa's microfilariae are sheathed and nuclei are arranged in a row upto the tail tip.


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8the edition, Page no 208-211.

questions.text: HIV positive patient with diarrhea, stool examination, acid fast stain shows 4-6 micron size oocyst, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The described clinical picture of diarrhoea in an HIV patient is suggestive of an infestation with the coccidian parasite.
  • Cryptosporidium produces round oocysts of 6 um (4-6micrometer) in size and they are acid fast positive
  • Cyclospora produces oocysts of 8-10micro meter size and they are round in shape which are acid fast
  • Cysto-isospora produces oocysts which have oval in shape and are acid fast stained





Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 99-105.

questions.text: A 50 year old male with fever for 3 weeks presented to the hospital. Patient did not improve on antibiotics and antimalarial. On examination abdominal distension present. Rk 39 antibody test (+). What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The best treatment option for the patient's condition would be: Liposomal Amphotericin B.
  • The positive Rk 39 antibody test suggests a possible diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar. The treatment of choice for visceral leishmaniasis is liposomal Amphotericin B, which is highly effective and recommended as first-line therapy.
  • Fluconazole is an antifungal medication and would not be the appropriate treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. Pentamidine and sodium stibogluconate are alternative treatment options for visceral leishmaniasis, but liposomal Amphotericin B is considered the best option.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1741,1743-1745 .

questions.text: Identify the pathogen based on the life cycle given ?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis:
  • Females live in the superficial tissues of the small intestine (duodenum and jejunum)
  • Humans, dogs, and cats are the definitive host
  • Larvae are filariform and penetrate via the skin route (Infective stage)
  • Autoinfection is common  (rhabditiform larvae in large intestine can become filariform and can undergo internal migration, penetrating the intestinal wall and entering the bloodstream) 

Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page no 182,183,188,196,201 .

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the pathogen based on the image given?
questions.solution:
1. Round to oval egg 
2. Hexacanth larva 
3. Polar filaments
4. Double membrane
Are suggestive of Hymenolepis nana.
  • Hymenolepis nana and H. diminuta infections are most often asymptomatic. Heavy infections with H. nana can cause weakness, headaches, anorexia, abdominal pain, and diarrhea
  • Infection is acquired most commonly from eggs in the feces of another infected individual, which are transferred in food, by contamination.
  • Praziquantel is the drug of choice because it acts very rapidly against H. nana.

Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page no 136,137,139,150,151,153 .

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of severe malaria?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, pH > 7.35 (option 1) is not a feature typically associated with Severe malaria.

Severe malaria refers to severe manifestations of the disease that can be life-threatening and often require immediate medical intervention. Common features of complicated malaria include severe anemia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury, cerebral malaria (which can present with coma or altered consciousness), metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia.

A pH greater than 7.35 indicates a relatively normal or slightly alkaline blood pH, which is not typically associated with severe malaria. In severe cases, metabolic acidosis is more likely to be observed with a decreased pH.

Unarousable coma (option 2), glucose < 40 mg/dl (option 3), and serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dl (option 4) are all features that can be associated with severe malaria.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1724, table 224-2 .

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen in the wet saline mount of vaginal discharge
Cysts can be seen in the wet saline amount of vaginal discharge

questions.text: A female patient presents with pain abdomen and a greenish discharge p/v. Which of these is correct about the causal organism?
questions.solution:
• A female patient presenting with a vaginal discharge and pain in the abdomen with green color discharge is associated with Trichomonas vaginalis infection which shows characteristic jerky or twitching motility in saline mount preparation.
  • The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, dysuria and dyspareunia.
  • The gold- standard for diagnosis is Culture on CPLM media. 
  • The treatment of Choice is Metronidazole 2 g orally as a single dose.
     
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 36, 37.

questions.text: Which of the following species is HRP-2 +ve?
questions.solution:
Histidine rich protein-2, abbreviated as HRP-2 is a protozoan antigen, specific to Plasmodium falciparum, the causative agent of cerebral malaria.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 67, 78, 83.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by Clonorchis sinensis?
questions.solution:
Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese or oriental liver fluke) chronic infection with heavy worm burden, can cause mechanical obstruction of the bile duct and irritation due to toxin released by the flukes leads to cholangitis, dilatation of the bile duct, marked ductal epithelial hyperplasia, and fibrosis leading to cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct carcinoma).

Reference: Panikar's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 154, 156.

questions.text: A patient from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer on the leg having rolled edges. On microscopy, dark staining nuclei and kinetoplasts were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A patient from the western part of Rajasthan, India has an ulcer on the leg (exposed area), with rolled edges, which on microscopy revealed kinetoplasts. This clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous Leishmaniasis.
  • Blood and tissue flagellates including Leishmania and Trypanosoma possess kinetoplasts.



Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 33.40.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, lethargy, and weight loss. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is seen. The blood filarial antigen test was positive. What is the next best step to guide the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's clinical pictures best correlates with occult Filariasis also known as Weingarten's syndrome which represents a hypersensitivity reaction to microfilaria antigen.
  • Since the microfilariae are cleared from the bloodstream, thus, it is unlikely that we shall be able to detect microfilariae in peripheral blood.
  • The confirmation of diagnosis can be done by noting a prompt response to diethylcarbamazine.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 215- 217.

choices.text: Differentiate between bile and non bile stained eggs

questions.text: Which of the following are advantages of Saline wet mount over iodine wet mount?
questions.solution:
Advantages of saline wet mount include ability to Demonstrate motility of trophozoites and to differentiate between bile and non bile stained.

Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page. No- 22, 235.

questions.text: 45y old male truck driver detected to be HIV positive presents with fever , headache and neck stiffness. CSF study done with India Ink showed an encapsulated organism. Which of the following is true regarding management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cryptococcosis.
ART should be given 2-3 weeks after initiating treatment to prevent immune reconstitiution causing severe inflammation. Combination of IV Amphotericin B with Flucytosine is considered to be standard of treatment.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1668.

questions.text: Reservoir for Kala azar is?
questions.solution:
In India, Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis) is caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by the bite of the female Phlebotomus argentipes (sandfly).

The reservoir of infection varies by geographic region:

  • In India and Bangladesh, humans are the only known reservoir (anthroponotic transmission).

  • In Mediterranean countries, Africa, and Latin America, dogs and other canines serve as reservoirs (zoonotic transmission).

So, for Kala-azar in India, the reservoir is human.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with continues discomfort in the right hypochondrium. Upon examination, an enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins is noted. The image below displays his CT radiograph. Additionally, he reports a history of spending a significant amount of time pet dogs. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s history of contact with pet dogs, presence of hepatomegaly, and CT findings showing cystic lesions in the liver are classic for hydatid cyst disease, caused by the larval form of Echinococcus granulosus (dog tapeworm).

Humans are accidental intermediate hosts, infected by ingestion of eggs from dog feces. The larvae migrate via the portal circulation and form hydatid cysts in the liver (most common site), lungs, or other organs.

Typical CT finding: “Cyst within a cyst” or “honeycomb” appearance, sometimes with daughter cysts and calcified walls.

  • Strongyloides stercoralis → causes intestinal infection, larva currens, not hepatic cysts.

  • Entamoeba histolytica → causes amoebic liver abscess (anchovy-sauce pus), not cystic lesions.

  • Ancylostoma duodenale → hookworm causing iron deficiency anemia, not hepatic lesions.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium falciparum is the most virulent malaria species and is responsible for cerebral malaria, which can lead to coma, seizures, and neurological deficits.

Key points:

  • Cerebral malaria pathophysiology:

    • Infected red blood cells adhere to cerebral capillaries (sequestration), causing microvascular obstruction and hypoxia.

    • Leads to neurological symptoms like altered consciousness, seizures, and coma.

  • Other Plasmodium species:

    • P. vivax, P. ovale, P. malariae → usually cause uncomplicated malaria; rarely affect the brain.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with a blackish lesion at the site of mite bite from a few days back. He also gives a history of fever and rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Key features:

  • Eschar (blackish lesion at bite site): Pathognomonic for scrub typhus, typically at the site of a chigger (mite) bite

  • Fever and rash: Common systemic manifestations

  • History: Exposure to grasslands, forests, or areas with heavy scrub vegetation

Other options:

  • Anthrax: Black eschar present, but usually associated with animal handling or infected animal products, and systemic symptoms differ.

  • Epidemic typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by lice, no eschar.

  • Rocky Mountain spotted fever: Tick-borne rickettsial disease, rash typically starts on wrists/ankles, not eschar.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites reproduce via parthenogenesis?
questions.solution:
• Females of Strongyloides stercoralis are known to be parthenogenetic i.e. capable of generating offspring without the need for fertilisation by a male.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis has a parasitic cycle and a free-living cycle in soil.
  • Humans are the natural host. Filariform larvae are the infective form and there are two modes of infection: penetration of the skin by 3rd stage filariform larva, and autoinfection. female worms present in the intestine lay eggs in the mucosa which hatches immediately, releasing the rhabditiform larva.
  • The larva migrates into the lumen of the intestine and passes down to be released into the faeces. The rhabditiform larva may change into a filariform larva while passing through the bowel.
  • The filariform larvae in the bowel do not leave the host and become a source of autoinfection as they penetrate the colonic mucosa or perianal Skin. The rhabditiform larvae passed in the faeces may undergo two types of development in the soil:

1. Direct development: The rhabditiform larva moults twice on reaching the soil to become the infective filariform larva. The filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.
2. Indirect development: The rhabditiform larvae develop into free-living males and females in the soil.

Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 169,115.

questions.text: Which is the best test used for detection of malarial infection and to estimate parasite concentration?
questions.solution:
• Malarial parasite detection and parasite quantification is best done by a Giemsa-stained thick smear.
  • Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due high sensitivity and specificity. A diluted Giemsa stain is applied to both thick and thin films.
  • Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium.
  • Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page No 306.

choices.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true and reason is Reason (R) is the correct explanation of Assertion (A)
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true and reason is Reason (R) is not the correct explanation of Assertion (A)
Assertion (A) is true and Reason (R) is false
Assertion (A) is false and Reason (R) is true

questions.text:
Assertion(A): Late trophoblast and schizont stage in Plasmodium falciparum are not seen in blood smears.
Reason(R): These two stages are trapped in the capillary endothelium of internal organs due to cytoadherence.
questions.solution:
• Late trophozoite, early and mature schizonts are stages in the asexual life cycle of P.falciparum.
  • These stages are usually not seen in the peripheral smear unless the malaria is exceptionally severe or pernicious. ,
  • In regular conditions these two stages are trapped in the capillary endothelium of internal organs due to cytoadherence.
Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 80-81.

questions.text: Which of the following is transmitted by all the components of blood?
questions.solution:
• Malaria is the only disease transmitted by all components of blood.
  • Bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes, inject sporozoites into the bloodstream and is capable of causing infection.
  • Hence malaria can be caused by transfusion of sporozite infested blood.



Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 80.

questions.text: A 30y old male with history of Renal transplant on treatment now came with history of multiple epsidoes of watery diarrhoea. The stool microscopy revealed oocyst of size 30 X15 microns given below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Given history with Pink Oocyst of size 30 microns is suggestive of Isospora.
  • Isospora causes a self limiting but protracted diarhoea more commonly seen in HIV individuals.
  • Infection is acquired by ingestion of mature oocysts in food or drink.
  • The oocyst can be classified based on the size of the oocyst.
  • Cryptosporidium is 4-6 microns and cyclospora is 8-12 micron.


Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 104.

questions.text: Which of the following is a protozoan parasite, that can be seen inside Kupffer cells?
questions.solution:
The protozoan parasite *Leishmaniadonovani* is known to be found inside Kupffer cells. These cells are part of the mononuclear phagocytic system located in the liver. The amastigote form of *Leishmania*, also called the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body (as shown in the image below), is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast, but lacks a flagellum.

Leishmaniasis is a gradually progressing disease caused by a protozoan parasite from the genus *Leishmania*. The parasite‘s life cycle has two main forms:

- **Promastigote**: This flagellated form develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector.
- **Amastigote**: This non-flagellated form multiplies intracellularly within the host‘s reticuloendothelial cells.

Transmission occurs through the bite of an infected female Phlebotomussandfly, which introduces the flagellated promastigotes into the host‘s skin. The disease presents with symptoms such as fever with chills, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly. It weakens the immune system, leading to persistent fever, anemia, and enlargement of the liver and spleen. If untreated, it can result in death due to secondary infections.

Diagnosis of leishmaniasis primarily involves the demonstration of amastigotes inside macrophages from tissue aspirates, such as blood smears, bone marrow, spleen, or lymph node aspirates. This method is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1744-1745 .

questions.text: A lady cleans her cat litter regularly to avoid infection by *Toxoplasma* during her pregnancy. What is the infective stage of this organism in the cat feces?
questions.solution:
The infective stage of Toxoplasmafound in cat feces is the oocyst. Oocysts develop through the sexual reproduction of Toxoplasmain the cat‘s intestinal lumen and are excreted in the feces. These oocysts take 1 to 5 days after excretion to become infective. Therefore, removing cat litter daily and disposing of it safely can help prevent infection.

In cats, the definitive hosts, both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur. The oocyst is formed through sexual reproduction, while tachyzoites and tissue cysts represent stages of asexual multiplication.

In intermediate hosts, such as humans, mice, and rats, only the asexual forms—tachyzoites and tissue cysts—are found.


Reference : Paniker’s Textbook Of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page no 90-93 .

questions.text: Which among the following parasites directly invade the skin?
questions.solution:
The parasite that directly invades the skin is Schistosoma mansoni.

S. mansoni adult worms live in the inferior mesenteric vein, and their infective form is the fork-tailed cercaria. Upon skin penetration, the cercariae cause a pruritic rash, known as cercarial dermatitis or swimmer's itch, which is self-limiting.

Katayama fever occurs 4-8 weeks after the cercarial invasion due to immune complexes formed by the high worm load and egg antigens. It presents with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

When eggs are deposited in the small intestine, patients may experience abdominal pain and bloody dysentery over a long period, a condition known as intestinal bilharziasis. The treatment of choice is praziquantel, 40 mg/kg as a single oral dose. Oxamniquine, 15 mg/kg as a single oral dose, is also effective.

Schistosoma mansoni eggs are yellowish-brown with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end. In Schistosoma haematobium, the egg has a terminal spine, and in Schistosoma japonicum, the egg lacks a spine but has a small rudimentary lateral knob.



Other options:

  • Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm): Infection occurs by drinking contaminated water containing copepods with larvae, not by skin invasion.

  • Wuchereria bancrofti (filarial worm): Transmitted by mosquito bite (Culex, Anopheles, Aedes, Mansonia), not by direct skin penetration.

  • Onchocerca volvulus: Transmitted by blackfly bite, larvae enter through the bite wound, not by spontaneous skin invasion.

choices.text: Amoebiasis is the causative organism and treatment Metronidazole + Paromomycin
Typhoid is the causative organism and treatment includes Ceftriaxone
Tuberculosis of the intestine, treatment would include ATT
Shigelosis is the causative organism and Fluoroquinolones are used for treatment

questions.text: A 28 year old woman presented with tenesmus, blood in stools. On evaluation was found to have flask shaped ulcers in the intestine. What is the causative organism and the treatment of choice for the following condition?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea, bloody stool and tenesmus with flask shaped ulcers in the intestine is suggestive of amoebiasis.
Amoebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone. Clinically, infection with entamoeba histolytica may present as.
Amoebic colitis as described above.Flask shaped ulcers occur as the organism attaches to the colonic epithelium invades the crypts and burrows laterally.
Entamoeba histolytica can also present as amoebic liver abcess. Here Patients usually present with fever, abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver. A characteristic "anchovy sauce-like" pus may be seen.Ref- Paniker Textbook of Parasitology 8th edition Page 15-24

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Stool examination reveals an organism with 4 pairs of flagella exhibiting falling leaf motility. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with loose, bulky, foul-smelling stools and abdominal pain, typical of giardiasis.

  • Stool examination findings:

    • Trophozoite with 4 pairs of flagella

    • Characteristic falling leaf motility under the microscope

  • Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan causing malabsorption and watery diarrhea.

Remarks on other options:

  • Cryptosporidium parvum: Causes watery diarrhea; oocysts seen on acid-fast staining; no flagella or falling leaf motility.

  • E. coli: Bacterial diarrhea; motility is peritrichous, no falling leaf pattern.

  • Isospora belli: Causes diarrhea in immunocompromised; oocysts are acid-fast; no flagella.



Reference

1. Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition - Page no: 35
2.Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - page 263

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a classic case of severe falciparum malaria.

Key Clinical Clues:

  • High-grade fever

  • Hypotension

  • Tachycardia

  • Fatigue

  • Peripheral smear shows banana-shaped gametocytes or multiple ring forms per RBC → these are characteristic of P. falciparum.

    Diagnostic Features on Peripheral Smear:

Species Morphology on Blood Smear
P. falciparum Multiple rings per RBC, appliqué forms, crescent-shaped (banana) gametocytes
P. vivax Enlarged RBCs, Schüffner's dots, amoeboid trophozoites
P. malariae Band forms, smaller RBCs, fewer infected cells
P. ovale Oval-shaped RBCs, Schüffner's dots, fimbriated edges

Other options: 

  • P. vivax: Typically causes tertian fever; smear shows enlarged RBCs with Schüffner’s dots.

  • P. malariae: Quartan fever pattern; band-shaped trophozoites.

  • P. ovale: Rare; has fimbriated margins and oval RBCs.

    Clinical pearl: 

  • P. falciparum is the most dangerous malaria parasite due to its ability to infect RBCs of all ages, cause cytoadherence, and lead to cerebral malaria, renal failure, and shock.

  • Treatment includes IV artesunate or quinine in severe cases.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 1724,1730
